RATING: 4
All hail Monster Yahtzee. Shines at 4-5p with the right crowd to stoke the showmanship of it, but elsewhere it can fall flat. In particular, once you're down to just 2 players, the game sort of comes apart in regards to attacks and stars. The other problem is people want to collect stars and wimp out; this is a Godzilla form of demolition derby, quit hiding. Great when folks get into the group (best with giant foam dice, people get into some sort of costume or getup, maybe an MC to stoke it). Also good with small children to get them into gaming or to for new people who have no background with gaming. Sort of lame the rest of the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[i]tl;dr the biggest redeeming virtue of this one is its simplicity, and I want to love it, but the game is just not there. Maybe if I got one of the expansions...[/i]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

King of Tokyo is a very solid filler that's great for kids -- just what I wanted to add to the collection. I call it "Yahtzee with monsters." Basically, players try to roll specific combos on their dice to punch other monsters, gain victory points, and buy special abilities with energy cubes; all without letting their health drop to zero! First player to 21 points wins. 

This is not a game that I'd call my personal favorite, as I love more complex and strategic games. Then again, I've only played it once so there's very likely more here than meets the eye. However, I love seeing other people have fun and King of Tokyo really makes our game selection more well-rounded for the game group, so everything works out all right. This is a great game if kids are around and want to play something simple, or if you've got a bunch of non-gamers with no stomach for complicated rules. Only takes about fifteen minutes to explain and not too much longer than that to play (plus, chunky dice and cutout monsters are always a solid addition to any game).  

Verdict: Simple to explain, very simple to play. Fun for everyone. Bonus points if players get into their monster personalities. 6/10, recommended.

RATING: 8
It's Yahtzee with combat, card-buying, and an awesome theme. If you're looking for a medium-weight or heavy game, this is not it. However, it's a great, perfect game. It's short, it has dramatic moments, it is social, full of interaction.. there's a lot to love here. It can easily appeal both to completely new gamers and to the very experienced, who will see it as a nice game to warm up with or to play as a longer filler. Probably going to buy the power-up at some point.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This was a HUGE hit with my friends, which is a big bonus for me because it gets everybody together and excited for gaming! The monsters are awesome, the superpowers are full of diversity, and the risk/reward of entering/exiting the city push the intensity skyward. 

I guess the real selling point for me is the fact that I've always loved Yahtzee mechanics, but Yahtzee itself feels so hollow. The different methods of achieving victory also add to why I like it. You can try to go all out with attacks or try for the points or try for some cards that may give you the edge in both scenarios. I wasn't sure I'd really like this game, but when I found it on sale and tried it with some friends, it wasn't until we were playing and then playing again and then playing again that I realized how brilliant and fun it was.

This is a great example of a game that fills a role in my collection. So often, I only desire games that are full of strategy and slow-burn progression, with story elements and special abilities. Those games are usually pretty time-consuming and difficult to get to the table with certain groups, so I need games that I can enjoy when I'm unable to get my favorite fix. And it's to the credit of these kinds of games that they fill that void and do it so well. That's reason enough for it to be high on my list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

LIKE: Dice + monsters. The game is best when it's fast and chaotic. Good for young and old. High replayability. 
DISLIKE: Drawn out games when everyone is conservative is not as fun. Dislike the player elimination, which can lead to some downtime.

OVERALL: I seem to have a good time with this game, win or lose.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the perfect game for our family right now. Even my non-gamer teenage daughter likes to play (although she tries to just be a pacifist and win with energy card combos). We usually play with four to six players, but my son (12) and I sometimes play a few rounds one-on-one. One variation we like to use when we do this is to decide on a number (between 5 and 20) and then randomly deal out seven to ten energy cards each. We then get to keep any number of cards that total in cost equal to or lesser than the number we chose. If we choose a high number (10 or more), then we play that we can only put one of these free cards into play at the start of each turn, while temporary (single-use) cards may be held indefinitely. Other cards can still be purchased as normal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Let me start by saying that I would kill to have a shirt that has the Urbavore on it (it only eats urban areas!) This is another game I was introduced to at a friend's birthday party. And the first round I was just watching and cheering the destruction on! The people who didn't know me were shocked at how much I was getting into the game (Crush that monster! You call two damage a lot? Go back to the slime pit you crawled out of!) But come on, who doesn't love the cheesy old giant monster movies? Gamera anyone? 

This game combines my favorite things: clever cards, cute art, and utter DESTRUCTION! The first time I got to play, I got crushed before I could even have a turn – which admittedly did make me angry – but I calmed down, got back in the game, and played jointly with my husband (who is great at calming my wild rages). And while we didn't win the next game either, it was a ton of fun. 

But the third game was the one that we rocked! We had to perfect storm of cards – a card that allowed us to reroll all “3”s and a card where if you roll one of every symbol on six dice we gain 10 points. We did that twice. 20 points from two otherwise useless rolls. It was glorious. The cards really can change the dynamic of the game. And this is one I will definitely be playing again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
King of Tokyo is one of the best gateway games out there - it's Yahtzee with monsters!  It doesn't hit the table much anymore, but it's fun every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Battle Yahtzee and King of the hill with a rampage theme. You play a monster whose goal is to either gain 20 vp first or to be the last monster standing at the end of the rumble in the east. You gain vp by entering and staying j. Tokyo, through cards, and by rolling certain combinations on your dice on your round. Fun, light, and quick this is a great game by the designer of mtg worth playing before or after a meaty one or with more casual gamer friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I had very limited expectations for this game.  There seemed to be a lot of randomness involved and it really looked like a dice throwing contest.

I was wrong.  Luck is a good factor but there is some nice strategy twists as well :should you leave Tokyo or not? which dice should be re-thrown?  Should you buy this ability card or not?  

There are also bonus laughters garanteed in every games!

Seriously enjoy that one with my kids.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
If you're looking for a party game with simple rules and relatively quick play-time, or if you're in the market for a game to introduce to your young child (maybe 6 or 7+ yrs old), this is the game for you.

KoT is extremely easy to learn, very smooth to play, and packs a lot of humor and whimsy in a small box. There isn't any real bean-counting that has to be done, as the little player "plaque" you have uses two sturdy little counter dials to keep track of your health and VP.

I can't say this enough: the theme and artwork are one of the strongest aspects of this game. Garfield et al clearly have a deep appreciation of the kaiju/monster movie genre, and it shows through in technicolor. My wife and I were giggling and reading out the flavor text on each power-up card that was flipped, and we've only seen 1/10th of the deck. I can't wait to see what other silly cards and beautiful designs lay in there!

The mechanics are a mix of push-your-luck dice-rolling, direct aggression, and some light strategy. Do you roll in an attempt to get energy cubes, or try and get more health? Or perhaps attack the monster in Tokyo, or [if YOU are that monster] attack everyone else? What about VP? Maybe you should roll for that!

The power-up cards are entertaining, and (as the name suggests) some are quite powerful! In another game, it might annoy me that some of the cards feel overpowered/unbalanced, but in KoT, it is all in service of the chaos and unpredictability of the game. Much like Love Letter or Ticket to Ride, people in the lead don't have an iron grip on their advantage, and the cards do much to shake up the ladder of players.

I love KoT, and I recommend it for anyone looking for a fun, light, and silly game to add to their collection. Eclipse or Power Grid this is not, so if Munchkin-style luck and aggression annoys you, you may wish to steer clear. However, if the theme appeals to you, and you have a spot in your collection for a simpler, lighter title, you can't go wrong with KoT.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
One of my family's favorite games.

It plays on the old Godzilla theme, except you are one of many monsters fighting for control of Tokyo and you don't care how much gets destroyed, so long as the others get damaged and you get "fame."

The core engine is a Yahtzee-based mechanic.  This is a Richard Garfield design, so that means it has plenty of expansions, but those expansions take a good game and make it better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A relatively simple game with big, chunky dice and gorgeous window dressing. The artwork drew me in first, and the large six-sided dice and humorous power-up and bonus cards kept me in. Half the game is its visual charm and light humor, but I can't say I felt like I was truly a giant monster stomping around, destroying buildings and having epic battles. Rather, it's a competitive points-acquisition/dice-rolling game centered around a king of the hill mechanic. 

Conceptually, where are the other monsters if they're not "in" Tokyo (the tiny board that comes with the game)? Why does one monster's attacks within a giant city impact every other monster not in the city next to him/her? It doesn't make much sense, but it's so pretty and simple you don't mind. Humorous and ridiculous scenarios on the item and bonus cards (often showing monsters that aren't one of the base set you can play as) help spur your imagination and visualize epic battles.

You can win by acquiring 20 points first or by eliminating all the other monsters. If you get knocked out of the game by losing all your life points, however, you hope for the remaining players/monsters to wrap it up quickly, which may or may not happen with the tug of war that can happen with certain item cards' hail Mary moves.

As for whether to get the expansions, I'd definitely recommend the (Panda-kai) Powered Up expansion as it makes the selection of monster actually have meaning. The Powered Up expansion provides unique ability cards that each monster can earn by rolling three hearts. Only in this way does each monster have a unique ability set and personality. Otherwise, the depth of your monster selection in the base game has about as much meaning and impact as the rest of the theme-- it's pure window dressing. That being said, Powered Up's monster-specific cards don't do as much as I'd like, as the odds of you acquiring and using more than one or two of them (out of a set of 12) in a given game is slim.

Thankfully, the base game, and the ability to roll and re-roll dice to your liking is fun enough on its own. King of Tokyo is a great gateway game-- light and pretty-- and a nice way to start up or end a night of gaming. Recommended.

Positives
- Easy to pick up and play
- Fantastic graphic design and theme
- Plays fast, encouraging "just one more round"
- For a game centered on dice rolling, it's nice you can always re-roll as many dice as you like at least twice

Negatives
- Theme is only skin-deep
- Monsters aren't unique without Powered Up expansion
- Easy to get knocked out of the game early and be sitting around waiting for it to end
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
+ Promo Cards.

I'm not a big fan of dice games, but this is on of the best I've ever seen. The idea of big monsters fighting each other like in those hysterical trash movies is splendid and the goofy artwork makes it ever more enjoyable.

For its characteristics King of Tokyo isn't only a great gateway game, that can be easily taught and enjoyed by non-gamers, but also a good filler game to take out, when you just want to have some fun without having to concentrate and build a strategy.

Rating without expansions: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
*When I heard of the theme I couldn't believe it hadn't reached a mainstream audience before. There's some quirky component choices (redundant tokens, doubles of random cards, fluro dice) aiding the immersion.

*Multiplayer conflict games are a great argument for the redundancy of modern boardgames: they have kingmaking, turtling and opportunism in spades. King of Tokyo avoids most of these problems. You are attacking the same area, so no favouritism. The leader gets to hit everyone else equally: no turtling. It's incredibly innovative in such a simple ruleset. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Awesomely fun game by the creator of Magic: the Gathering. It's almost like a mix between Godzilla and Street Fighter. You control a massive monster who is wreaking havoc on Tokyo and you win by destroying all the other monsters who stand in your way.
Card abilities add a fun mechanic to the game, but you still must rely on both luck of the dice and careful strategy when prioritizing when to attack and when to heal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
It's a pretty boring non-game that might keep kids out of your hair for a couple of hours. Roll dice. Roll more dice. Play a generic game-theory version of Chicken to push your luck (google game of Chicken if you don't know what this is). It's Yahtzee plus chicken. Most of the board isn't even used and could be replaced by a couple coffee stains on your table. The base game offers no difference in the characters either, so they amount to nothing more than a d12 for health and a d20 for victory points. The entire game is basically the custom dice and the cards. As such, it's overproduced and underdelivers. The expansions add a bit more fun but we're not talking buy-worthy.

RATING: 4

- The group wasn't too big of a fan of it
- The theme didn't really come through

RATING: 8
Simple but highly addicting game! The game might not have the true names for Godzilla, King Kong and all the other monsters due to copyright reasons but you get the picture! A must have is the Power Up expansion that makes the game much more thematic and interesting!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
At best, King of Tokyo is just a bunch of random events that occur before ending in short order. Theoretically there are some choices (which you can attempt to make using the Yahtzee mechanic), but they all balance out the same, so there's no real difference between getting Door A or Door B, and often you're not able to get what you were going for anyways. So, in the end, it's not much different than Uno, but far shorter.

But, if you get 6+ players, anyone not killed in the first 10-15 minutes will get enough power-up cards to become almost invincible, causing the game to stretch out for 2-3 hours, as the 2-3 invincible players try to kill one another, which is less than thrilling if you have been eliminated than the game. (And the one time I was one of the invincible players, I still wasn't terribly thrilled, since it's still just elaborate Uno, for 2-3 hours.)

Overall, I'd suggest playing King's Kilt over King of Tokyo. Guaranteed to last only 15 minutes and some actual choices to be made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

But I wouldn't mind pulling it out to have some new gamers have a go at it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A hilarious romp where players act as gargantuan beasts, intent on taking over Tokyo (a'la Godzilla).  Simple mechanism where players roll dice and bash the hell out of each other, but it's not all bashing.  You need to balance your health and victory points, gain energy, which allows you to buy power-up cards to affect play.  Fabulous cartoony artwork underpins a light, tactical luck fest that is simply lots and lots of fun.  Quick to learn and play, in around 20-30 mins.  Works best with 5-6 players, not so good with 2.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
An incredibly accessible game, which accommodates 2-6 players very well.  Nice, quick games means you'll play several times each time you get it out.  We've played it 20+ times in the 3 weeks we've had it.  My kids love it, and there's enough to mull over to keep me interested.  A very good game by a very good designer.

UPDATE (05/10/2014): In my view, this will prove to be another Richard Garfield classic, right up there with Magic: The Gathering and RoboRally.  If you have kids, you can't go wrong here.  We have played this game repeatedly and consistently since I purchased it a few years ago.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Light game. Great art. A bit too random for me.

RATING: 9.5
By far the best game to play with non gamers.  Also, best way to introduce people to Euro games!  This game will introduce new gamers to the idea of collecting sets, gaining resource cubes, acquiring and using special ability cards, and getting victory points.  Also its just great fun on every level.  Another game that goes everywhere with me.  Only issue I have with the game is the rolling for VPs strategy becomes dominant with 5-6 players, but I fix this by only playing with 4.

RATING: 9
I have many dice games in my collection, especially ones that can be considered as "Yahtzee on steroids" (Roll Through the Ages, Dice Town, etc.).  King of Tokyo sets itself apart through a variety of reasons.  It's mechanics are easy to understand, plays fast and it's theme really shines through.  For me, King of Tokyo is a rare game that perfectly fills its niche as a fun and immersive dice filler.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game is essentially a reskinned Yahtzee, but that is ok to me, since I liked Yahtzee as a child. The monster theme and power cards are great additions. Plays quickly and the fact that it can support a decent amount of players are both positives in its favor. Very swingy (had one game where a player in Tokyo rolled 6 paws, eliminating 3 players in one turn) and there really isn't a strategy so much as you're just being pure reactionary the whole game. It is definitely one of those games that lends itself well to session stories.

\_______GER_______/
Das Spiel ist ja schon einfach gestrickt, aber es macht einfach eine Menge Spaß mit seinem Monster entweder die 20 Ruhmespunkte zu erreichen oder einfach alle anderen Monster in die See vor Tokyo zu versenken.
Eigentlich hat das Spiel allen Mitspielern bisher Spaß gemacht (Familie von 8 bis 85 Jahren; wobei das hohe Alter sogar fast gewonnen hätte wenn nicht eine monströs unfaire  Wiederbelebungskarte einem schon scheintoten Monster am Ende noch den Sieg ermöglich hätte ...).
Nur Spieler die das Spiel etwas zu Ernst nehmen und dem Würfeln im Allgemeinen mit Argwohn begegnen haben weniger Spaß an diesem Spiel. Das Thema hatte jedenfalls bisher noch niemanden vom Mitspielen abgehalten. Und in einer Runde von 3 bis 6 Spielern hatten wir unseren Spaß gehabt. Für einen ganzen Spieleabend reicht es natürlich nicht aber zum Anfang oder Ende eine lustige Sache.

Da mir das Grundspiel schon gut gefallen hat, musste das Pandamonster aus der Erweiterung [thing=127067]Power Up![/thing] dann unbedingt auch noch dazu...
Der Panda hat totales Niedlichkeitspotential und wird sicherlich gerne als Hauptfigur ausgewählt werden.
Die Mutationskarten geben extra taktische Möglichkeiten die das Spiel wieder etwas weiter vom einfachen Kniffel entfernen. Ob man diese Erweiterung unbedingt haben muß, ist eine andere Sache (also unbedingt sicherlich nicht, aber schaden kann es auch nicht).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A good gateway game that has more strategy than you'd originally expect from a Yahtzee-style dice game. Very easy to teach and plays pretty fast. Great theme with large, fun visuals.

One downside is that I don't feel like the game scales very well. It plays at best by far with four players, with more players weakening the points strategy because health is always an issue with more players to punch you.

RATING: 7.4
A very light/filler game, but one that's quite fun to play.  Easy rules (Yahtzee-like) with several paths toward game end (roll for hits, roll for heals, roll for victory points, roll for energy cubes?) allow for several paths to be taken each and every game.

Quick setup, quick breakdown, (family) fun, simple gameplay with some strategic and tactical decisions, too -- a lot to like in one box.

Just realize it is what it is  -- this ain't no AP-prone Euro here at all...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
Watch my review
http://youtu.be/ZJFI-2-IGEk

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
King of Tokyo is one of a number of light-weight dice games to come out in the last couple years.  It's got master designer, Richard Garfield's considerable talent behind it which gives it a leg up against other games competing for the same space in my closet.

KoT is a game of King of the Hill mixed with classic Yahtzee.  Rolling dice will do damage to other players, heal your own wounds, or give you points or energy.

Almost all dice games can suffer if they go on too long and this can certainly happen in King of Tokyo.  Games will usually only last about 30 minutes, but the ones that go longer feel WAY too long.

This is a problem made worse by the fact that King of Tokyo does have player elimination.  In my mind player elimination is always a weakness in a design.  It's a flaw that can be mitigated by short play-time, but I pretty much always dislike it when players get knocked out of a game.

So what I end up with is a somewhat uneven impression of the game.  When it is working -- when you have a buncha monsters slugging it out with lots of cool special powers on the table, and when the game is short (under 30 minutes), it's a very fun and very easy-to-play filler.  

but there are games that drag on for too long and end up being sort of boring.

the one bit of warning I would offer is that if all players are ONLY focusing on killing the other monsters (which is probably most gamers' natural tendency), the game has a much better chance of dragging on for too long.  The "victory by points" is a pretty reliable timer as long as one or two players at the table are keeping that as an option for winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I don't think staying in, or even going to, Tokyo is a good ideia, especially so with a lot of players. Since everyone can attack players in Tokyo you will take a lot of damage if you stay in Tokyo (that's why with big player counts, 2 players go to Tokyo to reduce the nr of players attacking those in Tokyo, but still you'll take lots of damage). Trying to roll 3 of a kind of numbers 1,2 or 3 is an easier way to get points without having to go to Tokyo. The problem is that if you roll Attack in your last roll, and a space in tokyo gets unoccupied, you'll have to go to Tokyo even if you'd rather not go.
CON: dificult to see other players health and victory points.

RATING: 9
Boiled down: Yahtzee style game where you roll 6 dice to attack your enemies, heal yourself and purchase special abilities.

Likes: Lots of fun attacking other monsters. Lots of dice rolling. Excellent artwork and production. Finding the balance between attacking, healing and purchasing abilities. 

Dislikes: Difficult to read other players VP/HP cards. Player elimination (however most games are short and players are back into a new game within 10 minutes.)

RATING: 6
Richard Garfield strikes back, after many years since his best designs (Magic, RoboRally and Netrunner)!

King of Tokyo is a very simple yatzee variant, with mathematic elegance that supports different patterns of "strategy" towards victory. And, more important: it is a GREAT FUN filler!! Being the King of the Hill (or of the city, in this case) and bullying the others is very thematic and introduces some light-hearted choices that make this dice game stand above the others...

Highly recommended, and I guess my daughters will enjoy it when they will grow up!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Initial Impressions: This is a great dice-rolling game with a yahtzee mechanism. The real fun comes with the variable power cards, which add alot of variety to the game. The components are well done. It can be taught in under 5 minutes and enjoyed by almost anyone. A perfect gateway game that doesn't last too long.

10 Plays: This game is still going strong with my family. The sweet spot for us is 4 players, as more will make the wait between turns too long. The expansion has breathed lots of life into the game and is requested every time we play.

RATING: 10
Ah!  Beautiful smashy wonderfully universally loved King of Tokyo!  I have played this more than any game hands down.  Most of my game group loves this, and my 80+ year old grandmother loves it.  She was disappointed when I didn't bring it to a family gathering!  It is light enough to be easy to understand, but offers just enough choices to make smacking monsters around so much fun!  And it is brilliant that there are multiple paths to victory in such a simple game because it helps it appeal to a lot of different people, I have found.  It isn't a deep game.  At all.  But it is really really hard to not get into the mood of it and just laugh when you die by the monster before you rolling 5 or 6 claws.  It is hard to be bitter at this game at all.  Just brilliant.

RATING: 7.5
7/21/2015 - (I have owned this game for about one year and have played it around 20-30 times.)

I have never loved King of Tokyo until today! Today was my first time playing with the Power Up! expansion and it was VERY fun! King of Tokyo was just a good game, but it has turned into a great game for me because of the Power Up! expansion.

This will be my final written review for King of Tokyo the base game. All future reviews will be written under the Power Up! expansion or future expansions as I will never play King of Tokyo again without the Power Up! expansion. 

Furthermore, my rating for King of Tokyo will reflect the Base game AND the Power Up expansion for now. In the future, This rating will increase if more expansions are released as I always rate a board game based on using my optimal choices of expansions.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPDATE: Lowering my score slightly with this game because I just plain done think I will come back to it now that I have King of New York. KoNY has officially brought to light the biggest flaws of KoT.

2/17/2014: Hands down one of the best games for any level of gamer. Not only is it a solid game, it also makes for an excellent primer for more complex strategy or RPG based games. Add in the power up expansion and you even have unique powers for each player. If I were to pick a game to prepare gamers for things like Krosmaster Arena or Super Dungeon Explore or Zombicide, this would be it for sure.

UPDATE: This is still a favorite for me.  I have finally had the chance a few times to play with larger groups and it does change the game quite a bit.  I still enjoy a 2-player game but the 4 or more player games are far more intense and interesting.  I'd say 4 is about right, but even 6 players is not too hectic with the right group of people.  As always, games like this are best played with people who can laugh about trash talk and asshole moves.  I love this game and have no intention of ever lowering my score.

Love this game! It is a perfect mix of battle with a great dice mechanic. I've only played it twice and only 2-player. I'm betting it is even better with more people. I must have the expansion to this where the monsters have specialized power up cards.

RATING: 7.75
Silly, silly fun! Dice rolling, attacking your opponents, special abilities on cards you can purchase, all this leads to a really fun game. My only gripe with KOT is that there seems to really be only 1 way to win. That being to damage the other players to get rid of all of their health. I have attempted the victory point route numerous times, to no avail. If anyone has a good strategy to win via VP's, please let me know!

RATING: 6.4
Game Time: 30-90 Mins
Players: 2-4
Play as a kaiju warrior and fight for control of Tokyo in this king of the hill beat em up dice roller. Good for adults and children alike.

Additional Resources:
Halloween Expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You roll and reroll big, sexy dice to damage other monsters, heal your monster, earn energy to spend on cards that power up your monster, and to score victory points. The board is simple: If you are the King of Tokyo, your monster is on the board. All the monsters that are not the King of Tokyo are off the board.

A big roll can certainly determine the outcome of the game but mostly it's a back and forth battle. The key to the balance is that if you're the King of Tokyo, you get to damage all the monsters outside Tokyo and earn victory points for being King, and if you're not the King of Tokyo, you have the ability to heal. A monster will reign as King as long as it can to score victory points but eventually gets wounded enough that it has to relinquish its throne and heal. 

It's a fast-paced game that's quick to set up and quick to learn, great fun when there's a lot riding on a roll, and not too deep, making for light but exciting fare.

RATING: 6
Thank god this game allows you to win through victory points, because the defensive cards turn the slugfest into a slogfest.

A fun, rather simple game that lets you push your luck in a number of directions, so there are strategies to be pursued, you just might not get the cooperation of the dice.  The cards which allow you to change facets of the game keep it fresh and keep you paying attention.

Getting knocked out early can be a drag because sometimes the game isn't quick, but usually it's fine.

RATING: 8
I really liked it, but this had the same problem I had with Alien Frontiers:  Eventually you can't keep track of the 37 different player powers you and others have.  (This was with the "Power Up" expansion.)

Other than that, for being what someone called (and I agree) 'an exercise', it was a really fun exercise.  

It had wild point swings, super over-powered cards.  You get 2-3 bad rolls in a row, and you're hurtin'.  I don't want to say it's all luck, but a good roll will get you 1/5th of the way to the end of the game.  For the game length it definitely kept interest and had a fair deal of tactics.

-Power Up!
-Halloween

RATING: 8
So apparently, Richard Garfield was sitting around his mansion* thinking about Yahtzee.  "You know what would make Yahtzee great?" he said to himself.  "Freakin' GODZILLA."  And because he's Richard Garfield, he was right.  Fast-paced dice game of rampaging and monster-brawling, with a mutation/special event mechanism that gives it a lot of replay value.  Offers you enough meaningful decisions to prevent the strong luck-based elements from overwhelming the game.  Good times.

(* -- Successful game designers DO live in mansions, yes?)

RATING: 8
Lok: BHKJ020303
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lok: BHKJ020303
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Who would have thought that you could get a great game about battling monsters with a simple Yahtzee-style dice mechanism. But don't let that scare you, because the only thing Yahtzee like about this game is the fact that you roll 3 times and save dice to accomplish your goals. The 2 goals make for some interesting gameplay because sometimes players become overly aggressive and try destroying their foes, while other times people become very defensive and shoot for points. But the true magic of this game are the mutation cards. It is so cool that you can buy special abilities and slowly adapt your monster into something unique. Each card you buy can slightly alter your strategies for the rest of the game, and I love that. This is a superb game that I'd recommend to anyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
It's a fun change of pace from the games I usually play. It still has opportunity for strategy, but is more satisfying as a push-your-luck dice chucking big monster brawling king of the hill thematic experience. It's also excellent for introducing new people to board gaming. It's highly accessible, with some depth of choices as to when to hold/leave Tokyo, when to try and heal vs attack, when to focus on hoarding energy, when to buy cards, and when to clear cards. It's humorous, over-the-top, monstrous fun. I prefer KoT with the Power Up! expansion. The evolutions add an interesting element of unique special bonuses. The player elimination in KoT is a bummer. Usually it doesn't happen too early, though, so it doesn't tend to drag on like some games *cough* Bang *cough*.

(I do have to add that I haven't really played KoT since getting King of New York, which is everything I love about KoT plus deeper decisions and more to do.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Not just plain fun. The best kind of quick awesome fun.

RATING: 6
A quick, fun and light game of yahtzee-like dice rolling while attacking other monsters.  It's fun to attack, heal, score point, collect energy to improve your monster and balance all of these in order to win the game.  You win by either destroying everyone else or scoring 20 points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Card and Dice game with victory point mechanism. 

As a "fearsome" monsters you'd like to destroy Tokyo or - if necessary... or suitable - your fellow monsters.
Through dice rolls you get victory points, regain health, hurt other monsters or collect energy. 
The latter helps you to "buy" special abilities or more victory points and brings you closer to your goal: To rule over Tokyo!

The mechanism is simple: You are either in Tokyo and if not you might want to go there; be it only to shoo other monsters away from YOUR Tokyo.

One of my familie's favourite game. 
(playtime for 4+ players: 30 to 60 min)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
A light mega-monster themed yahtzee-type dice game.  Players choose their monsters and roll dice (3 rolls, keeping dice which they choose) to attack each other, accrue energy (for cards which improve their monster / abilities).  There is player elimination but non-serious theme and quick play time (approx. 30 minutes) makes this a non-issue.  Great for kids and adults.  Need at least three people to play unless you want to insert a "dummy monster player" to play with two (i.e. non-official variant where you add a non-player monster to roll and keep life and attack for monster outside of tokyo on his/her turn).  I have gotten enough use out of this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a classic, evergreen, gateway game. Players roll dice yahtzee style to either gain points, do damage, heal, or gain energy to use on power up cards. If you are in tokyo, you get more points, but can't heal and are the target of other players attacks.

While I personally like the sequel, king of new york, better, this is played more purely because it is simpler and easier to teach.

RATING: 8
I love to roll my dice, so King of Tokyo was a game I couldn’t miss trying, yet I’m still undecided about it. Don’t get me wrong, I like it: I just can’t get all that excited about its theme, since I don’t like big ravaging monsters nor Far-Eastern science fiction B-movies. 
Which means everything this game is about.

Anyhow, even though its theme leaves me pretty cold, I think King of Tokyo is fun to play, since it’s light, fast and dice-heavy. (March 2012)

[b]Update[/b] - After further playing King of Tokyo I’ve started to enjoy it despite its unattractive theme: as a matter of fact when everyone tries to hit hard it rocks! Sadly though some players still care for just grinding victory points rather than crushing their opponents, which makes the game a bit dull as it deprives it of its main source of fun.

Anyway, in July 2013 I raised my rating from 6 to 8 as it makes for lots of sparkles.

RATING: 5
Érdekes egy játék. Valójában kellemes meglepetés, de mégis úgy érzem semmivel sem több egy szerencsejátéknál azaz egy kockapókernél. Fogalmazhatok úgy, hogy egy kockapóker kibővítése egy tematikával és némi célirányú döntésekkel. Az akciókártyák némi képen adnak valamiféle stratégiát, de némelyik kártya egy vicc. Egy példa: 8-ért vehetek egy kártyát, melyet ha eldobok kilencem lesz. Szóval nem mondanám, hogy egy társasággal nem ülök le vele játszani, de hogy a polcomat nem érdemli meg az biztos. Még remélem kipróbálhatom a kiegészítővel is. A kockák minősége kriminális. Dobhatatlan ormótlan . Értem én, hogy a szörny méretek érzését szerették volna kelteni, de szerintem használhatatlan. Egy dobótálcát mindenképen érdemes használni hozzá.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This might be my favorite filler. More than any other filler in my collection it seems to match weight and play time with the silly, fun theme. The decisions are not only interesting, they're entertaining. Does the giant robotic bunny blast the monstrous radiated lizard out of Tokyo...or does the giant robotic bunny elect to grow another head?!? I like 7 Wonders and Colossal Arena very much, but there is a certain distance that one has from the way the mechanics interact with the theme; it's also hard for the short playtimes to establish much of an investment. That's why the term "filler" is so often appropriate not as a criticism but as a sober acknowledgment of the limitations of a shorter game. With King of Tokyo, though, you just find yourself rooting for your monster. "Go Giant Robotic Bunny! Use your carrot death ray!" It's the board game equivalent of a mash up of "Rock'em, Sock'em Robots" and Sunday afternoon Japanese monster movie features. It's not too serious and is the perfect game to squeeze in between heavier courses or for the end of an evening.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has been a hit with every group I have played it with. The most fun "Take That!" game I have played.

Edit: Most played game in my collection. Most laughs generated by a game...this one is a winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best fun you can have with your clothes on, although I suspect it's pretty good fun without them too. To shine, you need to get into the spirit of the game, badmouthing your opponents and bragging about your powers. The mechanics are wedded blissfully to a wonderful theme which is captured perfectly in the magnificent artwork - some of the art on the cards is brilliant. There is a real game underneath all the glitter though, and there are some tough choices, some push-your-luck (how long can you last in Tokyo) and lots of interaction with the other monsters, I mean players. Already one of my all-time favourites. Buy it and love it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
THE gateway game

RATING: 7
2 plays:

Light and quick but compelling. Kids like it, and can play it, but it has enough tricky decisions to sustain attention from more sophisticated gamers. Takes absolutely no setup and really doesn't even require much explanation to new players. Works with as few as two players or as many as six.. I wish the power up cards were more consistently interesting, though; gameplay doesn't seem to get beyond a thin level of depth. Still, very satisfying and with excellently designed components.

RATING: 10
King of Tokyo does what few games have ever done...make a fun game that can be taught in 3-5 minutes yet has enough depth to satisfy the regular gamer. I have literally tried this game with all types of different groups, including sure fire non-gamers and usually disinterested family members, and not one person has walked away with bad things to say about the experience. 

In fact, the experience alone has been enough to get several others to buy the game. If that's not a ringing endorsement, I don't know what is. Best game of 2012 in this household, even if it is completely silly monster smashing and dice rolling!

RATING: 7
It's not a surprise that this game was designed by Richard Garfield, because it's freaking awesome! At first glance, it's just a simple, Dakaiju-themed party game. However, after your first game, you'll realize that it does have a little bit of depth to it. That small amount of strategy is actually what sets this apart from all of the other hyper-light party games out there, and it's also why you and your group will keep coming back for more monster smashing action.

VERDICT:

As an ameritrash lover, I have to dig the fact that I'm a gigantic monster, terrorizing Tokyo. I'm also looking forward to playing the expansions.

7/10

RATING: 6
Yahtzee as a non-party-party-game.
You have some big dice, roll and reroll them and see what you get.
Some points? Victory here I come.
Some hearts? These let you heal up.
Some energy? Let's you buy cool stuff.
Or you get some claws and beat your enemies down.

King of Tokyo is a great game to start / end a game night with something light and fun. But that's it.
Ohkay, you have the urge to play a second round...
...but after that you are done with the game very quickly.

It's good as a filler or a small party game.

RATING: 5
I've probably played this 15-20 times, and with every play I like it less and less.

The short pitch is "It's like yahtzee, but you're all monsters trying to kill each other".  That's fine, as far as it goes.  But the game tends to drag on for quite a while, and the turns very rarely involve interesting decisions.  You just roll the dice and see what you get - there isn't enough wiggle room to actually try for different strategies.

RATING: 7
Not that much to this game when you get down to it but it has that essential fun factor which lifts it beyond what you might expect.  The rules are very simple, but it's worth highlighting the "you can't heal in Tokyo" rule - which is what makes the game (as it forces you to chose between death and glory and, very cleverly, drives the game on to a conclusion).  And, even though it's an elimination game, it's short enough for that not to be a real problem. Rating up a notch after another couple of plays, which is always a good sign.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While there is a fun little dice rolling game here, this is really a case of the components making the game.  Sure, you get to make a couple decisions about rolling dice, but the game has sweet cardboard monsters, score trackers, energy cubes, and beautifully illustrated cards (and a LOT of them too!).

Basically, you're trying to score points in King of Tokyo through rolling some numbers on the dice, using your energy on cards that let you do special stuff, or bashing on Tokyo, where you get points for hanging out.  The problem with hanging out in Tokyo is that, even though you score more points, you get bashed by all the other monsters!  You can also lose by taking too much damage, so carefully choosing your shots is important.

Overall, if you're simply into the mechanics of a game, you probably won't be incredibly excited.  However, if you can appreciate a great application of theme and be swayed by cool components, try this one out!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
+ Power Up! expansion
+ Cthulhu monster pack

RATING: 8
This game is cool. One of the best player elimination games for sure. Quick, fun, easy to learn (although effects of some cards are not well enough explained in the rulebook). RATING: 8
The game is random random random, but as long as everyone plays super aggressively (such that the stars are an oft-forgotten after thought), it's fun.

If everyone plays to passively, trying to build the most powerful monsters possible through energy, or trying to win with stars, then the game can last a really long time and the player elimination is a huge downside (I've had someone get eliminated and fall asleep before the game was finished).

RATING: 10
This is an early rating of 10, however in just a few sessions I have played this game nearly 10 times. And I am amazed at how good this game is. You have to understand what type of game you are going to play if you want to judge it correctly, however just look at the components and you should have a good idea.
If you try and turn this into a number game and strategicaly plan out each move to get the most points, then you are completely misssing the boat. It's a monster mash game, with hidden depth but simple enough to play with the kids and just have fun.

RATING: 4
I really like the idea/feel of this game but the execution lacked.  

2 player version is broken.  Whoever gets tokyo first (i.e. first player) will almost always win.  We played 4 games and never got more than 2 cards bought and never won with victory points.  Games are so quick and luck-based that it's hard to have any strategy other than attack nonstop and hope you roll better than your opponent.

The cards are pretty cool and gameplay is fun.  Will try again with some choice house rules to see if that fixes the problems.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
King of Tokyo is a fast-paced light dice rolling filler game. There is a fair amount of luck involved because of the dice rolls, but you can re-roll them twice so it isn't a huge issue. 

KoT is one of the big hits on BGG. However, I fail to see the fun. To me, the game is very boring, and no, it's not because I don't play it with the right group; I've played with my family, close friends and other friends, and every time I have felt the game was lacking. It just isn't that much fun to attack the other players' monsters in or outside Tokyo, and it just isn't that much fun to score some VPs here and there. 

The cards you can buy help to keep the game fresh, but it also increases the downtime. 
I also feel like it takes too long to actually finish the game even though it's a filler; 30 minutes is way too long for the amount of decisions you face in this game! Heck, even 20 minutes is too long. I don't find it interesting to roll dice and attack a little and get some energy cubes and some VPs.

All in all, King of Tokyo is way, way overrated imho.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Interactive Yahtzee with a nice theme but there aren't many decisions to make. It almost plays itself. Works well as a very light filler, kids' or gateway game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Also includes the promo King of Tokyo cards.[/b]

King of Tokyo is the perfect game for when you want something quick that involves chucking gobs of dice. It's admittedly pretty light, but that doesn't mean it isn't fun. Unlike Yahtzee which is totally solitaire, KoT does encourage you to see what the other players are doing so you can apply pressure accordingly. And that "king of the hill" in the middle allows you to get extra VPs at the expense of putting a target on your back.

The sheer diversity of cards is impressive, and the artwork is very humorous. I love the theme, and it adds to the charm. My one knock is that I wish each character had something to differentiate the abilities. The different monsters are just window dressing, but everyone still picks a favorite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A lot of fun, but even as a light game, had other players get upset from being eliminated. Simple with high luck, but has good strategy elements (Victory Point win, K.O. win, Energy Points to facilitate either quick at the end).  Best strategy to have is to roll with the dice (if victory Points are rolled go with them, if damage is caused go that way, if energy is excessive take that route).  Also avoid being the first into Tokyo.

RATING: 8
I requested this for Christmas (above several other games that I had previously been more interested in) after all of the stellar reviews I read/heard about it and the quick play. I'm so glad I did ask for it, because it is a great game.

It has a relatively small footprint too, my boyfriend and I played it over and over in hospital on the small tables that they give you to eat your food. It was a great laugh, and didn't strain the mind when I was feeling quite run down from meds. It is not so portable that I would take it tramping (hiking) but you could take it if you just took the cards and the die but without the monsters it just wouldn't be the same.

We've also played this at BBQs (when there aren't too many people) and although sometimes the game lasted more like 50mins than 30mins it was still hilarious.

It is easy to teach, not too serious and plays quickly so it is easy to get others to play, and can be played with many different groups of people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
(New edition)

This is harmless, dice-rolling fun with a bit of a monster flavour paste job on top of it. It is only sort of a board game, as the board is only used to show whether players are in the Tokyo zone, or in the "not in Tokyo" zone. All of the monsters are identical but for the theme gloss, that said, don't try to take my Space Penguin away from me or there will be consequences.

The game is primarily about trying to roll sets of like dice using a pool of 6, 6-sided dice ala Yahtzee. You want sets of 3 for the VPs to score, whereas the lightning bolts power up your guy, the hearts heal him, and the claws allow you to deal damage to the players who are in the zone opposite of yours.

The victory mechanism is multi-faceted in that you can try to just go after VPs straight up (mostly by rolling number sets or occupying Tokyo by beating on the current monster there enough to make them want to leave) or you can try to get aggressive and knock the other players out instead. This second option seems to primarily be included as a potential way for people to catch up against a leader with a strong early VP lead.

The only real additional gloss on this game is the power cards. These are cute, and you only see a few of them each game so the mix should add some long term variety to the play. The downside, however, is that the cards are fairly pricey and the game is so short that it's hard to get full use out of them in some cases.

Anyway, it's nothing absolutely amazing, but it's charming filler and one that I am glad to have around in my collection. I would have liked a bit of a tweak to the cards, as I do think they don't come into play quite as much as I would like (as they do add variety) but overall it's hard to fault it. Short and fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Simple fighting game. I'd reccommend it as an entry point for someone who's not used to playing boardgames.

RATING: 5.75

I'm completely "meh" on the game. I get that it is silly fun, but it doesn't feel terribly fun or strategic. It feels like I'm playing it to satisfy my girls. So that's completely worth it, but I wouldn't pull this game out for my friends.

RATING: 8.5
This game can have some rather explosive and crazy endings.  With all the abilities of the cards stacking people begin to dish out a ton of damage in a hurry or they make a quick and massive grab of points.  One good thing about it is until that flurry happens you're always in the game and it could be you that gets the roll or the card that swings the tide of the match.  It's about 75:25 luck vs skill.  Finally, the energy cards are well thought out and offer a lot of variety which will give this game a lot of longevity.  It's a very good 10-30 min game (number of players and style of play determines length of game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The very first time I played King of Tokyo I fear I made myself look a bit like nerdy Sheldon for not wanting to continue a statistically completely lost position (meaning I'd end up second, not a bad result for sure). Well, my opponents retorted, isn't it cool that you then win through sheer luck??! No, I replied, that's just dumb, as rolling beter is not really an achievement I want to rely on. And so I proclaimed the other player the deserved #1 (she had a wonderful combo lying in front of her), and we went on playing a different game. After that I did not expect to play King of Tokyo anymore, but a friend of mine bought it, and 'made' me play. To my bemusement, and the other players' annoyance, I found I'm quite good at it, finishing first or second nearly every time. So when I'm challenged again, I always mockingly joke that the players [i]must[/i] have a thing for masochism, seeing that they enjoy being beaten up so thoroughly every time. This infuriates them to the point of taking too many risks, and me beating the crap out of them once more. 

Game-technically King of Tokyo is of course just another Yahtzee-clone, spiced up with fictional Big Monster artwork. Poor Tokyo is just backdrop; and to be honest, once the game is done, I'm not sure there'd be much of the city left to crown the victor 'King of Tokyo'. It's 'King of What Is Left of Tokyo', I fear. There isn't much to talk about it, save, perhaps, the player elimination. The game is short enough that it can be stomached, although it is pushing matters in the 6 player-game. Apart from that, relax, and eat radioactive dice attack!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The most successful gateway game in my collection, King of Tokyo has attracted non-gamers to sit down at the table and play time after time. With various strategies to consider, yet an ease of access that few games possess, the game is the perfect blend of inclusiveness, luck, competition and decision-making. It’s light-weight and (at times) luck-driven, which may not be to everyone’s taste, but desperately deserves a place in almost every gamer's collection, especially those trying to bring new friends into the hobby.

RATING: 9

For those who question the strategy around King of Tokyo, you need look no further than back on a game you lost and ask yourself why. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This dice rolling game is ingenious in its simplicity - one of my favorite traits in a new game.  All you do on your turn is a typical Yahtzee-style role of several dice 3 times, setting aside those you want to keep.  You can score points with sets, attack other players' monsters, heal yourself, or gain energy.  Those energy points get you handy cards to make your character more powerful.

Throwing in a "king of the hill" mechanism, you weigh the risk vs. reward by staying in Tokyo, knowing you can attack all other players but leaving yourself vulnerable.

It's so fast, so easy to learn, I'm just sorry I hadn't played it sooner.  For fans of light, quick games that are fun for the whole family, this game is a home run.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Yahtzee with Monsters? So much more to offer than Yahtzee though. Great art and theme, dice are just cool. works ok with 2 but shines more with 3 or more. Power up pack is almost essential. if you buy the base game get the power up pack as well. it adds more interesting game play. You have cards to buy and energy to obtain and or course monsters to attack. Great for a younger crowd, I have played with kids as young as 5. They really like the monster theme. With a crowd that isn't willing to gamble by staying in Tokyo it can tend to be a bit of a drag and have a run away leader. The Power up gives it more depth and keeps it more interesting even in these situations.

RATING: 5
Components: Cool art on the power-up cards. Fun dice. The VP and health windows on the player boards should be large enough to see from across the table, and should be less prone to accidental changes. The power-up cards are a bit difficult to read from across the table.

Experience: Very chaotic. Huge swings of bad luck can eliminate a player early on, who must then wait up to 20 minutes before the game ends, which isn't any fun.

First Played: 2013-01-03
Last Played: 2013-12-29
Plays (3):
6 players: 3

RATING: 6
It's a blast when played with the right group, one that gets into role-playing their monsters and doesn't take it too seriously. If the group isn't into the theme though, it will fall flat. Gameplay and strategy just isn't very deep or compelling otherwise. I prefer to play it with 4-6 players. Player elimination stinks. If you're knocked out early in the game, it's not fun having to watch everyone else play. King of New York is just a much improved and more interesting version of this game.

RATING: 8
Opening the box, I felt like a kid unwrapping the best Christmas present ever.  The artwork was so cool and the concepts were so fun.  The first couple plays were really cool and tickled my childish funny bone.  However, the more games I've played, I actually don't know if it's much improved over Yahtzee.  The game is about 80% luck, and whenever one person starts running away with points, there is no real catching up.  Games sort of end anticlimactically.  I love the powerup abilities, but the games are usually nearly over before they seem to come into play.  I feel like the rules could be altered to come up with an even better game.

[BGCOLOR=#99FFFF]  [b]7[/b]  [/BGCOLOR] [u]Power Up[/u]: Additional goal for die rolls (options)
[BGCOLOR=#CC99FF]  [b]5[/b]  [/BGCOLOR] [u]Halloween[/u]: Costumes don't make the game feel particularly different. Extra dice are convenient

[b]Variants[/b]
[BGCOLOR=#999FFF]  [b]6[/b]  [/BGCOLOR] [u]Single power-up deck[/u]: All power up cards shuffled into a single deck balances out the playing field by eliminating perceived power differences and 'forced' playstyles

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial rating is a 9. Why did I give such a simple game this high a rating? Because it's so much FUN! I LOVE LOVE LOVE this game! It's getting a ton of play time right now. Due to this game's high fun factor, quick playing time, ease of rules explanation, and excellent artwork, this has to be one of the best games in my collection. I can play this with anyone. Everyone I have played it with has absolutely loved it. When we get done playing, everyone is always asking for one more game. I don't see myself ever getting tired of it. I love it and can't wait to see if they produce more goodness for this in the future. The game is perfect by itself, but I highly recommend getting the promo cards from the BGG store. They're not necessary for the game to be great, but I'd still say they're a must-have because of how awesome some of them are.

Update: This is going to a 10. I just love this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Last year, I had the opportunity to play this many times with kids.  Player count fell between 3 of us and 6 of us.  We only played the base game, and later added a custom dice expansion.  Either way, they revived the game overall for me, and continue to keep it strong.

Old Comment:
After playing the base game MANY times, I only pulled this out for reluctant or new gamers.  However, since adding the Power Up expansion, I will play this game any time.  As such, knowing you have access to particular strategies, based upon the combination of evolution cards that you may acquire, adds a strategic element that is completely absent from the base game.  I don't ever want to play just the base game anymore, unless I'm teaching multiple new players.  Rating increased from 7 to 8 with the Power Up expansion added.

Older Comments:
Quick, fun, and appealing to many different tastes.  My wife won her first play against me, and I had 6 plays under my belt already.  Her response when she won:  "Whoa, that was fast.  That was fun!"

'nuf said.

...though it never goes very fast at player max, rather a bit longer than I think it should.  That may have something to do with the fact that I always seem to be teaching someone new how to play it...

RATING: 4
This game's high rating is completely baffling.  Re-theme yahtzee, add bonus cards, tweak a few rules, and suddenly you have King of Tokyo.

Along with Sentinels of the Multiverse, ZombieDice, Quarriors, and some others, this represents a new wave of boardgaming that harkens back to a time when boardgames were pointless, juvenile luckfests.

RATING: 9

I will never turn down a game of this, it is always welcome at my table. I've yet to play with power-ups either. 

Having said that I have yet to play its new form in King of New York. I have heard there is more to do, which may draw out the length a little, or may cause monsters to die quicker. I will reserve judgement. Though I can't see New York replacing Tokyo. Especially if your going to play with a younger crowd, wives, or even newer players. It sounds like Tokyo will remain a lighter option.

RATING: 5
Have played this a number of times. It is fun. People will laugh and enjoy it. For the most part. However there are some aspects to it that take away significant points:

It is an elimination game where players can be kicked out of the game fairly early on. No fun. It is a game with victory points, where, well, elimination can work just as well. It is like it was designed to serve two masters and it compromised.

The mechanics are a little too simple to make this game endure for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun little game for 2-6 players. Every turn you throw 6 dice which can result in hitting your opponents, healing yourself, scoring points or gathering energy cubes, which can be used to purchase cards with special powers. As there can only be one monster occupying Tokyo, and the one actually occupying Tokyo cannot heal himself, there's a lot of jumping into and out of the city. When you're the last monster standing or have gained 20 points you win the game.

I've played a couple of 2, 3 and 4-player games so far, these were a lot of fun and so far have only resulted in eliminations. Will certainly play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
King of Tokyo is a light beat-em-up that is fun for a group of friends.  The rules are fast & easy, so it's straight to the fun.  The theme is carried through very well to the cards, which have a lot of unique special players abilities.  Good filler, or party game.

RATING: N/A

- King of Tokyo: Power Up!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent little lightweight dice-rolling game with a healthy dose of push your luck ("if I stay in Tokyo one more round I will win on victory points, but can I survive another round of incoming monster attacks..."). 

The rules are short and easy to learn but the game is a lot of fun and plays very fast. We have yet to get a lot out of the purchasing mechanic but maybe that's because the wrong combination of energy/cards came up for us, it seems like that would be the most difficult path to victory (since you'd still need to then aim for a VP or knockout victory while playing catch-up to the monsters who had been focusing on those tactics already).

All the artwork is fantastic, very cartoony, the components are good quality, the dice are big and chunky (if anything maybe a little too big, which is not a criticism often levelled at dice, but might be a consideration I guess if you're playing with kids etc).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Plays: 5+

RATING: 10
From the brilliant gaming mind of Magic: The Gathering creator Richard Garfield, King of Tokyo is a kaiju free-for-all game to see which kaiju monster will become the games namesake. With combat, strategy, and tons of customization with expansions and add-ons this game has tons of replay value. I unfortunately only have the base game but even then the base game is tons of fun to play. If you love the Magic: The Gathering card game I feel you will love King of Tokyo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
+Power Up expansion,+promo cards,+Brockenbar

Have only played it a few times and I'm already in love: Yahtzee-style dice done right. Even my wife, who hates confrontational games - although she's made great strides in her efforts to play them - likes this one as well. 

Update: With more plays under my belt, I can tell this is the sort of game that will work with just about any crowd. Granted, having some familiarity with the cards will reveal preferable strategies over others, so first-timers/non-gamers might not figure out quickly enough what cards should be acquired unless it's pointed out to them. 

The game is at its best with quick play and lots of banter. This should especially be encouraged when playing with 5 or 6 because the game can start to drag if people become indecisive over what to go for in their rolls or how to allocate their dice. This seems to be less of an issue when playing with three or four. Treat it as a light, fun, fast filler and you'll want to play it several times in a row. Playing it thoughtfully with a Min/Max approach will kill the pace and the mood.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Each player chooses a monster in this "king of the hill" style battle royale. Player with most VP at end of game or last one standing becomes king of Tokyo. Only one person can be in Tokyo at a time and collects VP every round for free, but cannot heal, so don't stay too long! Your actions for a turn are decided by rolling six (6-sided) dice yahtzee style. Choose to go for sets of three (1,2,3) for VP, (4) whack your opponent, (5) collect energy to upgrade your monster, or (6) heal (if not in Tokyo!). Fun simple push your luck player interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Great family and gateway game into modern board games. The components are decent though the dice can be a bit chipped. Hardly an issue since it is a fun big dice chucking game. For me the newness has worn off and the depth isn't there to keep me coming back unless there are new gamers to introduce it to.

Fallen rather far for me due to the lack of interesting decisions in the game. Too light to hold my interest beyond being a gateway game.

RATING: 8.5
Loads of fun in a simple dice rolling game, the amount of strategy is definitely limited by the luck of the dice, but the power up cards available do provide a bit of opportunity to try and form a plan of attack (providing the dice are kind).  Very easy to learn/teach, and with the addition of the Power up expansion, this game has a lot of replay value to offer as well.

Update (6/26/17): I have 3 year old twin girls that always ask to "play" my games (which is usually just me opening the box so they can play with the game pieces).  Well, this game was easy enough to add "house rules" to make a playable version for my kids (we did not use the energy cards, so energy dice rolls were "try again"), and once we got going they loved it!  Definite bonus, and this will probably keep coming to the table due to that fact.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
Fun, widely accessible game for pretty much all ages. Here, you take control of a big monster terrorizing the city of Tokyo, using energy to purchase upgrades & weapons to destroy the other monsters. In the end, there can be only one! Borrows the Yahtzee dice-rolling mechanic to attack the other monsters, heal your damage, use energy cubes, and gain victory points. First to 20 points OR last monster standing is the winner. Good times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the best fillers or wrap-ups of all time.

Second Edition has not as good production values as he first one.

RATING: 8

And the game doesn't play very well with only 2 people, which is unfortunate because due to player-elimination, it's very likely to become a 2-player game at some point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I love dice games but they have to present choices.  In KoT there is typically one obvious thing you need on a turn, either claws, or energy, or healing each with the same 1/6 chance.  You either roll them or you don't, that's it.  For me, too much luck and too few choices.  The other half of the die was some numbers that seemed like red herrings, too hard to get the combo and too pointless if you did.  I'd like to try again, but I suspect the only thing this game has going for it is the theme.  UPGRADE: with more players, rolling numbers seemed more relevant.  Maybe because each player was splashing a little damage on Tokyo rather than having to focus on it.  Monitor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

11/16/17 Update:  I've changed this game from a 6 to an 8.  As my kids have gotten older and able to process the game better, I've had more opportunities to play it with children.  I will say it's quite a hit.  I can see the value with it better than I did before.  I still don't like that it has a lot of downtime between turns as people roll dice, but there are other things much more enjoyable about it.

RATING: 8.9
[February 2015 - 8.9]
Solid. Stays right where it is in the rankings.

[July 2014 - 8.9]
The more I play this game, the more I really enjoy it. It's a great game to teach a new group, then play a few consecutive games. Definitely best with at least 3 players, and preferably 4. Everyone is involved, even when it's not their turn, intensely watching the dice. The best mechanic is how the game rotates you against everyone else,  everyone and you versus another single player. It's leader-bashing, but throughout the game, everyone seems to find themselves in the lead.  Even the weak can be targeted though if you force them into Tokyo.

RATING: 7

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A fun and likeable filler - plays short so the luck aspect of dice is not really an issue and there are some tactical decisions to make. 

It's a little overproduced - the card wheels to record hit points and victory points are a bit unnecessary and actually don't work that well - VP and Health chips would have been better and cheaper. UPDATE: after additional plays I will go further, the card wheel scoring things are completely rubbish. They're easy to turn the wrong way when scoring, the wheels are loose enough that the score can change just by nudging the card, it's difficult to know other people's score and they undoubtedly added to the cost of the game. A separate score track (with plastic or wooden monster meeples) to keep the VP score and health point tokens to record your health, would have been much better.

A deck of cards, some cardboard chips, 7 dice and a largely cosmetic board should have come in under £20. Managed to get the base game and expansion for £30 so that was OK in the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.98
The theme of this game really fits into its game mechanics combining the luck of the dice and the deck of cards. The designer was perfect in every way to bring about the concept of dominating Tokyo by different monsters and the art used can appeal to a kids and adults as well. However, the Kaiju theme does not appeal to some people. If the people you're playing with is into this theme then the experience of playing King of Tokyo will be one that is unique, with excellent replay value that you would enjoy for a very long time.  However my experience playing this game with someone who is not into the Kaiju theme would stop even after just one round. So if you're really into Kaiju or Strange Monsters dominating Tokyo then you're in for a fantastic, out of this world ride playing the King of Tokyo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Great game! Very easy and straightforward rules.
The game relies heavily on luck and very little on strategy, which may not be for everyone.

The game mechanics allow for people being killed and eliminated early in the game, this might lead to some frustration. Suggested remedy: There is at least one card that allows to reenter the game; players may chose to treat this card as always active.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For some reason, this game is a lot of fun.  It's basically a big "king of the mountain" game.  But it has some cool things going for it.  First, it's not a pure "take that" game.  Who you attack is constrained by who if you are in Tokyo or not.  Second, you can take the target off you back whenever you want by leaving Tokyo.  Somehow, these simple implementations really work well.  Throw in some cards for theme and special abilities...and you have a fun dicefest that can be qualified as filler.  Will probably buy.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players are monsters, fighting it out for victory points and damage in and around Tokyo.  Incredibly fun die roller where players take turns to roll 6 dice, and are granted two re-rolls before applying results.  Sets of 1, 2 or 3's will awards victory points, hearts heal your monster, while energy allows you to buy power cards.  The fun result is damage... if you are the King in Toyko, then you damage every other player, but if you are one of the other players you damage the King. Cute, fast and a lot of fun.  Presentation is great, cards are funny, loved it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.75

If I had to find a fault for it, it would be that in a two player game, it is far too common to win by eliminating the other person and the game is short because of it.

RATING: 8
Quick and fun dice chucking party game. Revitalizes the Yahtzee mechanism and makes it not-solitaire. Varying upgrade cards keep it fresh and bring some variation. Plus, they are really thematic, nicely drawn and often quite funny. I love how you can look at your monster at the end of the game and laugh at your winged cthullu-esque Kraken monster with its giant brain and parasitic tentacles. A minor flaw is the possible player elimination, which can be mitigated when playing with the right (that means aggressive) group of people, because the games won't last that long.

RATING: 10
A maga nemében egy tökéletes kockás, parti játék. Hárman próbáltuk ki, de így is működött és hozta az egymást gyepálós "feeling"-et. Az egyetlen hibájának egyenlőre a nagydarab kockákat tartom. Néha kiejtettünk egyet-egyet a kezünkből, mert nem fért el benne rendesen az összes. Gyermekek még jobban megküzdhetnek ezzel, habár erről nincs tapasztalat. Egyszerű szabályok és játékmenet, kellően gyors, így ha valaki kiesik, nem kell sokat várnia, hogy újra játékba kerüljön. Kétféle módon lehet nyerni, vagy valaki elér 20 győzelmi pontot, vagy egyedül marad állva. Hát nálunk még senki nem ért el 20 győzelmi pontot :). Aki kedveli ezt a témát, óriás szörnyek püfölik egymást (csak jó lehet :)), annak egy kötelező darab. Persze a játék nem csak abból áll, hogy ki tud többet sebezni a másikon. Különböző kártyák segítségével különböző előnyökhöz lehet jutni, ezt kihasználva és ügyesen taktikázva könnyedén lehet nyerni. Nem szabad elfelejteni, hogy két energia kockáért el lehet dobatni a 3 felcsapott lapot... (Én még persze nem nyertem benne, de a feleségem kétszer is :), így ő nagyon kedveli ezt a játékot :)). Csak ajánlani tudom, örülök, hogy magyar nyelven is elérhető már. (2014.12.24.)
Azt nagyon szeretem ebben a játékban, hogy kevés, könnyen megjegyezhető szabályai vannak, így bármikor elővehető és 5 perc alatt kialakulhat egy jó kis ütésváltás :). (2016.12.25.)

RATING: 8
I might actually rate this a 9 or 10 except I don't get to play it nearly as much as I'd like, so I'm hesitant to raise it up to those lofty heights.

The game is pure monster fighting fun.   You're smacking each other back and forth, in and out of Tokyo, knocking players out of the game, and the brilliant thing is it never feels personal.  There is a lot of enjoyment to be had in pushing your luck with the dice rolls, or seeing how long you can last in Tokyo.  If you make some foolhardy decision and get beaten out of the game, it's still fun to watch.

The theme and mechanics come together so well, even though on paper the combination of yahtzee and kaiju battles seems kind of odd.  King of Tokyo is a work of genius.  It's one of my favorites and I wish I could play it more.

RATING: N/A
東京之王
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
This light weight push-your-luck game is full of Yahtzee style dice rolling fun!  Players roll 6 over-sized die with up to 2 re-rolls and use the faces of the dice to determine their actions.  The goal of the game is to be the first monster to score 20 points (either by occupying Tokyo or scoring points for die rolls) or be the last monster standing by destroying everyone else.  

There are tons of special power cards in the game that provide all sorts of benefits.  The cards are very thematic and include things such as extra head, poison spit, wings, fire breath, etc.

So far, everyone I've introduced this game to has enjoyed it immensely and have immediately requested another game.  The game does play 2 players but in my opinion you need at least 3, and the more the merrier!  

I originally brought this game as a filler game for my group, but we had so much fun we played it 4 times in a row!!!  This is a great family/light weight game simple enough for kids and fun for adults!  Also works well as a gateway game to introduce newcomers to the wonderful world of hobby gaming. Definitely recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Overrated in my opinion. It's fun, but often clunky and the luck of the dice can ruin it.

RATING: 8
A fun monster themed dice rolling game with great artwork. Player interaction is high and the deck of cards keeps things interesting. While players can be eliminated, the game plays quickly enough for this to not be an issue. Big dice, big monsters, big fun. I've settled on a houserule for the power cards as the game is simply more fun when players receive more of them. King of New York introduces extra monsters, but the gameplay slows down as the board events clutter such a streamlined game.

30-45m, best with 3-5 players. 15+ plays.
