RATING: 7
A pretty fun dice game and one of the few "take that" games I don't mind because of the great theme. It's really fun to throw handfuls of those big, chunky dice and fight giant monsters in control of Tokyo. The power cards are really random and swingy but with a game that's relatively short it's not really that big a deal.

It's one of those games that is best played quickly though, so if your group is prone to AP or are very timid at games of a "take that" nature, I'd stay away. Good for thirty minutes, painful for an hour.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2016 edition with Space Penguin and Cyberkitty
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
King of Tokyo combines King of the Hill with Yahtzee.  Theme is giant monsters (like King Kong, Godzilla, etc.) attacking Tokyo.  On your turn you roll 6 dice and have 2 re-rolls.  The results are as follows: Attacking, Healing, Energy and VP (1, 2 or 3).  When attacking, you'll either attack the creature on Tokyo or if you're on Tokyo, all other monsters.  If attacked in Tokyo you can give Tokyo up and force the attacking player on.  This can be necessary as you can't heal on Tokyo.  Though, Tokyo provides VP when entering and when you can remain there until the beginning of your turn.  Healing is what it says.  VP requires a set of 3 of the same number to score that many VP.  Each extra result of that type will give a bonus VP.  Finally we have energy.  Energy is used to buy special ability cards which really changes the game.  I think it's the cards that really make this more interesting than other Yahtzee variants.  That and being able to kill the other players.  The winner is the last Monster standing or the first to 20 VP.  

I've recently had some games of this that have dragged and no longer like playing games with player elimination, so it's no longer a good fit for me.

RATING: 8
King of the Hill, err... I mean King of Tokyo is a fun game for a group of 4-6 players. Not much fun with only 2-3 players. We typically use house rules where everyone starts with a good amount of energy. That way,folks can buy cards earlier in the game. Way more fun that way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
King of Tokyo is a yahtzee-esq slugfest, reminicient of the classic Rampage arcade game. The king-of-the-hill attack mechanisms give the game a good feel, and the ability cards help solidify the clashing-monsters theme. The game overly encourages damage dealing, making the victory point condition mostly irrelevant which is a shame as in narrows the game to a singular strategy. But, considering its simplicity and accessible theme, it is one of the better kid-focused games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

In addition, many of the cards (and there are many) have powers that just aren't that appealing for the cost.  Sometimes less is more.

3/23/15: Played again with a different group. Maybe it's just my core group doesn't like it much? Was a hit with the new group, a more family style group with several younger kids.

RATING: 8.5
One of the games that always end up with "just one more round!". I have converted many non-gamers to the hobby through this game, and expect to continue doing so for many years to come.

Even among experienced gamers, very rarely have I seen people turn down a request to play King of Tokyo. Always a good time.

My only thing complain is that the "exit Tokyo without taking damages" card is very over-powered in a 2 player game, so we usually take it out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[2 plays] This seemed like an OK game at first, but it also seemed like a short, snappy game. Now I think it's just longer than the degree of my interest in it.  I also thought at first it would be a game where player elimination wouldn't be a big deal because the game was so short, but it's really not.  In a con setting or something where you can be eliminated, wander off, and find something else to do, it's OK, but if what you're going to do when eliminated is wait for these people to finish the game so you can do something else with them, it can really drag. This might be better with fewer players for these reasons, and because you have a bit more control over your fate; with lots of players, if you go around the table and everyone bashes you, it's easy not to survive till your next turn.

RATING: 8.25
I'm usually wary of any game with a heavy amount of dice rolling but this game was a nice change.  Has several unique elements and ways to win.  Theres actually a lot less luck to this than you would think too.  its more about changing your strategy based on what you roll and what others do.  The interaction level is solid, its a good party game with a small learning curve.  works really well with any number of players.  the quality of the game and the art is good too. Only issue is eliminated players are completely eliminated and have to wait around for the game to finish.  Overall I recommend.

RATING: 7
Yahtzee a little bit beefed up with monsters puts this game pretty solidly at filler level.  I enjoy the references to monster movie tropes on the cards and like playing.  Not sure how I feel about the moving into Tokyo mechanism as our games often devolve into people being forced into Tokyo, not willingly going.  Definitely need to pick up the expansion, though.  Worth mentioning that this game is SUPER accessible, even for people that might think that they dislike board games other than the "classics."  Pretty much everybody can get behind 'Yahtzee with monsters.'  While the expansions can add some extra length to the game not as readily present in just base, I really enjoy that they provide more options for rolls.  Rating is 1 number lower without expansions.

RATING: 8
I enjoy this game, just the right amount of random, just the right amount of choice. The dice rolls make you choose your strategy carefully - building power to get abilities, taking the city and holding it by force, or pressing your luck to farm VP from dice alone. The heal mechanic feels good as well. My one complaint is the "when you die, you're out" issue - it alienates players who die because they are no longer participating and invested in the game.

RATING: 7.5
I need to concoct the ideal two-player variant for this, because it usually gets to the table with my eldest only.
I've had surprisingly little success with this when other kids were around. The cards can confuse non-gamers, and they either ignore them or get bogged down in them. In my own experience, younger children just can't manage to keep things moving along and light-hearted. I've never played with the expansions, but if they start you out with different abilities, that might go a long way to solving some of those issues.
Update: I do have to say, though, that its simplicity and thematic fun just carry it through. It doesn't come out super-often, but it's an evergreen.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is a good little game despite the fact this is a dice game involving a lot of luck.  It is short, light, and simple.  It is a "King of the Mountain" type game and when played with the right crowd can generate a lot of surprises and laughs. 

The cards are well done. I often object to this type of card play when added to a game--but I enjoyed these cards. They are different and refreshing. 

The characters are large & sturdy cardboard in broad-based holders. The rest of the components are nice, but few and simple and therefore I have a lot of trouble seeing $44 worth of value.  Seems a little over priced for what it is.  The game sells out quickly so that obviously doesn't deter many.  

I shock myself by thinking I might get this game when it becomes available again.

RATING: 7.6
Expansions: Power Up!, Halloween

The more (players) the merrier.

My Halloween variant: after choosing monsters, each player draws 2 costume cards, selects 1, and gains 5-X energy, where X= the cost of the costume.

This allows you to actually use the expansion's content and gives you a bit of choice for something you choose (a costume) as opposed to something you don't choose (who you are).

RATING: 9
This game has to make my list of top 5 good game purchases ever - I bought it as a Christmas gift (among other things) for my 12-year-old son who doesn't usually enjoy most of the games I play with my other older children.  This one was an immediate hit - the perfect blend of exciting art, quick gameplay, the right dose of luck with all the fun of dice-rolling, player interaction and confrontation, and interesting decisions to be made.  He has thoroughly enjoyed it, along with the rest of our children, and it makes a great filler with adults as well.  The card deck allows for each game to play out differently.  This would be my top recommendation for a great family game right now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Really wanted to like this game - it's a fan favorite, beautiful production value and colors, the game is easy to teach and light for beginners.  

Gave it a couple chances, but it was just not a good game in my opinion.  Way too easy to die.  The only strategy for each player was to roll for hearts/hits, which made it difficult to roll victory points, and also made it hard to gain and save up energy (lighting bolts). When you finally did have enough energy, the upgrade cards were inconsistently priced - some are cheap and very powerful and change the course of the game, and others are really expensive and do not help much. Most are just pointless and seem to be added as a meek effort for variety.  There was also a lot of downtime for somebody if they got knocked out early.  

We even played with variants (double energy per lightning bolt, two piles for 'keep' and 'discard' cards, two card draft at the beginning of the game, etc.) and the game was still not fun for me or the group. 

Fortunately, was able to return to Amazon for a full refund (thank you Amazon!).  Maybe I will give King of New York a try to compare the differences

RATING: 7.5
Player elimination and lots of luck, but still the most consistently enjoyable light game. Everyone likes it. And it's always exciting. I rarely bother with the Power Up expansion, simply because there's almost always a newbie at the table. Either way, it plays great. If I'm with hardcore gamers, this sort of game isn't my first choice (which explains why my rating doesn't seem to match the praise I'm giving the game now), but if I'm not in the right crowd for breaking out Great Western Trail or whatever, this is perfect.

RATING: N/A
Noam's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Combine Yahtzee-style dice rolling with Japanese B-movies of dubious entertainment value, and the result might look somewhat like King of Tokyo.

I suppose it does what it set out to do: provide some mindless fun and offer lots of opportunity to lunge out and bash everyone else. Heightened emotional reactions through monster embodiment. Or something.

All of that lasts about as long as you need to realise that the influence any single player has on the mayhem going on in Tokyo is practically zero. The dice actions are most uninteresting and you have to look for decision points with a magnifying lense. Even so, it does have a certain entertainment value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Drôle de parcours face à cet objet ludique. Avec un camarade joueur, on en lisait et on en entendait beaucoup de bien. Mais voilà, le graphisme de la boîte, avec les petites figurines cartonnées et son look aguicheur pour ne pas dire putassier nous laissait de marbre et nous rebutait. Et pourtant, nous étions tous les deux passés pas la case "Magic". Mais on se doutait bien que, malgré un auteur commun, les deux choses n'avaient pas grand chose en commun. Si, le succès.

Mais voilà, un jour de janvier 2013, on se rend pour la première fois à une soirée jeux organisée dans un bar par la boutique au meeple orange qui fait la fierté de notre ville (avec le jeu créé par Stefan Feld). Mais on arrive en retard, du coup toutes les tables sont prises, on boit un coup, je renverse un Irish Coffee sur mon ami, et finalement on apprend que des tables se libèrent dans la salle du bas. On avait le choix entre "Takenoko", que l'ami en question possède déjà et... "King of Tokyo". Du coup, on se dit que c'est l'occasion de l'essayer et on s'assoit à trois autour de cette table.

Un animateur vient rapidement nous expliquer les règles (merci à lui, très dynamique et qui communique sa bonne humeur), simplissimes. On fait une partie, on trouve le tout très fun, on enchaîne sur une deuxième, qu'on apprécie aussi beaucoup. Depuis, on ne l'a pas acheté mais on a eu l'occasion d'en refaire quelques parties et de faire découvrir le jeu à d'autres camarades ludiques, qui eux aussi ont accroché rapidement.

Car ce jeu est ce qui se fait de mieux dans sa catégorie. On s'y amuse, on met des baffes, on se charrie, on pousse des cris un peu étranges, on rigole, on crie après un mauvais jet de dés, on voit des retournements de situation... le tout en trente minutes maximum, dans une très bonne ambiance et avec des mécanismes très bien huilés.

Tout n'est certes pas parfait et le graphisme qui me rebutait au début demeure, mais il colle bien au thème finalement. Le truc, c'est qu'on voit vite arriver les limites de ce genre de jeu, qui est très fun à sortir de temps en temps et assez addictif, mais dont on n'enchaîne pas trente parties non plus. On s'amuse énormément aux premières, un peu moins aux suivantes. Le mécanisme de stop ou encore est tout simple mais demeure efficace et permet d'élaborer différentes "stratégies", même si le résultat de celles-ci reposent beaucoup sur celui des dés qui peuvent la ruiner. Mais au fond, dans un jeu de ce format, ce n'est pas si grave, et l'élimination progressive des joueurs n'intervient pas dès le début de la partie. De plus, comme la partie est courte, ils ne sont pas éliminés trop longtemps.

Différencier les espaces et les coups portés par la présence ou non sur Tokyo est également très astucieux et permet un minimum de gestion de sa partie. Ajoutez à cela le mécanisme de collecte d'énergie pour prendre des cartes qui changent un peu la donne sans trop déséquilibrer le jeu (enfin, ça dépend, mais sur plusieurs parties, ça se lisse) et la capacité d'enquiquiner les adversaires en les défaussant toutes ajoute encore une petite subtilité à un jeu qui ne l'est pas vraiment.

En bref, et malgré un parti pris graphique qui ne me conquiert pas totalement (mais qui, encore une fois, colle assez au thème) et quelques limites (rien de vraiment novateur, un nombre de joueurs qui est là plus pour attirer l'acheteur car à deux c'est nettement moins intéressant et à six c'est un peu trop le bordel) , je suis très satisfait d'avoir découvert ce jeu qui, je pense, devrait un jour ou l'autre rejoindre ma ludothèque. Car malgré toutes les faiblesses qu'on peut lui trouver, on s'amuse en général beaucoup en y jouant, et c'est peut-être le principal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the fact that this game is fun, easy to teach, great for family and fast to play. The components are colourful and the dice feel great in your hand. I enjoy any kind of push-your-luck based game and I think this game masters it. It has multiple levels of depth, whether you invest in cards or not, which makes it great for both adults looking for a bit more strategy and replayability and kids who have fun rolling the dice and hitting the other monsters.
I don't like the player elimination side - but it is not a showstopper because games are quite short anyway.
I am not a fan of the triple 1, 2 or 3 to give you victory points as it gives an alternative to getting to move in Tokyo, which is not thematic and not as fun. Also, being in Tokyo does not reward much (2 points a full turn) for the risk you are taking, which leads many players just hoping not to get invited to move in Tokyo - which once again is not thematic.
Finally, the set of actions and decisions is quite limited which somewhat hinders replayability for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a bad game by any stretch, but highly luck-based due to the nature of the dice. The push-your-luck aspect combined with hit points and damage tends to make me want to play safe rather than push things too far, but that doesn't make the game any less enjoyable, rather makes me feel like I'm not playing the game as optimally as I could. Good game to play with my kids, as it plays fast and it's easy for me to throw and let them win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Not horrible, but really nothing extraordinary either.  I don't mind playing a game or two once in a while with my daughter, but when playing larger games I can't shake the feeling that the game is missing-lacking something.  It seems like it wants to be more than a random dice battler, which it isn't.  I expected much more from the cards, and was somewhat let down by my expectations there.  The game can be decent quick fun, however. 

NOTE: Components are also cheap, in the first edition.  I had to request replacement character sheets, standies, and dice.  There was already damage before the box was even opened.  This seems to be a common complaint.  If you have kids, these things will NOT hold up.  If you travel with the games, be sure to use plastic baggies or something to help protect the cards (sleeved won't fit in the insert without cutting the insert or removing it altogether).  Every time I've traveled with this game, cards have been set loose through the box and damaged.  They have to be rubber-banded or paper band at the least.  I ditched the crap insert and put everything into ziplock baggies.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 8
One of the best games to play with younger players and still feel competitive as an adult.  It's all about the luck of the dice, and it's surprising how quickly young players develop a strategy for gameplay.  The power up cards make each game a little different so after countless plays it's still yet to get stale.  This one's probably been played more than any other game in the house.

The expansions, so far, haven't really been fully utilized.  It's nice to have more characters to play but, overall, the expansions are not all that necessary.

RATING: 7
King of Tokyo is a lightweight game that is really fun for my lucky husband (who just loves dice, and whom dice love in return) and has enough strategy to hold my attention. While this game might be a lot better with more players, it is fine for two. The rules were fairly easy for us to grasp after a single read-through. The components are nicely designed and produced, but the dice symbols are not etched into the faces in the version I have. They are already showing some wear after only one game. Edit: I purchased replacement dice with etched faces. Problem fixed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My son wanted this because of the art, and the Kaiju theme.

I found this to be less than 'OK.'
Again, yet another game that I just don't get the hype around. It's really bland and boring, and the only thing cool or fun about it was the art. The standees and board seem pointless, but not quite as pointless as all the cards. I'm not sure there's a real game here - it looks like a box full of bling and very little substance, and when you play it, you realize that it is.

This is OK for kids and barely passable at that. Everything about it just felt to me to be lacking.

My kids found it weird you do nothing with the standees, which look really cool, and give the game a really cool theme and feel....but then they don't really have anything to do with the actual game.

This is an over-produced dice filler that should cost less than half of what it does.

It's really weird too, because I love dice-chuckers. But this one was just plain bad, and boring.

Some further comments since the kids wanted to try it out again:

What's the point of the cards? - while they add some interesting and unique stuff to the game, I never found the need to waste dice saving up energy to buy abilities when it's much more prudent to kick the stuffing out of your opponents.

It's over too fast to even get into the depth of what the cards are supposed to provide. And 20 VP to win? It would take forever, and not in a single game we've played has anyone gone above 10 VP before everyone else is killed.

So much of this game seems really pointless. Outside of the dice and life/points counter, everything else feels tacked on and superfluous.

Also, player elimination has to be THE WORST rule to incorporate into a family game - yeah.....it's real fun for one kid to get knocked out first, and sit there and watch the rest of the game unfold. They usually just go and play on their own or watch TV. 

So, as far as bringing the family together over a game? This is one stinking pile of crap.

As you can probably tell, I hate this piece of shit and have zero desire to play this ever again.

BUT! My kid loves this damn thing to death. So, I`m forced to play, just so I can get him into other stuff as his tastes mature. And let me say there needs to be more Kaiju themed games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
This is a fun game which often frustrates me. Ultimately, a lot of it comes down to luck. I find it plays totally differently 2-player compared to more players. Much quicker and more brutal with 2 players. With 4 or more people, I find you have more freedom to embrace different styles of play (some people might build cards, some may aim to deal more damage) and players may have different agendas depending on which cards they hold. 

I have played the Power Up! expansion with the lunchtime game group and think it really adds to the game. I would purchase it if I played KoT more outside of work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent game, Richard Garfield's best since the days of Magic, RoboRally, and Netrunner. There is real beauty in the way that the simple rules allow multiple approaches and generate interesting patterns of play. Players can win either by earning 20,000 Twitter followers, or by knocking out all of the other monsters. The balance between these goals is perfect. King of Tokyo almost always ends in a photo finish. Upon seeing the mathematical elegance of this game, it is rumored that Reiner Knizia has abandoned his similar prototype about ancient Mesopotamian flower gardens.

If you're going for the win via Twitter followers, it is highly recommended that you announce your Tweets and/or Facebook updates. Also, when choosing monsters you will definitely want to get your hands on "The King," since he has already named himself King of Tokyo and your victory is assured. The only other viable possibility is to make a Chuck Norris standup, and smuggle him into game night.

I plan to make cutouts of my nephews to use as additional rampagers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
King of Tokyo is significantly more popular that King of New York, but I prefer the latter. By comparison, Tokyo is very simple and your strategy is more limited.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Good monster fighting game.  The goal of the game is to be the first player to reach 20 victory point or to be the only one alive.

On your turn, you have to roll the 6 dice up to 3 times (you can keep dice between roll).  The dice have the following faces :
1 : gives you 1 victory point if you have 3 (+1 VP for each other 1).
2 : gives you 2 VP if you have 3 (+1 VP for each other 2).
3 : gives you 3 VP if you have 3 (+1 VP for each other 3).
Energy : each of those gives you 1 energy cube (can be use to purchase card that gives you special power).
Heart symbol : each of those gives you 1 health point back.
Monster hand : each of those cause 1 point of damage to the monster(s) you're attacking.

Your monster can be in Tokyo or outside Tokyo.  When in Tokyo, the monster can't use heart symbol to heal.  There's only place for one monster in Tokyo (except for 5-6 player game).  Attack are made to the monster(s) that are not at the same place as you are (if you're in Tokyo, you attack all the monster that aren't in Tokyo and vice versa).
Each time the monster in Tokyo is attacked, he chooses to stay or leave.  If he leaves, the monster that attack him goes in Tokyo.
Each time a monster enters Tokyo he gain 1 VP.
Each time a monster is in Tokyo when his turn begin, he gain 2 VP.

The game end when a player reach 20 VP or when there's only one monster alive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun, fun, fun!  Also this is the game where friends fight!  :D  Awesome dice chugger which plays fast.
One caveat is if you loose early - you'll have to wait for others to finish - which could take some time.

RATING: 7.8

RATING: 7
Somehow, this game found itself heavily recommended in the Board Games Google+ community. I was happy to eventually come across an opportunity to play the game at open gaming one night. I get what people see in the game. Brightly colored components, large dice and simple gameplay. I normally don't care too much for dice rolling mechanics because I feel like choices are being taken away from me, but in this game the decisions are based around your keeping or re-rolling dice. The tension in the game is somewhat based around your choices to NOT keep what might be good for you.

At the same time, though, sometimes it just comes down to the dice being stupid and ruining your game. Either way it makes for a fun, light game.

RATING: 8
Very fun little dice game filler.  Especially if you are a monster movie fan.  Random and light.  I can see this working well with kids.  The game is usually over quick enough before you get frustrated for not rolling what you want on the dice.  Scratches the same itch as Quarriors for me and is more fun.  Highly recommend for fans of monster movies.  Recommend for light game fans and those with boy children.  Don't recommend for grognards and people who hate random games that can sometimes feel like they are playing themselves.

RATING: 7

We have started removing certain cards from the deck to offer a higher reward for focusing on "bolts".

RATING: 7

Tokyo is clearly one of the most popular games out there, acessible and fun for the whole family. It may not hold more experienced gamers for long, as is too much like Yahtzee, but it is good enough.
Sometimes can overstay it welcome a little and has a problem of player elimination, but it is a good game to introduce people to the hobby. Probably best at 4-5.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
I know I'm not in its target audience, but I don't understand why this game is so popular. Maybe it's a combination of fanboyism for the designer, the kaiju theme and mob mentality.

Rolling dice tends to be at least a bit fun in other games, but here it is completely unexciting. In your turn, you just roll the dice three times, keeping whichever dice you want between rolls. Oh!, you may also spend energy to buy special cards that range from useless to ridiculously powerful. To add insult to injury, this boring luck fest also includes player elimination.

It may be fine to play once in a blue moon as a group activity, but it is barely a game. I concede that at least it is relatively harmless and not annoying like "Sentinels of the Multiverse" - just to mention another absurdly overrated piece of trash that I've played recently.

It's actually perfect for what it is... King of Tokyo has a place in my collection for a while.

RATING: 7
This is a pretty fun light game with a little bit of strategy, not a whole lot, but some.  The game goes fast which is nice, but I do not care for having multiple routes to victory.  I understand why there are two, but winning by points seems like the game was a waste and always leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

As you go up in players up to 4, it makes it easier to win by points, since the guys in the middle rarely make it around a whole turn to attack out, which I don't like.  The rest is fun though and fairly fast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is simple, quick and pretty fun.  I play with kids, and I imagine that if you play with a lively group of adults it could be over-the-top fun.  As it is, we're enjoying it more and more as we get more familiar with the different power-up cards and the best way to exploit them.  It's also very nice to look at in a playful way.  One knock against it is that all the monsters are the same -- it seems like the monsters could have balanced, special powers that make choosing your avatar more meaningful than just prefering the look of your cardboard counter.  But as it is, the game mechanic is still unique and a lot of fun and involves some risk management and meaningful decision making, and KOT is one of those games where you really never know who is going to win or be eliminated until it actually happens.  You can have a guy about to win on VP get suddenly eliminated from the game by a hot attack role from an opponent.  That always keeps a game interesting to the end.  I don't like games (Monopoly, Conquest of Nerath, etc) where you can get into a hole and know you are never climbing out, but you have to keep slogging on waiting to lose.  One drawback, however, is that a player (or more) can get eliminated early and have nothing to do while the game goes on.

Also, setup is very fast and the games are short, and it's important to have a few games like that in the house for the days when you don't have hours to spend.

RATING: 4
Counter-productive. Encourages turtling and laborious building up. Aggressive players seem to die early. More points are gained by rolling 1s, 2s and 3s than by actually battling for Tokyo. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
King of Tokyo is a Yahtzee-style dice game that is very simple to teach to new players within the span of a few minutes. It's great as both a short filler and a gateway boardgame for new players.

The artwork is imaginative and playful. Moreover, the gameplay mechanics are immediately intuitive and seem to lend to the monster theme of the game. While not the most strategic game, I enjoy it for what it is: an immersive and light game.

There are other games out there with better strategy in the same time frame.  The big choice is when to go to Tokyo and when to leave Tokyo.  

Best thing about the game is I think it is simple enough to play with family members or non-gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
King of Tokyo is a light, beer-and-pretzels style game with a quick playing time and a healthy dose of luck. It also scales wonderfully from 2-6 players, though I think it's just plain more fun with more monsters - ah, I mean, players.

The premise of the game is basically the same as [thing=17835][/thing]. That is to say, it's not JUST Godzilla or King Kong, it's ALL THE MONSTERS and they are going to kill each other, not just the planet. The cardboard stand-ups of the monsters are high-quality and have great cartoony illustrations. It has a bunch of custom dice and some special power cards which are really what make the game shine.

Just as in Yahtzee or [thing=37380]Roll Through the Ages[/thing], you take a fistful of dice and get three rolls, keeping whatever you want from the previous roll and re-rolling the rest. The goal is to either kill all the other monsters or get 20 points. The dice have various combinations that get you points, healing, attacks on other monsters or energy. Energy is the currency of the game and is used to buy special cards.

As you would expect from Richard Garfield, these cards all break the game in various ways, changing the rules just for your monster so he has a leg up on the other critters. There are tons of these cards; it will probably take 4-5 games (depending on the number of players) to see them all, even if you set aside the ones you already used. 

If I had to describe this game in one word it would be "addicting". I can't think of another game that creates more of a feeling of "just one more game" than this one. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We love playing King of Tokyo with our son (8 years old as of this review).  The game plays quickly and is simple to understand.

The game can swing a bit based on dice roles (for example; my son's first game he rolled 3+ 3s every turn and won outright with little challenge).

There are a lot of great special power cards, but without some house rules to get players more energy early the cards don't come into play until it is too late for them to be of much use.  We start games with 4 to 6 energy (instead of 2) and reduce the energy cost to wipe the face up cards down to 1 (from 2).

If a group has never played either this or King of New York (KoNY), I would choose this to play first since it is a little more straight forward, and then might pull out KoNY if everyone enjoyed it.  Has a good middle ground between the light party gamers and the more serious board gamers that most everyone seems to enjoy.

RATING: 8
[Initial Impression: 8]
Who doesn't like a good monster smash-up?
This is totally not my style of game, but I found it to be fun, thematic, and short enough to be interesting to kepp watching even after you've been KO'd. The cards should add enough powers and interest that you won't feel like you're playing the same battle over and over. Very much a dice-rolling slugfest. For some reason reminds me just a bit of Nexus Ops, but with simpler rules, and a more fun theme.

It is well worth every penny.

RATING: 7
6-22-15
I want to like this game.  However, the 2-player version sucks with just a complete deathmatch, and the 4-player version feels like you don't get to accumulate cards and make much use of them.  

We tried a modification to play to 30 and not be kicked out after death, however, the game dragged way too long for the luck involved.  After a standard 4-player game, I guess the base rules are the way to go, but it feels a bit underwhelming.  By all means, I should like this more than Risk & Roll, but I'm not sure that I do.  Time will tell.

PL: Ten tytuł jest tak popularny i tak często przewija się na forum.gryplanszowe.pl, że naprawdę liczyłem na coś mega. I mega się zawiodłem. Gra ma naprawdę niezłe opracowanie graficzne. Te wszystkie kolory i rysunki robią naprawdę niezłą robotę. Niestety plansza jest wielkosci pocztówki i ma tylko dwa pola (z czego przy grze na 2-3 osoby tylko jedno jest aktywne), dodatkowo "urządzenia" do liczenia punktów życia i zwycięstwa i kilka figurek. Aaaa i kostki. Kostki są potrójne mega: mega wielkie, mega jaskrawe i mega fajne. Sama rozgrywka polega na wejściu na jedyne dostępne pole na planszy o wielkości chusteczki chigienicznej. Jedni kulają kostkami żeby zrobić kuku temu na środku, a on się odwdzięcza. Tyle. Naprawdę liczyłem na coś więcej.

RATING: 8
This is a good beer and pretzels game. Easy to learn, easy to teach, and you can have fun beating up on other people (in the game).

Some people have commented that winning by victory points defeats the purpose of the game, to them I point out:

triple 1s indicates you've eaten pedestrians.
triple 2s indicates you've smashed vehicles.
triple 3s indicates you've destroyed buildings.

This seems to make them enjoy gathering points more.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
““Nuclear waste turned him from a harmless grub into a 350 foot tall monster that attacked Tokyo.” - President Hathaway

GAMEPLAY
Players take on the role of giant monsters set on rampaging through Tokyo and bashing each other. Each turn the players roll 6 dice Yahtzee style with 2 re-rolls to build energy, attack other players, score victory points, and heal. The objective of the games is to build up 20 victory points or destroy all of the other monsters. Buying power cards with stored energy brings in victory points, augments your dice rolls, or interferes with other players. Stomping into Tokyo builds your victory points but it makes you the center of attention. The game board consists of only the single space (two for 5 to 6 player games) which creates the dramatic tension of the game mechanic. One of the great decisions mid-game after there are fewer players is whether to hold the middle. Games move quickly form turn to turn and none of my games has taken longer than 30 minutes to finish making it possible to play several times or as a filler while waiting for other people to show.

COMPONENTS
The art style is fun and evocative. Monster stands are of thick card and all the images have strong colors. I would have like to see miniatures for the monsters but that isn’t really the point of the game. The box insert is just right for the existing components in the box but there is already one expansion so I don’t think it will fit.

THEME
Giant monsters attack Tokyo. Simple, easy to understand and fun. Monsters are easy to recognize and mimic many trademarked monsters from movies through the decades. The power cards are all over the map from destroying building for victory points to getting an extra head for more dice rolling.

WHO IS IT FOR?
KoT is easy to bring out with a broad range of players. Young kids can enjoy this game. There is some reading involved but if the adults are keeping the game moving kids as young as 6 should have fun. The game is for 2 to 6 players and can get pretty wild with a full group. Because the game is short (20 to 30 minutes) and the rules are basic, it can be played with anyone passingly interested in sitting down. Monster noises encouraged.

RATING: 8
Okay, it's just Kaiju [i]Yahtzee[/i] with some game-nudging cards—but I'm a sucker for a glossy theme and this one is well-lacquered.  If you have trouble managing probability, hate player elimination or can't make serviceable giant monster battle sounds then stay away; otherwise know that it plays quickly and is a real hoot if everyone can get into the theme:

[microbadge=22861]  Full-throttle haymaker

[microbadge=22861][microbadge=22861]  Spartan-kicked through a city block

[microbadge=22861][microbadge=22861][microbadge=22861]  Clubbed with an aircraft carrier and raked with scintillating eye-beams

Note:  Somehow there are actually people alive who have never seen a Kaiju movie—not even [i]King Kong[/i].  When you say, "You know, like Godzilla," they stare blankly and say, "God-what?"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An entertaining player-versus-player Yahtzee-like game.

If played with 2-3 people, the game is ridiculously short--no one is going to get to 20 VP; everyone except the King (whoever that is) is going to die. Game is over in 15 minutes.

I think I prefer it with more people if I actually want to play this--game lasts longer, gives you an actual choice on if you want to pursue collecting VP or try to wipe everyone else out. That being said, dice rolling isn't my general cup of tea so the idea of the game lasting longer does give me mixed feelings.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As a fan of giant monster themed items and someone that likes Yahtzee, this was a logical choice to add to my collection. It contains a lot of flavor in the visual design and card effects, leading to a goofy fun time. Also has well-made game mechanics, making for a bit of strategy to the overall randomness of the dice rolls. It does have its issues, but their tends to be a counterargument for most. For example, being knocked out early in the game to watch everyone else play for a half an hour isn't much fun, but it also makes every action a tense and dramatic situation when every dice roll could be your last. In the end, though, its a game where you move around cardboard figures pretending to fight each other while destroying a major city, and that's fine by me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my favorite dice games. Easy and light, almost anyone can play!

RATING: N/A
By Richard Garfield. 3p, 4p, 5p or 6p. A dice game with fighting and player elimination. Similar to BANG! The Dice Game, but much worse. Gaining victory points is unexciting. Winning via victory points is unexciting. Too much in-game text. Minimize in-game reading by removing KEEP cards from the game and buying cards face down? RATING: 8
If you love monsters/kaiju, then King of Tokyo is a must have! Fun with just two players or with a group, you can't go wrong here. King of Tokyo is a modern gaming staple, a status that's well-deserved.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played on 1/3/2015. I thought I played it before, so this could be wrong? Good shorter game light enough to play at leisure. Different elements with battle monsters.

Pick a monster, start with 10 health and get 20 points to win. On your turn roll 6 dice (1,2,3,health,$,attack). You get 3 chances to lock in the dice. 3 of any one number gets you that many skill points, each additional gets you one more skill point. (5 3's get you 5 points). Health heals you only outside of Tokoko. Attack attacks monsters opposite where your monster is (in or out of Tokoyo). Health drops below 0 and you're out. You get 1 point for attacking into Tokoyo and 2 pts making it a round in Tokoyo without coming out. The $ get let you buy cards with special ability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A perfect game. Can be taught to anyone, but can still be enjoyed by heavy gamers. It has conflict, pushing your luck in Tokyo, great cards, and dice with decisions! You can aim for points, for attacking, for energy (aka money for cards), or healing! Fantastic game. Doesn't quite work with 2 players, and the only criticism I have is that it doesn't matter what monster you pick, they are all the same (except the expansion fixed this!)

My wife didn't like the idea of rampaging and smashing other monsters at first, but now she usually stomps all of us.

RATING: 6.1
Aug12:

I understand the attraction, but it's just not for me.  Too few decisions to be made on your turn.

And the player elimination is real.  Of course, it does add a nice touch of tension.

The dice are super nice and chunky.  There are a lot of cards for variety.  There are a couple win conditions.

You first think king-of-the-hill.  But really, it's more tug-of-war, and I dislike tug-of-war.

RATING: 10

While on the casual side, this is one of my ten favorite games to bring out and play, and it works with any group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wonderfully thematic and colourful, this game really takes the Yahtzee mechanic to a new level.  Big dice, terrifying monsters and great card art all make this a great game for kids and families - well, if only it wasn't for the player elimination.

Normally I wouldn't be so bothered about players being kicked out, but this isn't a skill-based game and there simply shouldn't be any player elimination at all, particularly when considering the game is clearly aimed at youngsters and families primarily.

Recommended, but consider changing the rules to allow "dead" players to continue playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Basically Yahtzee with Kaiju-esque monsters fighting to reign over Tokyo - absolutely brilliant. The artwork and quirky design of components genuinely contribute to how FUN it feels to play this game. Buying cards to upgrade your own personal Kaiju to match your playstyle also feels very personal and rewarding. It's also incredibly accessible - No one I've introduced this to HASN'T understood or enjoyed it. It's a great party pleaser! While dice-rolling adds an interesting random element to the game, players still feel like they have more than enough control over the outcome of the game and they have the chance to make plenty decisions that can either make or break them. King of Tokyo offers simple, unsaturated fun! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

It's a great game mechanic with similar play style to Asshole (or President) - the college drinking card game with thumbs and seats and stuff. I have the engraved wooden box edition with promo artwork cards and the promo postcards. Beautifully executed game!

RATING: 9

But then I played it, and it really works! -- in large part because, unlike most Yahtzee variants, it has player interaction. This just blows away so many of the dice-rolling games I've played over the years. So quick and fun that I'm always up for a game. Fantastic art and components put it over the top.

RATING: 7
This game is a fun romp between players and begs to be played multiple times in a session, as players get eliminated quickly and only a few special powers will be revealed and used. The game's over a bit too quickly for my tastes, but I really love the king-of-the-hill mechanics. Component quality is great, and it's good fun. I'm not sure it quite deserves all the hype it receives, though.

RATING: 5

Initial Rating: 6.0 (January 2013)

Good familiar dice game. It is pretty easy to teach and learn. As everyone talked about this game I was expecting a great game, however I´m a little disappointed. Still I recognize it is a very good filler, but not my kind of game and I´m glad I sold my copy.

Its main strength is that is plays so fast, that you don’t care about the luck involved in it. Also due to its speed, the player elimination is not an issue. 

I´m pretty sure I will play it again as the game is fun from time to time.

Current Rating: 5.0
[hr]
2013-11-18

After a couple of additional games, I have changed my mind, it has a lot of uncontrollable luck and it is very boring for me. The games takes araound 45m, way too long. If I don’t play KoT again it would be for the best. I will do my best to stay away from the game, however many in my game group really like it.

RATING: 7
I like this game. Simple and straightforward, just monsters bashing the hell out of each other for control over Tokyo, Godzilla-style. I love the big dice you roll each turn to damage others, gain some life or some cash to buy special powers. I would say it's best from 3 to 5 players.

RATING: 4
Estoy un poco decepcionado con este juego, esperaba que fuera más divertido.

El juego está sobreproducido (pero no incluye figuras) y te hace pensar que vas a jugar a un juego de la leche, pero no es así.

Los monstruos son similares, no tienen poderes especiales. No importa si juegas con el que se parece a King Kong ó con el que se parece a Godzilla, todos hacen lo mismo... esto es una gilipollez y está totalmente enfocado a lo comercial, porque sí han sido incluidos en la expansión.

Además, los jugadores pueden ser eliminados y el juego todavía sigue, creando situaciones tontas de 1 contra 1.

Juego regular para 4 ó 5 jugadores.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2013
[/color][color=blue]
I´m a little bit disappointed with this game. I was expecting more fun.

Game is a little bit overproduced (but includes no figures) and that makes you feel that you going to play to an awesome game but it´s not.

Monsters are similar, no special powers. Doesn´t matter if you play with the King Kong-like character or the Godzilla-like one, they all do the same... that´s very stupid and completely commercial-focused, because they included it in an expansion.

In addition players can be eliminated and the game still goes on, creating not very fun situations 1 vs 1.

Ok game for playing 4-5 players.[/color]

RATING: 5
I had no intentions of playing King of Tokyo as this kind of silly random luckfest is not up my alley but a guy from the Iello booth at Spiel 2011 asked me to enter a game of it as they were looking for one more player. As expected, it's not my kind of game but for 20 minutes and considering the gorgeous art, it's ok. I had fun killing myself and reaching the victory condition of 20 VP at the same time by playing jetfighters. At that time, we all weren't sure if this made me the winner or first loser. In the mean time, I know that I lost the game but it didn't matter as it was the most fun part of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is fun on so many levels! It was a breeze to teach to my cousins, and they speak English as a second language. Anyone can understand the monster theme, and the ability cards are so perfectly written that it's hilarious! It's a great value with amazing replayability.

I had to get the expansions after how amazing the core game is.

Update: I like what the expansions did to the game, but I find myself getting bored during my plays. I am beginning to gravitate toward more strategic games, and this one lacks the hidden information to keep it fresh. Still fun to play with the right crowd, but not what I remember

RATING: 8.8
Amazing game to introduce people to hobby games. Works at all player counts over 2.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a bad game, but tends to be a bit predictable. 
The game is a glorified version of Yahtzee. You roll 6 dice multiple times, re-rolling only the ones you don't like. You can heal, gain victory points, or attack other monsters. You win the game by killing all of the other monsters, or by reaching 20 victory points. The game can be fun, but it needs people who can immerse themselves in the b-grade monster film theme, and not take things too seriously. Would recommend if you want to spend 30 mins playing a light-hearted game, but wouldn't recommend if you are looking for a strategy based game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Lacks both strategic depth and amusement factor. 

Player elimination is not always a problem, i.e. if the game is still interesting to watch, but Tokyo falls flat on that too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
While King of Tokyo is certainly a popular game, most likely due to it's theme, it's not a very good game.  There is very little incentive to actually put your monster into Tokyo.  You have a target on your chest while everyone else sits back and licks their wounds.  The game often turns into a roll off for who gets what the need first to win.  On top of that, this game is not as good as its sequel: King of New York.

King of New York has more for the player to do.  You have greater incentive to be in Manhattan than Tokyo.  There is more fighting, and you can't sit back and bide your time. Cards are more important in KoT than KoNY.  Since there is less to do in KoT, buying and using cards has a bigger role; you have more time to buy and use them.

This game is a little simpler, so a lot of people argue that it's better to start new players on KoT and graduate them to KoNY, but that's crap.  KoNY isn't too difficult for new players to understand.  Just skip straight to the better and more interesting game.  The only reason to own KoT is if you need to collect different monster tokens.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Using a Yahtzee-like dice mechanism players roll for points, attacks (which lower the life gauges of other players), healing (which raises your own life gauge), and energy (with which you buy efficiency boosts and one-shot effects). Symmetry is broken by one player being "in Tokyo", which yields additional points at the cost of increased vulnerability. Play goes on until one player reaches a score threshold or all players but one have been eliminated. The game can nominally be played with two, but should be played with three or more to take advantage of multiplayer dynamics like opportunity costs and asymmetric valuation. While it's true that rolling well is good strategy, the game is lively and not too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A blast with 4 or more people.

RATING: 6
Excellent game IF you also play with the Power Up expansion. Otherwise just a 6.

KoNY is said to finally get its own Power Up expansion so it'll finally be a superior version (right now KoT + PU = KoNY).

KoT is a great, simple dice rolling game. Sadly enough there are some problems with it that have kinda soured it for me. Stuff like more players = strength of the very dull VP/stars strategy rises. The fun bit of the base game, the ability cards, being way too expensive. Going for a battle build being totally useless by the time you get a decent loadout. And so on.

Still, great little filler. I don't want it in my own collection but I like it well enough :)

RATING: 8
Players: 2-6
Time: 30 Minutes
Players take the role of giant monsters as they try to destroy a city. This is primarily a dice mechanic, but permits a bunch of useful decisions. Monsters can improve throughout the game so that each is unique. This game is very re-playable and very entertaining.

RATING: 7
An amazing game with a very easy to teach and learn rule set.  Artwork / production quality is good, but my game came with some very irritating blotches in quality.  I did however get replacement parts free of charge so I'm going to grade the game as if these were non-issues.  The game itself plays out really fast, and with lots of dice rolls.  Very good gateway game for people to get into gaming who generally would shy away from heavy rule sets and lots of thinking.  I'd say it's kid friendly enough, and plays well no matter how many players there are.  Only downside is, if you are a bit more of a heavy gamer, the game is a lot farther down the lighter side of gaming than I personally would like.  I'm more a medium weight player myself.

Due to the ease of setup and retention factor of this game, it would still probably be one of my most played games in general groups.  So it will always have a place on my shelf.  I just wished it had a bit more bite considering the hype surrounding it.  The game's only flaw is that there is nothing but good things about it, just not enough of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Based on one four-player game.  A fitting description might be "Yahtzee on steroids".  It really comes down to rolling six dice and saving the best individual dice over three successive rolls.  Then with the results you gain a combination of health, energy (money), hits on another monster(s) and/or victory points.  The game also includes card that you can purchase which provide varous powers or points (health/life).  A very light game that anyone can play.  It was fun and I'd certainly play it again.  Not sure if I need to own it though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great family game. Easy to learn, play and teach.

RATING: 7
Great small 30-45 min game.  Good for a low-key group of people.  Game is based on dice rolling so luck is a large part of the game.  That being said it is still very fun to play. Nothing terribly confusing about it and it can be taught in 10 minutes with a few "fake rolls/turns".  Not a whole lot for strategy, this can be used as a gateway. Normally will use this game to break the ice into other games on game night with newer gamers, it is good for indicating if the newer gamers are capable of stepping into a deeper game or if you need to stay at this level of strategy.

Aktualizacja 11.09.2017 Plus dla Egmontu - zapytałem czy mają jeszcze karty promocyjne (10szt) które kiedyś dodawali do przedsprzedaży i okazało się że gratis wyślą mi je jeżeli potwierdzę zakup dodatku (który miałem właśnie kupić i napisałem by wysłali jedną paczką jak by mieli te karty). RATING: 8
The gameplay is kind of light, and the monsters are identical except for the graphics. But it's a fun theme with great components. The way you get to customize your monster throughout the game by giving it new powers is a lot of fun. Although some of the powers synergize SO well that they break the game. And the game doesn't play very well with only 2 people, which is unfortunate because due to player-elimination, it's very likely to become a 2-player game at some point.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7
I bought this as an introduction game for my friends and I at university.
It's a good beginner game with simple rules and is always good for an easy night of gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
I'd consider myself a pretty gateway gamer, but I don't enjoy this game. It's often compared to Yahtzee which I find quite boring but at least when you roll you are going for different outcomes every time and your options narrow down as play continues making the game more dynamic. Here's it's just roll for whatever you really want every time. The amount of luck and lack of skill in this game is what really gets to me. Some interesting things start to happen when cards come into play, but just when the game seems like it might be getting interesting it always comes to an abrupt end. Many players forego acquiring cards altogether only adding more monotany to the game. Then there's the downtime and player elimination which can lead to a back and forth tug-of-war just to end the game. Nobody in my gaming group have seem all that enthused by the game either. I might recommend this game for children and families. I do generally dislike dice games and games of chance, but I actually own and enjoy Bang! The Dice Game which I feel scratches the same itch, only better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good game in and of itself but KoNY really improves upon it.

RATING: 6
Roll dice, roll dice some more.  This game features elimination, which is not a good thing, especially since the final 2 can stretch on for a while.

The theme is the saving grace, it is rather enjoyable.  You do get a bit of a monsterly feel, especially when hurting people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is surprisingly fun. After years of not picking it up, I finally did. It's interesting to see how things play out. You have a luck factor, but also a strategy factor. Roll dice, but keep what you think will benefit you. The game also moves very quickly and even when you get eliminated, the end game lasts no more than 5 minutes. It's funny to watch two players duke it out for king of tokyo, leaving tokyo when they can.

This is a nice filler game.  It goes by quick, replay several times, and is just an all around nice dice rolling game.  I enjoy it and so has my gaming group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a local favorite. I carry this with me at all times, because inevitably someone asks to play it. It accommodates a large group of players, and is relatively light on the thinking, you roll dice, keep what you want, roll again, keep more, roll one last time. What you do and how you play is completely up to you, it's open ended strategy, first to 20 victory points wins, BUT, you can kill all your opponents, and voila, you win. A nice card market buying element keeps the games fresh, as your experience can change based on what you buy. Art is top notch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game looks great, is super thematic, easy to teach and fun. It's your usual Yahtzee-like, but this time with a giant monster theme. And the mix works! It's a very light-hearted, take-that kind of game. The downside is that there aren't all that many decisions to be taken, so it's mostly a matter of how much you can press your luck. I prefer [thing=143741][/thing], which scratches the same itch, but doesn't play itself as much as King of Tokyo does.

Still, good if you're in the right mood, and probably great to introduce non-gamers to the hobby.

RATING: 7.9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
great fun, family style dice game. The mechanics are similar to Yahtzee except you are monsters fight to control Tokyo. Each player has a chance to attack other players in or out of tokyo, buy power up cards, heal or take VPs. The game play is that of king of the hill. The longer you maintain tokyo, the more points you'll get. 

While the game is fun for light or moderate gamers, I had a few issues with the game. Some of the cards are game-changingly ambiguous. meaning if someone reads a card one way, it could totally change the game and the outcome. The explanation of cards in the game is rather lacking. Also, the monsters are all the same. There is no reason to pick one over the other. I think one of the expansions changes this, but it should have been in the base game IMO.

Definitely recommend though if you are looking for a fun, light family dice game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game, with nice visuals, fun gameplay, and fun player interaction. The components aren't that great though. The monster standees like to peel, and the cards are cheap quality. Overall, a great game despite the less than stellar components.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Big dice, cool theme, great artwork for the win.  The game is simple, you want to get the victory point goal first.  You are enticed to get to that goal faster by trying to stand on Tokyo, but the trade off is everyone gets to beat up your character while you are there.   I think this is a very clever game and It won't take long to teach it to anyone, while at the same time it has enough variety that multiple strategies can be taken to achieve your goal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Too many decisions are made for you in this game. If you're low on health, roll for health etc. Not terrible but not exciting either. 

Edit:
I started ignoring points and rolling only for attacks and health. Then, I would bail the second I was hit in Tokyo. I made this switch and won the next 3 games I played, and decided I didn't want to play anymore. Points are useless if people attack like they should. The problem with this is I had zero decisions. We're talking less decisions than Yahtzee, because in Yahtzee you have to decide what you're rolling for. In KOT you just see how many hits and health you roll.

RATING: 8

I'd typically rate it a 7 for its low amount of strategy and high luck, but due to the how much fun we always have playing it and the regularity it gets to the table, it has earned an honorary 8.

RATING: 7
The most-played game in my house. Its quick playing time means we can play 3-4 matches in an afternoon. This is the dice game that has meaningful choices, plus wonderful art and great mechanic. We play with my house rule of drafting cards like 7 Wonders (which is the only house rule I use for my games, increased game value tremendously) and ban some over-powered cards to keep balance and make the draft fresh every time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At the start of each turn, you roll six dice. The dice show the following six symbols: 1, 2 or 3 Points of Destruction, Energy, Healing and Whack. Over three successive throws, choose whether to keep or discard each die in order to win destruction points, hoard energy, restore health, or whack other players into understanding that Tokyo is YOUR territory.The fiercest player will be crowned King of Tokyo... and will end up facing all the other monsters alone!Top this off with special cards purchased with energy that have a permanent or temporary effect, such as the growing of a second head which grants you an additional die, body armor, nova death ray, and more.... and it's one of the most explosive games of the year!In order to win the game, one must either destroy Tokyo by accumulating 20 destruction points, or be the only surviving monster once the fighting has ended.

RATING: 4
Played once, 5p.  I do not understand a bit of love this game gets.  This is one step up from random dice rolling.  The theme is paper thin; I never once felt it was about monsters duking it out in Tokyo.  It was simply about rolling dice to get a decent result.  My decisions were which dice to keep/re-roll, whether or not to leave Tokyo (I never had that choice to make), and if I should buy a new power (this was almost always an obvious choice).  This is really a themed version of Can't Stop with an additional random element - the special powers.  Very weak.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This is basically a dice fest filler.  Fun, wacky, with special powers that can be purchased with acquired energy cubes.  First to 20 wins.  Lots of chaos, limited planning, luck of the roll but like yahtzee, you can roll your dice up to three times.  Plays up to 6 as well.  Easiest set of instructions you'll see outside of perhaps Blokus?  I'd play this to open or close an evening any time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[u]Awards:[/u]
[b]Game of the Con - GenCon 2013[/b]

[u]Comments:[/u]
A great filler game filled with surprises and fun. The cards are what really make this game tick, and I think giving players 2 cards to start would even up the ante with this one. The components are top notch.

[u]Comments Update:[/u]
While i initially saw the genius of the pure awesomeness that is KoT, I didn't understand how long lasting that awesomeness could be. I spent most of the GenCon 2013 playing this game just to get a stupid Space Penguin, and even though I didn't win a single game of the 20+ games that I palyed during the con, I enjoyed every single second of it. That says something awfully loud about this game.

[u]Expansions Owned:[/u]

RATING: 6.9
I hate most dice rolling games that are not RPGs. But, this one is pretty fun. The concept and customization of your monster makes it a decent dice rolling game. If I had kids, I bet that I would have to play this all the time after they understand the mechanics of yahtzee.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I think this is the single most popular game in my game group. If we want to play something, but don't know what to play, this is one of our go to games. This game is fun and really short. All the rules can be explained in the matter of minutes and there is practically no set up time. There is no one way to win and relies luck with a minimal amount of thinking so there is no guaranteed strategy to win, giving it a fair amount of replay value. I would recommend it especially for people with short attention spans or are just too tired to focus on a game for too long.

RATING: 4
Fun light game in a Beer and Pretzels atmosphere.  The Yahtzee dice mechanic is simple, attacking other players is fun, and there's enough strategy in deciding to attack, heal, earn energy, or go for points.  Once everyone knows the game it seems to drag.  the correct strategy involves healing as much as possible which just lengthens the game.  Especially with Power Up.  Need to try King of New York, which supposedly has quicker player elimination.

RATING: 10
What a blast!  Very easy to learn and while two can play this game, it works better with the more people you have. The seemingly infinite amount of ability cards can tilt the game over the course of a turn or two, which is great.  Yes, someone who is getting their doors blown off can make a full recovery (with the right dice rolls and proper cards) to make a comeback.  It happened to me...sadly I wasn't the one making the comeback.  I was the one kicking tail then eventually got wrecked and lost.

RATING: N/A
I'm kind of on my own when it comes to King of Tokyo in my group.

It just doesn't get any love. It may be that my group is directly split between theme and euro players.

The thematic guys want something a bit more exciting, and the Euro guys want something considerably less lucky.

It's a shame because I really enjoy the simple brilliance of KoT. Then again, I like Bang! Dice game as well so I guess these short dice games work for me specifically.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has it's ups and downs. Sometimes we get games where everyone has fun and it's all a back and forth, but other games it's a complete one sided devastation by one or two players and the rest are just stomped over and not having fun. I don't suggest playing this with younger kids who have issues with losing or taking things personally. It can be a good tool to teach those qualities but if they are too young this can just end in tears.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is ok. It's fun, but too much downtime in between players (I play with 6 people) and too much luck for my taste. I enjoy luck but this is almost entirely based on it.

Just gets boring after a while. I'll still keep it, but probably will only bring out for serious non gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've been intrigued by King of Tokyo as a nice, colorful filler game and finally got a chance to play it.  We've typically not been huge fans of dice games, but this one seemed to work better as it was short and sweet.  Yes, it can be random, but it is fun to try and play king of the mountain.  What makes the game is not the dice---it's the cards, which give each player a more unique identity with special abilities.  The unique abilities gives the game a lot more replayability and fun, so I'm eager to give the expansion a try as well.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
PnP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whenever you just want to roll some chunky dice, this is the game for you. Bonus points for roaring like Godz...Gigasaur.
When you have just 30-35 minutes, don't want to think too much just get into the action, this is a great game to have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really fun lightweight (family) game.  There's a fair amount of luck because the game's mostly based on the dice rolls, which the yahtzee rules (re-roll up to twice) helps mitigate SOMEwhat.  The real reason that's ok is that a game only takes 20-30 minutes, so you just play again.  

The theme is really goofy, monsters beating each other up and eating a city.  My wife didn't think she would like it (ugh, monsters? I'm not a little boy), but actually she DID after she played it, and we played 2 more times.

The meat of the game is in all the cards you can buy.  Good fun stuff.  My one complaint is that, since there's only 3 of them, you can really get a bad lot, and it costs 2 energy to recycle them :-(

I love the components.  The semi-translucent green energy cubes, the really meaty dice, the ultra simple gameboard (which also summarizes the 3 effects of being in tokyo).  The cardboard stand-up things for your monsters--ok, not as awesome as miniatures--but it makes the game cheaper and I actually like that move for this particular game, even though normally I wouldn't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I didn't like the theme at first, kept me from buying it for a bit.  The Game play is a perfect balance of luck and strategy.  Those who lean towards heavy strategy or heavy luck will be a little disappointed. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tastes of the boardgame tribe change as fast as a victory point wheel turns.  When I started getting involved in this hobby dice and early elimination were practically forbidden.  Now they seem to be de rigueur.  However, I am always slow to keep up and they are not yet to my tastes (give me another year when everyone has moved on).

However, the artwork, quality of dice and flavour of the cards are excellent.  Plus though it is only a narrow choice of decisions they are real and get the brain warmed up.

Fun but lacking substance.

RATING: 7
Initial impression. (8)

Very great gameplay with pretty poor components (curved bent cards straight from the box, unrefined painting of dices, character score plate trackers are very loose, some characters cardboard standees are bent on the edge) and an unclear rule book.

30x plays (7)

The game get deeper beyond the surface, its eveb more entertaining. However the components could not keep up and further question the quality and material involved.

A die chipped a bit on the edge. 
The cards need sleeves to shuffle better. 

Pretty boring when played with 2p but it's better with variants from BGG forum.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is basically dice rolling and hoping but that is fun in a filler. The cards you can buy to change up and individualize your particular monster have a nice variety of powers and my card combo brain churns away looking for synergy.

That said, the game is pretty random. Getting eliminated is not a big deal - even if you get KO'd early, I have seen folks mentioning the simple variant of re-entering the game with a fresh monster. And in any case, it usually short enough that the elimination is not a problem.

Part of me yearns for a bit more control of what happens on a turn. Perhaps a way to give a more steady income of energy points (the game currency) so the cards can get into play? It would also be cool to distinguish the monsters from the outset rather than as they buy powers - is it as simple as giving everyone some cash to spend at the beginning? Or setting a power card for each monster (something thematic)?

Anyway, I bought this for a game that my 8 year old would love and that part has paid off handsomely.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You are a monster trying to destroy all other monsters in the game. You do this by rolling dice and attacking other monsters, healing or gaining energy which allows you to buy special cards that provide unique powers.  If you score a certain number of points or defeat all other monsters, you win.  

Very light, very fun family weight game.  It is a dice game and you get multiple rolls but good rolls can win the game for you and poor rolls will lose it.  Even with this, the game is short (about 30-45 min) and great fun.  Card play adds a unique dynamic to the game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, this is a great dice game.  Theme and mechanics are a great match.  Love the king of the hill dynamic of moving in and out of Tokyo.  Also, this game does not have the problem of many conflict-oriented games where 'take-this' and 'take-that' is chosen by individual players for semi-random or metagaming reasons, because damage is dealt based solely on whether you are in or out of Tokyo.  There is player-elimination, but games are generally pretty short, so not so big of a deal.

The components are by no means overproduced--ignore comments to that effect.  If the monster figures were life-size and stomped around during their turns and when Cyber Bunny causes Complete Destruction two turns in a row for the win (*cue triumphant sounding metal music* \m/), the whole building in which the game was being played and all other players were destroyed, then *that* would be overproduced components.  Anything less is merely adequate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Good game for kids too. Even my seven year old has her attention held.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Some of the cards in this game seem unbalanced at first, but on further reflection I think it's a case that when the powerful cards come out, players need to work as a group to punish the players that take them; a conservative game will let the luckiest player win, whereas an aggressive game lets skill play a deciding role (though of course, the aggression needs to be managed).

I seem to be born to lose at this, after being one of the first two eliminated in my first four games. Nevertheless, this is fun.

One caveat is that the 5-6 player option feels tacked on, and is not sufficiently well explained in the rulebook. I'd suggest playing with exactly 4 players only.

RATING: 7.9

The high score is because the game is a lot of fun, quick, easy to teach, and I would not turn it down in spite of the flawed mechanic and the fact that I am not usually a fan of dice rolling (again a testament to the strength of the game).  A classic and also a great gateway game.

RATING: 8
Always a top pick at family game night, KoT is a staple in both our house and my game group. Great as either a filler or a tournament game, it's immensely entertaining. The oversized dice are a great touch and the monster standees make it easy to get into the game. The "keep 1 and roll the rest" mechanic ensures that players gain something on every turn and the energy, points and attacks ensure everyone can take their own path to victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very Chaotic.  You'll have to enjoy chanting your desired roll as you shake the dice, trash talking with your opponents, and reading the clever titles of the cards.  If you don't, there's not really much of a "game" here.  Love the art, the theme, etc.  All very cute.  But those rolls will ultimately determine the winner, and many of the cards are "swingy" or just basically "rewind" the game and make it longer.  You'll have to be ok with that.  Don't get me wrong - many people are ok with that, and with the right group I don't mind a fun, colorful, nicely-themed dice fest if it's not too long.  Just be aware that this is what King of Tokyo is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Great components - lame gameplay. Too unbalanced. There is a huge discrepancy between life points and required victory points, thus killing each other is the only feasible option (House rule #1: when taking control of Tokyo you gain 2 VP, when starting your turn in Tokyo you gain 3 VP). The cards are, also, very costly. No more than 4-6 cards are ever played in each game (House rule #2: you get 2 energy cubes instead of one with each energy result). All of the above could be forgiven, if the theme existed. Unfortunately, there is no feeling of rampage in Tokyo.

In essence it's a children's game. Indeed, my son loves it, my daughter likes it, so... it's rather ok I guess.

----------------------------
UPDATE: I now always use house rule #2 and my overall impression has significantly improved. If this was an official rule, I would rate it a 6!

RATING: 7
Rating based on 3 players.
