=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
King of Tokyo is such a beautifully done Kaiju themed, dice driven battle, and variable power card drafting game that creates a new experience with every play.  The re-playability of this game is quite high with the end of every game (especially with new players) having at least one person saying, "lets play again".  What makes it so re-playable is its shortness with play time 30 minutes or less and its deck of variable powers that can be bought leading to different strategies.  The simplicity of the main game mechanic with Yahtzee style of re-rolling die to either do battle, power up, regain health, or gain victory points is so elegantly done that its luck factor feeling is reduced to nothingness.  It is good for all ages, for experienced gamers, and people you'd like to have enjoy gaming at its best for the first time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The base game is... not really fun.

It's more boring-er than Yahtzee, and Yahtzee's pretty boring. Pro-tip game designers: if you're going to have players play different characters (especially cool ones, like big, scary monsters), have them all have different powers. Now, I've heard the first expansion does exactly this, but seriously? Variable player powers should definitely have been part of the original game. Leaving it out, just so it could be an expansion is pretty weak-sauce if you ask me.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Probably still my favorite boardgame of all time, if not counting Magic. And also the game that opened my mind to dice. I've always been opposed to dice, as they are usually used only for rolling for "good or bad stuff", instead of possibilities as with cards. But Kings of Tokyo, with it's light strategy, gives you possibilities with the dice. You can still roll badly, but you have to be really unlucky and it will rarely set you back much. It's just a really good gateway game that's easy to understand, super silly, has a good amount of luck, but still not so much that the game feels too random (like Fluxx or Munchkin). The player elimination part is also a good introduction to, what we in my groups call, "Gentleman Play" - not being a dick towards someone just because you can. I cannot praise this game enough and I will probably never get tired of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good party game and filler game. Similar to dice Bang, but some variety with cards.

Quite a hoot - a game you can play 3-4 times in a row without growing tired of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I love the theme and artwork, but I feel the balance / mechanisms of this game are off in quite a few ways:
1) 2-player game completely does not work (bgg ratings reflect this with >80% not recommended, so I won't elaborate).
2) Victory points in center are not proportional to # opponents / allies. So I feel far too little bonus for 4-player game, and far too much for a 2-player game. This changes as players are eliminated, but doesn't make it balanced.
3) Game can be won without ever fighting! This makes me sad since I've seen it happen several times, and it contradicts the entire theme.
4) Power cards feel pretty imbalanced (e.g. sometimes costs most of 2 rounds to get a decent card, other times 2 cheap cards combine to give an easy win).
5) Decisions rarely substantial/difficult. Most of the time my initial roll narrows my reasonable strategic choices pretty drastically (at most one or two possibilities). So I don't feel I'm playing the game nearly as much as the dice are. To be fair, the cards add a bit to this (if multiple are useful). Choosing when to exit Tokyo is usually not a hard choice though.

FWIW I have high-ish win rate (~50% for 4-5 player games) against more serious gamers than myself, so I doubt I'm missing something. Maybe just need to treat the game as a light social activity and not look for depth here.

RATING: 6
Updated - After playing it a couple times with my kids, I have to bump it up a point.  The special ability cards are what make this a fun game to play. The overproduction of it is what makes my kids want to play it in the first place. So I can't say thats really a bad thing. Uhhhmmmm, trying to understand the BGG ranking on this one is a bit of a head scratcher.  It's a cute enough game that is fun, but rank it in the 300s?  I think there are lots of games ranked higher than it that are much better quality games.  For me it scratches the same itch as Mmmmm... Brains!, and  actually is a bit less elegant. That game is ranked at around 6400 I think.... I really don't understand how they are so different in ranking. Perhaps being a decent Godzilla theme game makes people rank it better?  Perhaps because it is so much better than Rocketville? I don't know...  I actually ding it a point in my rating because it is so overproduced. I just don't think you are getting a whole lot of game for the $35-40 retail price tag. If the production value wasn't so high I seriously doubt people would play it more than a couple times and forget about it.

It is a $10 dice game in a $40 box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.6
BANG! The Dice Game scratches this itch quicker now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
King of Tokyo is a fun-filled dice rolling romp!  In it players take on the persona of a giant monster, a la Godzilla, and fight each other to dominate Tokyo.  On your turn you roll dice Yahtzee style, whereby you have three rolls to get the symbols you want. You can roll numbers which give you victory points, electric bolts which get you energy, claws which are attacks that you can use against other monsters, or hearts which heal you.  You can use your energy gained through rolls to purchase cards that will give your monster various special abilities.  You win by being the first person to get 20 victory points, or by killing off all your opponents.

The game is beautifully made.  The player markers are cardboard stands with fun cartoony renditions of monsters. The dice are chunky with the custom images engraved into them.  There's even a cool push-your-luck aspect to the game, as the longer a player stays in Tokyo the more victory points you earn.  However, you can't heal your wounds in Tokyo, so the longer you stay the more chance of getting killed.  Everything about the game is great!  Buy a copy now!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So much fun to play with the right crowd. The children loves it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Perhaps the most overrated game ever made. 

It's not anything about what kind of game this is - I like short games; I like dice games, and I love the idea of dueling giant monsters.

What I don't like is a game with little strategy, and what strategy there is being completely unthematic. Half the dice are friggin' rolling for victory points for chrissake. Unthematic random VP crap can be bad in a Euro, but in a game like this, it's pretty unforgiveable.

Also, in games I've seen, the winner tends to be the person who spends as little time in Tokyo as possible - those who overstay their welcome get killed, and those who play cowardly and roll for VPs tend to win. And those who go for cool special abilities find that the game usually ends before they can do much with them.

In other hands, it's a luck-filled, non-strategic game that rewards the dullest and most unthematic strategy. 

This game is barely passable as a kid's game - for adults, it's a miserable failure. If you want some mindless violent fun play Cash and Guns instead. Just because a game is designed by Richard Garfield and features giant monsters doesn't mean it's any good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome Yahtzee adaptation. Easy to teach, simple mechanics allow for fun bantering. Getting points directly from dice is bit boring even though there's push-your-luck element involved and player elimination can be a problem (especially if you play with 4+) but other than that it's a nice game. Power Up! is decent expansion.

2-Player Comment:
* I think King of Tokyo is fun even with two, but the more the merrier. Unofficial 2p variant: Only 1 point per round in Tokyo. Lose 1 health per round in Tokyo. Otherwise follow normal rules.

Expansions:
+King of Tokyo: Power Up!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Full Review: http://manualgamer.com/king-of-tokyo-review/

Tokyo smashing goodness!  In King of Tokyo, players get to be giant monsters rampaging through Tokyo, causing as much chaos and mayhem as possible.  It is fast, fun and fantastic for families and casual gamers.

Essentially, it is Yahtzee with giant monsters and super powers.

Fun and light, with different strategies depending on what others are doing, and the cards that are available.  Shall I rush Tokyo and smash down my opponents?  Shall I sit in the background and go for point victory?  Shall I power up my character with various abilities?

King of Tokyo is incredibly easy to learn and teach.  The amount of luck involved means that brand new players have plenty of opportunity to win against seasoned veterans.

Sometimes the interaction between particular power-up cards isn’t clear.  Fortunately this is a rare occurrence, and if players can’t agree then there is a fist full of monster dice to help settle any argument.

Players who have difficulty with being eliminated may need some assistance and coaxing to play (adults or children).  However given the short play time and the amount of luck involved in this game, players shouldn’t take elimination too personally.

While this game does play with 2 players, doing so loses much of the interaction that comes with 3 plus players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Good: 
Entertaining selection of characters, power ups, and powers. 

Easy to teach and pretty quick to play, yet has interesting gameplay. Which makes it the perfect candidate for a large variety of gamer and non-gamer types. 

Theme is successfully portrayed in art and gameplay. 

Bad: 
Once you have seen all of the characters in action, powers, and power ups the game loses some of its shine and becomes a bit repetitive. 

The Power Up! expansion is a must if you enjoy this game as it actually gives each character themed powers and increases the diversity of the hearts on the dice.

RATING: 8
So fun!  Simple game with limited strategic/tactical options and heavily dice-dependent, but the interaction between players is strong and makes for a great atmosphere.  Players attack each other directly so there's strong conflict but always in a fun manner that gets people laughing, cheering, and sometimes even shouting.

The special ability cards are the source of variability from play to play.  Some cards when bought can really change the strategy for all other players, so each game is unique.  It's a pity that so few cards come into play in any given session because some of them can really swing the balance of a game.

Component quality is excellent and the artwork is just terrific.  The look of the game alone will get a lot of people interested in it.  It's definitely not a dry Euro game in either aesthetics or mechanics.  Fun for all ages.

RATING: 7
I’d been looking for a lighter, silly themed game for a while, and this does a good job.  Basic mechanics are great, and the “king-of-the-hill” style gameplay works wonders for keeping everyone engaged in a game of “direct conflict” while avoiding much of the issues that plague other take-that style games.  That said, I think the game could have used more development and balancing.  We’ve resorted to using a number of house rules to mainly increase the energy supplies enabling more turn-over and use of the power cards, which is the real interesting part of the gameplay.  It is yet another take on the Yahtzee die rolling mechanic, but it’s wrapped into quite an interactive and tense game.

RATING: 7.6
This is a great gateway game; it's easy to teach and seems to be widely appealing due to a great theme and eye-catching art. While it can play a wide range of players, I would say there is a sweet spot with 4 (with more it can drag on due to players auto-fleeing when in Tokyo). 

Expansions:
* The "Power Up!" expansion is a must-have, as it adds a nice catch-up mechanic through the evolution cards (with the added thematic bonus).
* The "Halloween" expansion adds some cool new monsters with the interesting "Gift" Evolutions, but can probably wait to be purchased until you really need another fix for your board game buying addiction.

RATING: 8
2 3 4 5 6 P

Video review here! http://www.the-boarding-kennel.com/?p=361
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
As with any dice game, there's definitely a randomness to KoT.  However, I think it works well with the fast and chaotic theme.  This isn't a strong strategy game, per se, although there certainly is some decision making.  I tend to really enjoy it because of the fun theme and great art, fairly fast play, and the fact that it plays up to 6 players.  If you like games like Martian Dice or Zombie Dice, I look at this as a much better multi-player implementation of something like that.  You're still just rolling dice and hoping, but there's enough strategy mixed in to keep it engaging.  I do have a hard time with the player-elimination aspect, but it's usually a short enough game that this isn't a notable problem.  Unfortunately, most of the gamers I've played with don't seem to enjoy it as much as me, but as a family game or just something to bring out with a group of casual friends, it seems to go over very well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A light-hearted fun game, shines when played by the "rule of cool" instead of doing your outmost to coldly play the odds. Sure - you can just die (and thus be eliminated) by what is a fluke of the dice, but I find I don't care.

Ultimately, I don't get much satisfaction out of playing, I think I'm irked about the numbers, they feel a bit cheap, if the dice had 6 difference faces, or just duplicates of some, and all of them had some sort of ability - then I'd be more happy. As it is, rolling for numbers reminds me too much of Yahtzee. More energy also to get wacky with the cards a bit more maybe? Bah, anyway, I like the concept, and I could easily be more enthused with it if it only had a biiiiit more meat to it. Maybe New York? Though I fear it adds complexity to all the wrong areas.

A perfectly fine game, it's just that I'd always pick something else I guess
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Game in a Nutshell: Roll dice to gain 20 VP or be the last monster standing.

Played as: 4,5,6 player

Pros: Great theme, excellent art, and big chunky components. Easy to explain and enjoy to its fullest on the first play. Tons of power-ups such that you could play several plays without seeing them all let alone actually buying or using them. Playable with a broad range of ages.

Cons: Perhaps it's the quick playtime or maybe the overall luckiness, but I never seem to care about how I'm doing such that there's more than a little excitement or tension. Really, that's a pretty significant ding given there's not a ton or cognitive interest or crunchy decisions to be made. Player elimination, however short lived, never feels really great.

Other: This game was on the top of my wishlist for over a year and one I really wanted to like. It's a fine, fun game but it sort of disappointed in that there seems to be more moans than cheers during play. It's something Magical Athlete (another stupid, for-fun dice game), for its lack of variety, had: an attachment to your progress that filled each roll with loads of adrenaline. I was expecting more of that in King of Tokyo.

Best Use: Good for starting or ending a game night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not sure what everyone likes about this one.  I found it to be just okay.

RATING: 8
Category: Light Strategy - fun and exciting game with lots of cheering and laughing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This one has fallen of the map a bit recently. It was my go-to pull off the shelf for months after owning it. One of the reasons could be that I find the game too structured. What I mean is that it follows a very distinct pattern based on the number of players. For example, in a two player game, cards are generally ignored and occupying Tokyo is the fastest way to win. With three players, a late push into Tokyo after rolling some VPs will probably get you the win. I don’t think cards are viable until playing with five or more players. Also, an underlying mechanism that develops is that players tend to mirror each other. If a player rolls VPs the next player will inevitably try the same. Then the third player feels like they’re falling behind and they feel compelled to follow suit. Same can be said if players start stockpiling energy. I’ll admit not all games follow this formula but no matter the group, the “sheep” mentality prevails. Is this bad? No. For me it slightly detracts from the game. The only other negative about the gameplay is that I find 20 VPs to be too short. With the addition of five or ten more points I think it would make a world of difference. It would give time for players to upgrade their monsters with purchased cards while not feeling they’d fall behind players that were focused on rolling VPs versus energy. One fix to the issues could be to use the evolution cards. I’ve been hesitant to pull them out because I imagine them making the game shorter. Hopefully I’m wrong but I’ve yet to try them.

On a separate note, I REALLY like Broken Token’s organizer for this game. Using the organizer I am able to fit so much into the base game’s box. In addition to all the components in the base game, I’ve added the 1st Power Up expansion, the Halloween expansion, and all the components from the 2nd Ed. Base game except for the board. I didn’t see a need to have a second in the box. That’s a total of 16 Monsters (additional monster being a promo – Kookie) with their associated boards and stands, 2 sets of power tokens, 2 decks of double sleeved power cards and costume cards, sleeved evolution cards, 3 sets of dice, a bunch of energy cubes, game board and rules.
 
The component quality is excellent. One exception is the painted dice. Seeing as how I have backups, I’m not too concerned. The Monsters, cards, artwork and other components are great and outshine the faulty dice.

30 additional games played

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Excellent filler game.  Games last 15-30 minutes.  The decisions are interesting, the interaction is high, and the art is really fun.

Dec 2013: Bumping down from 8.5 to 7.5. Sadly, the winning strategy seems to be "stay out of Tokyo and don't die." Very rarely in my experience does a game end by someone reaching 20 stars.  So the multiple paths to victory aren't as balanced as I had hoped, and therefore many of the bonuses on cards just aren't worth going after.  Still, it's fun, quick, and the art is great.

RATING: 7
Another great game from Richard Garfield. Probably best with 4, but I wouldn't hestitate to play it with 3 or 6. 

It's really fast and because of that the lucky nature doesn't bother me at all (unlike other more time demanding games). And while luck plays a large roll in how well you do, the fact that you get those 2 rerolls plus the power cards you might get to purchase, plus the possible "negotiation" (more like pleading, usually XD) adds to you actually having some saying on your destiny...

It's cheap (or cheapish), has great quality overall and it's easy to teach, accesible for beginers and enjoyable for experienced gamers.

RATING: 5
Oh, the lovely sound of dice-rolling...makes my head spin and wanting to puke. King of Tokyo is without strategy, thinking or planning. It is dice-rolling all the way through to the city sewers. Your game is totally dependent on what your dice gives you and not even the varied cards and wellcrafted art saves this from being an absolutely boring feast of dice-eating boredom. 

Oh, did I mention that if you die you are out? Good luck waiting 20-30 minutes while waiting for your friends to end the game. But then again, you can enjoy the pleasurable pain of the sound of dice-rolling for half-an hour uninterrupted.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Roll dice to improve your monster and defeat the other monsters to become King of Tokyo.

Plays: 2.
Type: Dice game = A game where you roll lots of dice. 
Complexity: Heavy dice game.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Conflict.
Randomness: High - Dice.

Replayability: Average, vengeance can be called for.
Fun: Giant monsters going at each other in every concievable and inconcievable way. This is designed to be fun more than anything else.
Memorability: A bit, the monster fighting can create some stories.

Thematic integration: High.
Components: Good.

Who will like this: People that like rolling lots of dice and want to have a quick laugh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So if this is just Godzilla Yahtzee, why do I rate it so much higher than Elder Sign? Well, for one, it's fun- a good deal more so than its Cthulhu cousin. It plays so fast that it usually sees 2-3 rounds each time, it looks great (cartoony monsters and chunky dice), and is far more family friendly than Elder. Unfortunately, it still feels a bit too slight for most of my groups. If they liked it better, I bet this would be an 7.5 or so for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
King of Tokyo is super fun, pretty light, but actually a little more strategic than it seems. The game is addictive in a way most board games aren't. As soon as one game ends, people want to play another game. I think this is because the cards and dice together add enough randomness that there's the feeling that you always COULD have won if things had just gone your way a little more.

I lump this into "reactionary strategy," which are games like poker, in which you have to be smart given a randomized set of ever-changing circumstances, as opposed to planning strategy, which are games like chess (or Agricola, etc) in which you have to smartly manipulate a complex system to give you an ideal outcome.

Because it's random, I feel like King of Tokyo gets crap from people for not being strategic, but there is real strategy in playing the dice you roll, not trying to brute force your way to one result.

Fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Great game, great party game, great gateway game. No one, and I mean no one, I have ever played this hasn't felt the love for this game. I had zero interest in this because it seemed to basic, a reversion-ed Yahtzee. It isn't, it's great, even if you think its not your thing, get it for when boring relatives come into town. The one bad thing? After the first play you will figure out how great this game is and know you will want to keep it for a while. That means sleeving the cards. Game box has a great insert, love the insert, really wish more games came with a good insert. But the insert wont work if you sleeve the cards. At some point international law should intervene and if you make a game, with a really good insert, that doesn't hold sleeved cards, you should be shot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's little more then Yhatzee with extras when the theme's stripped off, but its the theme that catches my eye rather then just scanning past and thinking "meh, dice game". Its easy to learn and not taxing on white cells to play, making it an excellent family/gateway game into more interesting themes.

It IS a dice game and therefore its just a big luck fest from start to finish, but the option to pick upgrade cards and juggling gaining life, VPs and taking life from opponents gives enough game play to keep me entertained for 25 minutes.

Watch out though as this game is prone to all the usual competitive negatives including player elimination, king making and runaway leader, and it is possible in a 5-6 player game for both occupants of Tokyo to kill every player outside in 2 sets of rolls...

This aside it can be really good fun if you don't take it too seriously. Exceedingly popular with more casual gamers.

Hilarious fact: We actually received a noise complaint from our neighbours in January 2014. Why? Because we were playing King of Tokyo at 12.30am and I assume we were enjoying it too much. Is it possible to get an ASBO for board gaming? 

Progressive Rating: 8-6-7-8-7.

RATING: 7
Fun, light-hearted and easy on the rules and game mechanics. However, do yourself a favor and put a focus on buying Power cards. These are what gives the game some flavor. The rules don't force you to focus on getting energy and buying powers. New players won't see the incentive in doing so. It is possible to finish the entire game without buying a power. And that was the most boring game I have ever played. Buy Powers. As many as you can. Even if that means delaying the end of the game unnecessarily. Have everyone else also invest into powers. Do that and the game is fun.

キング・オブ・トーキョー

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is currently the mostly played game in my family, and my 7 years old twins are crazy for it. 

It is a dice game that hits the sweet spot with its Yahtzee style rolls, multiple paths to victory element, king of the hill battle mechanics, all within a gorgeous and highly attractive Godzila monster invades Tokyo theme. 

Cards add a lot of flavor and game mechanics, and since only a small subset is used for each match, the game maintains its novelty and freshness for a long time. 

Richard Garfield has done it again and this game deserves the success it got in the last couple of years. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a fun game, but I still don't get all that fuzz, it's not THAT good. Usually it's over too quickly & you get too few energy cubes per game to buy cards and make it something else than pure dice rolling. With 2-3 players it is somewhat boring and with 5-6 players you can get killed instantly. Still, the sweet spot seems to be with 4-5 players.  

Maybe you could tweek the rules or maybe the expansion would remove some of the problems, but is it really worth the money? 25 euros for a filler expansion? I bought the base game from sales so i got it at -30% price, which seems more like the ACTUAL value.

RATING: N/A
Oh, what a kitschy subtle game. The first time I didn't like it. The second time it was ok. The third time I began enjoying it. By now I am hooked. 

This is an excellent example of the "hey let's get together and have a good time" game. This is one of those games that lets you actually have a good time with people, not just with the game itself. 

That's because the game itself is average. But the components, the theme, the special powers, and the overall "aura" it possesses make for a true gem. 

Some of my friends do not like it, and I really think that this is a pity. I always want to play this, because I always want to simply have fun with my friends.

RATING: 10
A game you play once and never stop playing, simple mechanics and very fun to play, King Of Tokyo combines the luck of the dice with a small strategic angle in order for you to win.
An excellent game for beginners in the boardgame world, King Of Tokyo is very easy to understand and start playing, even if you have never tried something of the genre before you will get the hang in no time, with the twist of the cards and the energy cubes for you to buy more powers, it's always fun to play and it's a quick game so you don't take to long completing one playthrough which makes it a blast to play.

http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/821635/thedackers-double-dose-of-energy-variant

I also own the Power Up and Halloween expansions.

EDIT: Definitely fired from my collection by King of New York.  I like that KoNY gives the players more to do if they aren't in the main point-getting parts of the city (Tokyo/Manhattan).  I'll of course keep KoT, so I can keep playing as Cyber Bunny!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has a great theme that has instant appeal to a large demographic. It capitalizes on that theme by having colorful, evocative artwork and these fun [i][b]super-sized monster standees[/b][/i].

Mechanically the game borrows the time-tested Yahtzee mechanic of rolling dice up to three time per turn before being held to a certain result AND then adds resources, player interaction, special powers and hand management ALL without over-complicating anything and weighing the game down. It offers [i][b]two different paths to victory[/b][/i] to suit different personalities and even provides clever point-tracker devices for added [b]FUN[/b].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players are monsters attempting to be the King of Tokyo, either by accumulating 20 VP first or be the last one standing. Players roll dice on their turn to either earn VP, attack, heal or get energy. Energy is used to purchase cards, which may give you more bonuses. The damage you do depends whether you are in Tokyo or outside of Tokyo. Inside, you damage all monsters outside, and when you are outside, you can only damage those monsters inside. 

This game was designed by Richard Garfield, and it is a fun little filler. I'm looking forward to more plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yahtzee rolling mechanic dramatically enhanced with lots of decision making. Big games could leave some getting bored waiting until everyone is quick with the rules.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
By all rights a dice game with lots of luck using player elimination shouldn't be fun. This one is great. Player elimination is used in just the right way. The dice rolling has enough strategy in it that the luck adds excitement not meaninglessness, the components are fun, appropraite and likable. People have complain that a given game doesn't use very many of the cards available... how is this bad? This means any given game your unlikely to repeat the same cards over and over and there's always plenty of variety. The expansion is strong though it doesn't add much--the expansion should be a better value--but this is often the case with small expansions. This game is one of the few board games that actually plays well as a "party" game of 6 people without resorting to not having a board. For family, for adults having parties, for gatherings, I can't recommend this game highly enough for how strong it is. People have complained that certain strategies just trump others; this is not the case. If you think you can just "roll for numbers" this is easily countered once someone realizes what you're doing. Likewise, just going for kills doesn't always make sense either. There is no "cheat" or "perfect" strategy for this game and you have to adapt. If a strategy seemed perfect its only because your opponents failed to adapt to it. Luck is a factor but don't let dice make you think this has more luck than many euro games that incorporate luck but dont even have dice. Overall, great game. I rate this according to the criteria BGG provides.

This game continues to just be a fairly shallow but incredibly awesome and fun crowd pleaser. An essential game for my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like this more than I expected to. Good fun, quick.

**House Rule**

1st) Drafting 
We added a drafting phase at the beginning of the game (much like 7 Wonders). Draw 5 cards, keep 1, give the remaining cards to the player on your left. From the 4 cards you received by the player on your right, keep 1. And so on. 

The selected cards are not activated but you can buy them later in the game if you can afford them.

*Also own Powerup expansion, though it slows the game down too much to bother with* 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
A very fun adaptation to the Yahtzee dice rolling mechanic. 

It makes it very approachable to new players who have never played a "board game" before.

It does have a good bit of confrontation and players can get knocked out early, making them sit idly by as they watch others having fun. That is my biggest negative to this game, and it is a considerable downside because it happens often, although the games are short so it isn't a huge deal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rating based on 1 play during CanCon 2015 (Canberra Australia)

I can see how appealing this game can be, especially to a general audience. Has a nice mix of luck, actions and simple play mechanics. However it is mostly just a an exercise in push your luck. Continual rolling of dice and not getting what you are after can get repetitive and boring. This is not the game for me but can see more potential with the right group of people aiming to have some social fun. Would recommend to non-gamers and younger age groups (greater appeal to younger ages although can be enjoyed by all ages). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played this a couple of times over the past summer at a meetup and liked it enough to buy it...my friends at school didn't like it as much.

I liked this game's Yahtzee like mechanic and its theme of monsters and effects.

I dislike Wings, Jets, and the sometimes freak rolls which swung the game wildly. I also realized that I hate the player elimination (thought I was okay with this, but 10 minutes is too long for a player to be out, and player elimination is only okay if there's other games going on/people need to leave/do stuff). I think Player Elimination is okay in extremely short sub-10-minutes games but not even okay for 15 minutes in my opinion.

That said, its still a lot of fun with the right crowd who takes it for what it is: a dice chucking party-esque game. There was a neat variant on the forums too of giving every player a starting random item and extra energy to compensate the ones who got bad items. I think that's probably worth a try too.

Overall nice idea for a game, but player elimination and heavy party nature hurts it a bit.

Plays: 5-10+

RATING: 8
This is a great game to finish a night of board gaming. I am not a fan of player elimination but this game is goofy and quick enough that I don't mind it and fits perfectly for the end of a night. I particularly enjoy the light and goofy theme. The rules are easy to explain. This game is best played with a loud group who enjoys taunting and trash talking.

I would recommend this game to anybody who enjoys light party games and does not mind player elimination. Avoid this game if you do not like conflict.

RATING: 9
Simply put: a great game!

The artwork is evocative and fun. The dice are easy to read. The cards are effective, colourful and simple to understand. And the player interaction is very high.

Don't let the theme or style of this game keep you away, like it did me. Once we cracked it open and gave it a few plays we all loved it.

Two negatives in my book however:
1. The dice are way larger than they need to be. Younger kids may have trouble picking up and rolling.
2. The components are not super robust. You'll need to be a little careful with the monster boards.

RATING: 5
Become the King of Tokyo and get attacked by every other player, back out of Tokyo and attack whomever is in Tokyo.  Roll certain bonuses to add card abilities to your character.  Win by eliminating everyone, who scoring 10 points by conquering Tokyo.

Yes, it is a dice rolling fest.  Yes, there is player elimination.  Yes, it can go a tad too long.  Yes, even playing perfectly and making excellent decisions there is a big chance you will lose.  Yes, I will play again.

RATING: 7
I was so very excited for this game, and when it came I must have played it 8 times in a row with my girlfriend who loved it. I really enjoy this as a two player game. It's quick and fun with enough depth that you don't grow weary of it. The cards can make some truly awesome combinations and just up the strategy enough to make me WANT to play my next turn.

Still, it's not all sunshine for me. I have really had trouble playing with more than two players. The game just feels so slow compared to the blistering pace you can set with two people. It's more chaotic and unpredictable which is a good thing for this game, but at the moment, 4 players adds too much time for me to get excited for a game. 3 people was a decent mix but still not the same feeling I got with just 2.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
King of Tokyo is a nice mix of mechanics and a strong theme based on Kojiro films better known as Godzilla.  It's extremely easy to learn and has a common side effect of: new players seem to win more often than not.

I own this game and out of countless play throughs I have only won once, but always come back for more.  My little brothers (ages 14 and 16) as well as my mother play this game with no issue and they absolutely love it.

GAMEPLAY: The game revolves around 6 dice, a simple playmat called Tokyo, and the player's avatar/player-cards.  The 6 dice have 6 unique sides (1, 2, 3, energy, fight, and heal).  The Tokyo playmat shows whose in Tokyo.  And the Avatar is the fun aesthetic representing who is who, the play-card tracks Victory Points and your avatar's Health.  The game is divided into each player taking turns, one after the other.

When it's your turn you roll the 6 dice, choose to keep any or none and reroll.  This process is repeated till there has been a total of 3 rolls or all dice are kept.  If you get to the third roll then you must keep all dice.

Energy is spent on buying cards revealed and each card has some sort of benefit to yourself and often hinders other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
King of Tokyo is fun, and the kids love it, but for me it's on the edge of being too complicated for a dice game. I do kind of dig the king-of-the-hill feeling the damage mechanism employs. It only works well with larger numbers though, and then you end up with greater downtime. Downtime in dice games kinda sucks. The game would probably be better if you just got one roll and that was it. On the other hand, it is lavishly over-produced for what it is!

RATING: 8
A great, light, easy and fun filler that I really like to play in "bigger" groups. 2 people is fine, but not optimal (we made a house rule for 2 players that works quiet nicely without changing much: entering Tokyo does not give a point and being there on your turn does only give 1 but not two. This nicely balances that Tokyo is not that dangerous)
As it's easy to explain also to new people, it's just one of the most fun fillers for us. So for what it should be, it's really a great one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Toys. Fantastic bits, cool new dice... it's a simple game, but looks so good I almost bought a copy. The players control giant monsters that battle to live in Tokyo. Roll dice, score hits on one another, heal, gain special powers, and/or score points. King of Tokyo takes about five minutes per player, and would be perfect for teenagers. It was very good for our group of tired thirty- and forty-somethings.

Players roll their dice, then can elect to re-roll some or all of them twice. After three rolls they must accept what they have. This removes the all-or-nothing aspect of many similar games, and adds a little strategy (i.e. do I try to collect points this turn, or attack the other players? Silly question: kill, kill, kill!). You win by reaching 20 points, or being the last one standing.

The theme is great- wiping-out Aneirin's hitpoints is more interesting than stealing a high value worm from her. KoT is more fun than Can't Stop, but really only a step removed. Zombie Dice and Martian Dice are not as cool, but they take up less space.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
King Of Tokyo est un jeu familial +. J'aurai tendance même à dire familial tout court, ça reste un peu entre 2.
Il est très largement accessible de par ses règles simples et claires. Le fun est de la partie.
Malgré son format, je trouve que c'est un bon filler dans le sens où il est toujours bien de se faire une partie plus fun où on va se taper dessus, se venger, après un jeu plus sérieux.
Le jeu est vraiment différent à partir de 5 joueurs où on utilise la 2ième partie du plateau. C'est beaucoup plus fun dans cette configuration.
King Of Tokyo est un nouveau classique incontournable accessible à tous.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game probably hits the table more often than any game I own. A quick, rough, and surprisingly elegant dice throwdown. The rules are very simple, (think Yahtzee, but with Godzilla) but manages to never feel facile. The ability to buy powers adds a layer of depth and personality that many dice-fest games just can't equal. There is certainly a random element to the game, but it always feels like a controlled random, if that makes any sense at all. This one is a personal favorite, and very popular amongst board gamers and non-gamer alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun, fun dice game of battling giant monsters!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]King of Tokyo[/b] was sold via auction 6/15/15

[i]Quick update:

After a few years of owning this and many plays it has left our collection. We've grown to like other dice fillers more (games like Qwixx and Qwinto).

- Great, thematic art and some of the most amazing dice we have.
- This game is just fun, you can't help but smile and laugh when you play this. 
- Great gateway game that we have had great success introducing other families to. 
- Might be the easiest game to teach that I own... Roll claws!
- The cards add some fun twists to the game and are worth collecting energy for. That said, I only roll for claws and very rarely leave Tokyo.[/i]

[i]Favorite KoT moment: winning the [thing=144606][/thing] at a Tabletop Day event at the Adams Memorial Library for my daughter. She was so excited and this will be a cool keepsake reminding her of our day spent gaming together![/i]

RATING: 9
100517
Played 2 games with 6 year old today. Came across a few issues regarding whether a monster can leave Tokyo of his own free will. He was adamant in healing himself even though he had a substantial amount of life left and so I let him do so even though I didn't need to attack him. He still doesn't understand the concept of the monster outside of Tokyo having to focus on damaging the one inside to minimize the decision to stay on for free victory points. I still see the beauty in the game though in the dual ways to win depending on the roll of the die, where your monster is relative to the other and the cards displayed. 

Freaking fun! Player elimination not a major issue here due to the speed at which it plays. And the cards add so much variation to the game too!

RATING: 7
Just plain fun

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Excellent game for 2 to 6 players. It has great replay ability. For example, we have played a few 6 player games and only went through about 10 cards of the deck...there are way more cards that are as of yet untapped. This game is almost a party game in the sense that new gamers can sit down and take it all in as they play. And the game length keeps them involved but ends soon enough for them not to get too board. 

Excellent theme, components and rulebook. One of the best mechanics of the game is when everyone not in Tokyo can hit the monster in Tokyo, and of course, the Monster(s) in Tokyo hit everyone outside of Tokyo. This really keeps the game active and moving.

RATING: 9.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lots of fun with a beautiful theme which helps bring what's really nothing but a dice game to life. A turn is simply rolling 6 dice with 2 re-rolls. Dice can give you VP's (if you get a set of 1's, 2's or 3's), can inflict damage on players not in your location (you're either in Tokyo trying to earn points if you can hang in there until the start of your next turn, or your outside Tokyo whaling on those in Tokyo trying to earn points), heal thyself, or earn cubey things, enough of which will allow you a genetic modification which will enhance your status or capabilities (there's cards in the display). So, go for what you want, re-roll away, whale away, heal thyself, buy good stuff, earn VPs. Die last or get to 20VPs first. Turns are fast. It's a fun decision whether to keep or re-roll damage if it's going in on Tokyo as it's a double-edged sword - they're allowed to move out if they get damage and that forces you in ... at least until you cop it next and you'll be faced with the decision on should you stay or should go ('cause if you go there will be trouble, but if you stay it will be double). So the game is one of trying to stay alive, be on the righteous side of where the damage is going as much as possible and accumulate those VPs as you go. Easy to learn, easy to play, easy to laugh, great components. Good result.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A quick, solid game that's easy to learn and provides some variety.  You assume the role of a giant monster and start smashing (rolling dice).  The dice pretty much determine what you do so you won't like the game if you're not into random dice effects.  The different power-ups provide enough variety so things don't get repetitive.  If I were going to get kids into the gaming hobby, I would start with this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Ultra fun game, not to be taken too seriously, works better with a little banter and monster talk. I really love the fact you can go the victory points or last man standing to be crowned King of Tokyo. The cards are cool, I love the variety and the artwork. Just really a neat all round game that plays fast, furious & fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
KING FUN!! This is the KING of all of the yahtzee-reroll-mechanic dice games out there. Lots of luck in this cool fun dice game about giant monsters playing KING of the Hill in Tokyo.  Try to find the strategy and tactics to win, only to be smacked down by a giant cyber bunny. Kids love this. Best with 3 or more players, though some fun 2 player variants are very good. I'm really liKING this, when initially I expected to think it would be a mediocre game just for kids.

Family Game. Church group game. Beer-and-Pretzels Game. Casual Game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
"Way too long for what it is (my shortest games have been 35 minutes), especially with player elimination. It's not as easy to learn as some people think (thanks to the sometimes-tricky cards). I don't like attack-y games anyway, but at 15 minutes this might get a 5 or 6 rating from me."

What I liked:
- Cool dice and energy cubes.
- Despite the randomness, there are some decisions to make, both tactical and strategic.

What I didn't like:
- At 35-60 minutes, it is TOO LONG! 15-20 minutes would be much better.
- Player elimination. I have seen multiple players get eliminated 15 minutes in to a 60 minute game.
- The whole game is about attacking each other.
- Being forced into Tokyo when you didn't want to go.
- Complicated special abilities prevent it from being a great gateway game.

More than half the times I have played or watched, the game has dragged out to 45-60 minutes. That's just way too long, especially with player elimination. 

I think the weight is about 2.0, not the 1.5 currently voted by BGG members.

RATING: 6.5
Very fun little game. Fast and ferocious dice-fun! A great filler with good components! Hope to play this many more times. I dislike it with 6 players. Drags on too much. 4 players is best.

This game needs the first expansion.

I might actually for the first time ever go for a house-rule to have players draft some start-up powers just to make it a but more fun...

Thoughts for initial drafting. Players obtain 5 cards each and draft up to a total value of 10 energy. Players may chose Keepers as well as instant cards that are played before game starts. This might give some players a heads start in VP and powers, etc. must try

RATING: 8
Fun, light dice game that everyone enjoys. Great use of the Yahtzee mechanism combined with some take-that and character building. Player elimination can sometimes knock people out too early but it is never as bad as something like Bang.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Love it. Straitforward even for non gamers. Fun dice rolling action, enough decision making, stylish (the small board of the game is an excellent idea).

Its great power is its simplicity and fast gameplay.

Be warned though. In my opinion King of Tokyo is useless as a 2 player game. It doesn’t let you breath. In a situation of 2 players I use two  monsters for each player and forbid monsters of the same player to switch places in and out of Tokyo. 

I think I prefer playing with 4 players.

(Wife's Point of View: She hates strategy and complicated games. That said, she always likes King of Tokyo. Unfortunatelly as a 2 players game it's awful)

RATING: 6.5
My first play was with only three players and I would not recommend it at that number of players. My second was with four players and recently played at six and it is much more interesting as trying to remain in Tokyo is much tougher, since the player in Tokyo (a source of points) gets attacked a lot between turns and the player in Tokyo rotates more. At three I found that although fun at first (more funny then fun) it got old fast. At four or more and with players who are not too fixed on strategy, it is fun and fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
What a boring game. Players take on the roll of monsters and use dice to attack other monsters, heal, and buy cards that have a wide variety of effects. The problem is that that the game is terrible with 2 players but then with 4 or more the game can easily drag way longer than it should and downtime between turns becomes intolerable for a game of this weight. On top of all this, many of the cards are too weird and convoluted for their own good. Gamers can figure them out, but if you are playing with family or casual folk, you are going to get a lot of blank stares when you read the cards to them. So if you have to stop and attempt to explain every other card multiple times until everyone gets it, the game will drag even more.  If you want a game where everyone can act silly and attack each other, get Cash n Guns instead as it is a far superior game.

RATING: 6

The rules are simple to understand for new players but the addition of a deck of special action cards gives experienced players scope for devious tactics and strategies. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a monster brawl game in which you try to be the first player with a given number of points (and not die in the process).  You can either be in Tokyo, where you gain points every turn, dish out major damage to everyone simultaneously, but can't heal, or you're not in Tokyo, where you can only hurt the Tokyo monster and don't gain points, but can heal.  The core of the game is a Yahtzee mechanic--you reroll dice a bunch of times until you get what you want.  You can accumulate money to buy upgrade cards, but the game is so short that you don't really get too much into that.  Other than the pictures, the monsters are all the same.  The game is an okay filler.

(3 plays)

2 - bardzo słabo, praktycznie mechanika przebywania w Tokyo jest bez znaczenia
3,4 fajnie
5 - fajnie, pojawiają się w Tokyo 2 potwory, a po eliminacji pierwszych graczy, gra nie trwa na tyle długo żeby zabici się wynudzili
6 - dla pierwszych wyeliminowanych graczy jest to mordęga, bo tylko patrzą przez 20 minut i nic nie robią, słabe.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players control monsters ravaging the city of Tokyo. The monsters outside the city will attack the one inside. The guy inside will attack everyone outside, but can't heal unless it uses a special power. 

All of this is done through dice rolling a la yahtzee, with two re-rolls allowed. The dice have special symbols: a hand allows a monster to deal damage, a heart allows it to gain one health point (if the monster's outside the city), a lightning is worth one energy token (used to buy cards) and the numbers score points. If a monster's killed the player is out of the game. The first guy to reach 20 points, or the last monster standing is the winner. 

So, why is this great? 

Because it's so damn clever! The inside/outside Tokyo dynamic works very well, the cards add just the right amount of rule twisting and the the dice the indispensable randomness. There are two opposing paths to victory - points or last man standing - which demand very different approaches and, let's not be afraid of the words, strategies. 

And it's fun! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Besitzer: Kenny

RATING: 4
Didn't much like this one. The artwork and bits are fantastic. The yahtzee mechanic is what it is.

The main problems is player elimination. Our group, instead of ganging up on the leader, predominantly sought to eliminate the weak as fast as possible. So some people are knocked out very early and go play something else.

The game didn't quite capture the King of the Mountain feel it is going for, nor the Godzilla defends Tokyo heavyweight title bought a la Rocky vs Klubba Lang/Apollo Creed/Ivan Drago feel it is trying to capture.

They can maybe figure it out with a later implementation, but this one is a swing and a miss.

RATING: N/A
+ Halloween
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
It's just "King of the Hill" using special dice and some special action cards to try to roll your way to occupying the "Tokyo" spot on the very small gameboard.  If you like dice-fests where you try to wipe out your opponents this is a game for you.  It has some imaginative aspects: you roll 6 dice once and 0-6 dice two more times after that on your turn trying to get the best combination.  The dice have numbers and symbols on them: the numbers get you victory points (20 wins the game) and the symbols allow you to attack your opponents or add energy and health (recovery from battle wounds).  Last one standing or first to get 20 Victory Points is the winner.  There are also 3 face-up cards from a deck of several dozen that provide special powers, points and favors.  There is a small gameboard that is not used for anything except to show which player controls Tokyo at the moment.  Lucky rolls make a difference but the decisions you make about which dice to keep or re-roll play a big part in the game's outcome.  

A good game -- if you like dice-fests -- which I don't.   If you get tired of this dice-fest apparently there are expansion games that will offer additional variety to the play.

RATING: 8
[b]Note: The 2016 Second Edition looks horrible, get the original while you can - they removed the Kraken for a lame Penguin.[/b]

Sometimes the hype is justified - quick and easy to pick up but tons of fun to play. 

Pros:
* Easy to learn.
* Great theme - who does not like large monsters?
* Re-roll mechanic works great for this game.
* Quality components - player cards with dials are elegant.
* Well balanced - makes all gamers equal.

Cons:
* Some power cards are fairly useless.
* Strategy is limited but still there.

RATING: N/A
House rules:
- 5 cards available for purchase
- max 3 keep cards per player
- 1 vp, 1 hp and 1 energy for entering Tokyo
- starting in Tokyo for a whole round gives vp equal to the number of players
- 3 vp for killing a monster
- no elimination - at 0 hp discard all cards; at the beginning of your next turn heal to max hp; take 1 wound: decrease the number of rolled dice by 1 per each wound

RATING: 7
Garfield does yahtzee, and he does it well. Excellent filler! Most light filler games involve playing cards, but there's just something special about grabbing a handful of dice, rolling, and seeing what comes up. There's a hint of tactics and choices, but the dice determine pretty much everything. And surprisingly, that's ok. The theme makes it potentially less suitable for playing with my family, but it also makes it so much fun that I can see this getting a ton of play as a closer on game nights.

RATING: 9
Most of the games in the Yahtzee family fail. Yes they are variants but so many are so dull (the Settlers dice game is a perfect example). The two best, to date are Roll Through the Ages and King of Tokyo. Where King of Tokyo surpasses RTtA is in the fun factor. Both play quickly but RTtA is too 'serious' while KoT takes the mechanics and adds fun. Is it a great game...no. However it is short, easy to teach and fun. King of Tokyo reminds me of the final battle in Monsters Menace (Ravage) America. However, it skips the foreplay and goes right to the.... What else do you want?

RATING: 8

At heart, it’s just another Yahtzee-style dice-roller, but the dice combinations aren’t very interesting and the decisions seem mostly obvious. A lot of the fun comes from the Alien Frontiers-style special power cards. Needs to be played fast and furious - it’s not a strategy game and ponderous play would be particularly annoying if you got eliminated early.

UPDATE: not sure what I was talking about here. It's expertly designed for the type of experience it wants to create.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
On paper this ought to be a really fun game; it's quick, simple, has oodles of player interaction and at least two paths to victory. However there are a couple of serious flaws. The first is the dependence on player elimination, which might not seem to matter given the quick playing time. But the second is variable playing time: Certain cards (like the one that gives -5 VP to everyone) can really slow the game down - so you could be sitting out for 45 minutes or more in rare cases.

RATING: 7.5
Very good filler! Simple but functional mechanics and fun theme. Yes, it's a dice game and the luck factor is high, but players may direct their (simple) strategy. Playing time is short and more than one game are easily playable during a play session.
It's a pity the monsters result all identical; I would have appreciated a personal, unique ability for each of them.
Components are good.. except for the dice: why they're not carved...? They are the game-core after all...
Energy cubes are great! Rubbery miniatures would have been better than paper stands - but that's just a finesse.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Maybe you have some non-gamer friends. Maybe they have no interest in playing games whatsoever. Maybe you haven't been able to play games with them because you know they'd think board games are lame.

King of Tokyo is the game you want to show them. You tell them it's a game about smashing each other, you explain the rules in two minutes, and you start playing.

And it will be awesome, 100% guaranteed.

I've never played a game that delivers what it promises as consistently as King of Tokyo. Yeah, it's filler. But it's filler that lets you pursue different strategies, has a lot of direct player interaction, and has enough variety to play several games in a single night and never be bored.

There's a lot to like about this game, but the best thing is that it's simple enough to be played (and enjoyed!) by almost anyone while still complex enough to provide all but the most complexity-craving experts with interesting decisions. The second best thing (or best, depending on your viewpoint) is that it's short (30 mins max). This makes the player elimination less of a problem.

[EDIT: I played this with a different group and it was not short. They took foreeeeeeeeever. It made te game way less fun...you really need to keep the game moving for this one to work]

King of Tokyo is a great game that can appeal to a very wide range of players. I absolutely recommend trying this no matter what type of player you are, and that's not something I can say for very many games.

#3 on personal list "Top 10 games for a new gamer to own"

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Very pleasant game of meaningful dice rolling. Well designed and produced, doesn't play too long. Player round is very quick, as it's just couple of rolls, resolve and then pass to the next player. Obviously it's also very random, so if you don't like dice, it's not for you.

To me, it's Quarriors simplified. I love Quarriors, but I feel that you have more decisions there to make and it can get quite deep, despite dice roll. Here, it's simple, easy and if you can't get Quarriors to table, or just want a quick entry level game for kids, this one is definitely a hit. But it cannot match the stream of Quarriors dice rattling in a bag :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Reduced rating from 8.5 to 7.5 because the base rules really lead to an uninspired game play where whoever rolls 3's wins. I'd raise it to 8.5 or perhaps 9 if I could figure out the right combination of house-rules to improve the game.

(original comment) Just a lot of dice-rolling fun.  The theme goes a LONG way with me, and the short time making the inevitable vagaracies of luck more bearable.

Only problem with the rules to me was the lack of victory points for staying in Tokyo 1 whole turn. 2 measly VPs for surviving that many attacks (in larger player games) is not nearly enough motivation to suffer so much risk.

After thinking about it, I want to try the number of VP's = # of players still in the game
For example, if there's 2 players, it's 2 VPs.
4 players, 4 VP's for starting the turn in Tokyo.
And for 6 players, it's 6 VP.
Yes, this sounds overpowering. However, I strongly feel the game should be decided by whoever conquers Tokyo the most/longest, AND even 6 VP's is not that much compared to "3" rolls and cards, AND you have to take your lumps and stay in Tokyo all the way to your next turn. It should give motivation to the players to beat the crap out of the ballsy monster in the city. In a 6-player game, a monster would have to stay in Tokyo till their 5th straight turn to win!

Other possible house rules:
Nobody is going to use 3 1's to score one measly VP unless they are the last dice to come up. 
All 1's should be Energy. Energy is the entire currency which is required to make the game more than just a dice-throwing luck-fest. There needs to be more energy available to the players, and eliminating the 1 and making it an Energy seems an easy way to do that.

Oh - house rule #3 : 
All players start with 3 Energy. Gets the action and choices happening faster.

Other potential house rules:
a) Use 5 face-up cards instead of 3 (or maybe 1 per player?)
b) Wings may be overpowered - remove the card from the game
c) At beginning of game, draw 5 cards and keep up to 7 Energy's worth of cards  OR  Everyone starts with 1 Keep card and gets Energy equal to the difference between their card and the highest player's card.
d) Cards may be bought before you roll dice.
e) A rolled Energy is worth 2 Energy cubes, not 1.
(not actively considering the following) f) Every opponent's turn you are in Tokyo, you get 1 Energy.
g) When in Tokyo, after resolving dice, you get 1 free wipe of the cards, if desired.

RATING: 8
I was pleasantly surprised by this game. Usually, Richard Garfield's non-ccg games aren't very successful with me, but this dice filler with its fun kaiju theme, and well produced bits won me over. The pacing of the game seems like it could be a little better, in terms of acquiring variable powers via the cards and having those powers effect the game, but on the plus side this plays pretty quickly, which is a must for a game ultimately this light. I've had a lot of success introducing non-hobby gamers to this game. 

However. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that sometimes the game can drag if players aren't having any luck eliminating each other and some of the more "take that" cards, which set players back, get bought and played. But more often than not, the game plays quickly and is good for a few laughs. This has become one of my go to games to break out to play with people who aren't dedicated hobby game enthusiasts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fun game, easy to teach, and kids can play.  My 5 year old was able to learn and play this game.  Mechanics are very simple.  The game play essentially involves rolling 6 dice, choosing which ones you want to keep, and rolling again.  You may then once again choose which dice to keep, and make one last roll for the dice you don't want to keep.  The strategy is in deciding which dice to keep, and deciding how long you want to stay in Tokyo.  Otherwise, the game is very luck based.

The only thing I don't like about this game is that if you get killed early, you may have to wait around a while before the game ends.  Thankfully, the game time isn't too long, so it's not that big of a problem.  Additionally, 5-6 player games aren't as fun as 3-4 player games, in my opinion, because of the longer down time before your next turn.

In summary, it's a nice simple game, that is good for families.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A shame about the player elimination - I think any game that includes that element is likely to lose a point from me.

RATING: 7
I still can't believe how fun this game is. Maybe it's the cartoonish monsters or the cool dice or even the ability to pull a buddy into Tokyo to feel the wrath of everyone else, but King of Tokyo seems to be a winner with gamers and casuals alike. The goal is simple: either destroy all other monsters or get 20 victory points. Getting to either goal is not hard to understand, but for some reason people's strategies crash in flames in every game in which I've played. It's not the randomness of the dice rolls that does it (you get two re-rolls after the first roll), but it's one inflexibility to accept what one rolls that often rings the death knell of the hapless player.

RATING: 8.5
pros :

1)Quick playtime makes it easy to get several games in.
2)Artwork is very pleasing to the eye and fits the theme well.
3)King of the hill mechanic also blends well with theme.
4)I like the "purchasing" of powers with the cards.
5)High fun factor especially if players "get into" their roles.

Cons:
1)Quick playtime maybe a bit too quick?  I would like a little more time to get powers to differentiate the creatures more.  Perhaps a variant to start with a power?  
2)can get eliminated quickly if dice decide to hose you, but at least you won't have to wait too long for another go.

Looking forward to getting the power up expansion.

RATING: 8.67
Great game.  Quick, engaging, fun.   Surprisingly satisfying to add characteristics to your monster via the cards.

It uses the Yahtzee mechanism.  Roll the dice 3 times (keeping what you like each time).  the dice allow you to attack other monsters, heal yourself, score victory points, or store up energy so you can buy special powers (cards) later.

Key question:  How long can I stay in Tokyo without getting killed??

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Those who say the game is like Yatzee are ignoring the king of the hill elements of the game.  

This is a clever design which gets a lot of fun out of a very small rule set.  However if people are determined to roll for hearts (until they are at maximum health) the game play is duller and slower.  But this sort of turtling is punished (an aggressive monster in the center will demolish them).  The game is more fun when people take risks, roar, and make sound effects, cackle etc.

Surprisingly, this game does not have the feel of 'gang up on the leader'.  If you are in the center everyone gangs up on you, but you CHOSE to be there and can leave promptly if you want to.  (This paragraph is a bit over simplified.)  Still, it has a more fun dynamic than most games where everyone hoses the leader because in this game the leader decides their self to step into the line of fire.

The game might play out, but for now, (2 plays), I am eager to try it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 9
My favourite dice rolling game with an engaging theme, nice comic art work and really chunky dice! Still there are some decisions: play defensively or offensively; try to reach 20 points this turn, but be vulnarable if you fail... 

Some plays might get a bit stale if you really have bad luck or get eliminated quickly. But since the play time is not that long, you can easily do another game. In total, still my most favourite game to play after a long and brain-burny Euro game (but usually with Power Up! expansion). Without  the Power Up! expansion I would only rate it an 8 (even maybe 7.5). The expansion adds very little, but this can still make quite a difference in such light game.

This is a simple dice game.Monsters in Tokyo attack monsters outside and vice-versa. The monsters in Tokyo score victory points but cannot regain life points. Players can win by scoring twenty victory points or by killing all the other monsters.

RATING: 7
Dice-based monster combat, with different ways to win (do you try to kill everyone else, or stay out of trouble while acquiring victory points?), and a pretty large deck of purchasable cards with special powers, meaning no two games will ever be quite the same. This is great fun if one is in the mood and doesn't feel like anything too heavy. And the expansion makes it even better by introducing extra abilities which are unique to each monster. Indeed, I would now say that the expansion is essential to the game, in the sense that I never want to play without it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
For ages 8 and up, and I suggest that you bring an 8 year old so that at least one of you enjoys it.

OK, it's a "fun" game.  It's not meant to be serious or deep.  You can ham it up, stomp on opponents' cards, make your own fun.

But the mechanism is deeply flawed - it's just far too random.  You can't pick a strategy, you can only go with whatever dice you rolled, sometimes to your detriment.

Holding or ceding Toyko is too gross a decision, and often doesn't make that much of a difference anyway. You don't have any choice about moving in, and you need to take at least one bout of clawing before you can bail out, which can be fatal.

The cards are a real mess, and there are too many of them to be able to base any sort of strategy around them.  There are a couple that can be useful if you're lucky enough to roll a bunch of energy very early on when they're showing, but again that's a pure luck gambit.

Two or three player games are just a claw-fest, four or more players turns into a race for points while desperately trying to avoid becoming the temporary occupier of Tokyo, a curious conceit considering the theme of the game.

In brief:

To complicated to play drunk, too pointless to play sober.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The general consensus is that King of Tokyo is not a very good 2 player game. I disagree. Sure it may be more fun with more than two, but 2 is very fun. The only rule change I suggest is that players still receive 2 coins when they start their turn in Tokyo, but do not receive the 1 coin for entering Tokyo. Love the chunky dice. Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's very fun especially if you get into the role of monsters smacking each other for control of Tokyo. Rules are straightforward and simple, making it very easy to learn.

It heavily involves dice rolling, so it's pretty luck-based; however, since it runs quick, it doesn't make it irritating if you are getting bad rolls or if your opponent is getting particularly good rolls - just wait out until the game finishes.

There is still some strategy (when to leave Tokyo, should I try to get 20 points or just smack everyone around, etc), though it is not as deep as other games.

The biggest point of contention, aside from the luck factor, is the presence of player elimination. While the game usually runs quick, eliminated players still have to wait quite a while to play again either because of getting eliminated too early or if the rest of the players are using "turtle" strategies. Nonetheless, eliminated players can still have fun while watching. 

Another possible gripe is there are some games wherein you can't really do much given an early multi-claw roll from your opponents, leaving you the rest of the game trying to roll for hearts. There are also dead turns, where you are having bad rolls wherein you can't do anything for that turn. The game is quite short, though, so these things aren't as bad as they seem.

It's a great game to play when one doesn't want to burn their brain cells and have fun. I would play this given the chance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good fun in a simple, push-your-luck dice game.  The big stack of special power cards is what makes this fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A build'em (victory points) bash'em (hit points) type of game.  Keep it light and the game is much more enjoyable.  Stop to think to hard and the game can slow to a crawl.  As player's start with nothing - there is bit of a decision - start to be aggressive early before defenses can be built up, or build up energy (and then cards) before attempting to be more confrontational.  Of course, rolling a hand forces one into Tokyo when it is empty, so not much one can do other than respond to the dice you do get.  Don't over think this one...take it lightly as a filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good, not great, pick up and play game.  It's not much fun with 2 players at all, but it does get more interesting with 3-4 people playing.  

There's more strategy involved than one might think at first glance.  Gameplay moves quickly, and most games end within half an hour at most.  Not my favorite, but you could do worse.

RATING: 7.75
Each player takes the role of a giant monster who starts with ten points of health and zero victory points. Either be the first monster to reach 20 points or eliminate every other opponent to win the game. The gameplay is simple as players roll six dice up to three times (like yahtzee) and apply the effects to the appropriate monsters. Fun? Heck, yeah! Lots of tabletalk and social interaction for all the players involved. This game should be a part of everyone's collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I didn't want to give this game as high a rating at first, because I'm not as much into luck-based games, but all my kids love it, which makes me love it more. There's a bit of strategy in so much as there's strategy in Yahtzee, because the dice are rolled and re-rolled in a similar manner. It's really clever, and the pieces are very colorful and creatively designed. There's a large element of luck with dice rolling and card drawing, which means the young kids have a more even chance of beating the older kids and grown-ups. It also has the advantage of being a short game, so you can play it a few times in a row if you want. For example, Kid: "Let's go again!", Parent: "I'd love to, but it's almost midnight."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
The game plays quickly and the duration is good—usually playing more than one game in a sitting. If a player gets eliminated, they don't have to wait long for the next game. Downtime is pretty short, giving just enough time to think about what you would like to do next turn. Non-active players get attacked during another person's turn, giving them something to do during the downtime. 

The downside to short games is that there's not enough time to use many of the power-up cards, however I wouldn't want the game to last much longer than it does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
Two Player Value = Fair. Good game, just better with more players.


King of Tokyo is a simple dice game turned into a free-for-all brawl. It is silly and light. Nothing fancy or complicated.

In King of Tokyo players fight to victory. There are two methods of victory, the first to 20 points or eliminating all other players. Easy.

The whole game revolves around the dice roll. On your turn you get 3 rolls to build the best "hand" of dice. Then you use those dice to effect the game. You can attacks other players, heal yourself, score points or buy powerful cards to help you are hurt others. Players can also score points by controlling Tokyo.

The design is simple and efficient. The game is very basic, but it is meant to be. That is what makes it fun. It is supposed to be silly and light party game.

Everything else is fine, but not incredible. Rules. Artwork. Components. Theme. 

This game is very good with younger and new gamers.


Pros - 
- Easy to teach and learn
- Good party game


Cons - 
- Very simple game play could turn some away


Overall Playability = 6.9

Design = 7 
Strategy = 7
Luck = 6
Artwork & Components = 6
Use of Mechanics = 8
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 7
Innovation = 5
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 7


[b]------------------------------------------------------[/b]


The first expansion for King of Tokyo is [thing=127067][/thing].

This is a small and simple expansion, but it offers a good game play boost.

This expansion provides a small deck of cards for each character that gives the characters new powerful abilities.  Players can buy these power cards with dice.

I like the added game play mechanic and it really helps round out the game.

Because of this it will raise the overall rating of the game slightly.


Overall Playability = 7.1

Design = 8 
Strategy = 7
Luck = 6
Artwork & Components = 6
Use of Mechanics = 8
Time of Play = 8
Fun = 7
Innovation = 6
Analysis Paralysis = 8
Theme = 7

RATING: 10
I could comment on the almost flawless design that embraces fun and interaction over all else. I could praise the terrific production, with it's excellent illustrations and components.

But instead I can only say that King of Tokyo is perhaps the best light game I've ever played. It's so effortless, so intuitive, and so direct that I have trouble thinking of any short game that has ever accomplished those things better. This is more than a filler: this is the best game from 2011.

RATING: 8
I personally don't love this game. It's over before you get the most out of your powers, it's kinda swingy, and player elimination sucks.

But you have to know its audience. This is a gateway game -- perhaps the BEST gateway game -- for people who are used to rolling dice. I've never had a bad game of it and that gives me a great deal of second-hand enjoyment. Just don't expect more out of it than it can offer.
