=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
RAAAAH! I always look at this on my shelf and say "what is that kids game doing there? I really should get rid of it, or put it in the kids' collection, so I can get a better game in there."

But then I play it...and right back on my collection shelf it goes. I've never not had fun here. Kudos, Garfield.

I'll say it again, just so you all know: THE STARS ARE HOW MANY BUILDINGS YOU"VE EATEN. I don't know why people get so confused, try to make it less thematic by calling it fame, or twitter followers or whatever. Even the rules get confused on this point! Foolishness. It's obvious, and makes the game better once you realize this. Try it.

Have no interest in playing King of New York. Why would I want to take a good 30 min whiz-bang silly fun game and make it longer and game-ier? If I want a more complex game I'll play wiz-war or Tammany Hall or something. This is perfect for what it is. I don't even use the evolution cards, though I have them. Appreciate the game for what it is, I say.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
King of Tokyo is a light fun and humorous game where you take control of a monster and give it special abilities to destroy more of Tokyo or destroy your fellow monsters quicker. It's relatively devoid of strategy and is very luck based due to dice-rolling. It's fairly short and the game changes with more players (with 5-6 there is an extra spot in the city to rampage). Worth playing with young kids or with older people looking for some filler fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
King of Tokyo is unbelievable fun. It's a spin on the Yacht roll-reroll-reroll-stop mechanism with power cards and (mostly) passive-aggressive player interaction. I think the passive-aggressive interaction is what makes this game. There's no politicking, "Why did you hit me?!", "Because you were in Tokyo, duh. Why were you in Tokyo??". Most often your attacks are directed at everyone else, or the player in Tokyo. Offering little decision about what to do with your attack power (only cards you buy allow decisions) keeps this game on track, it's a real lean game design that travels full speed as soon as someone takes Tokyo and never allows players the chance to even slow it down. Excellent, rock-solid design, I can't get enough of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
FUN... is one word I use to describe this to other people especially muggles who is a Virgin for board gaming. And if it's fun. It's a nice gateway game that never fails it's purpose. The one it lacks probably the value of replayabilty. Once you master it you probably want something more challenging. You may not play this repeatedly with your adult friends, but with your children this might be a house favorite. I personally will play this game only if I want a fun easy game on my game night and of course to lure other muggles to join my board gaming passion. It's like honey to Pooh bear. Sugar to ants. And blood to mosquitos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First and foremost to remember is this is filler, and probably better if you're drunk. Each player represents a monster getting victory points for destroying Tokyo while fending off other monsters who want to get into Tokyo to do the same. It's a dice rolling game: roll, hold any back, and reroll up to two more times. Roll energy to take energy cubes, which you can use to buy cards. These cards give you extra powers, or just annoy the hell out of everyone. Roll hearts to heal, but note that you can't heal while you're in Tokyo. Roll a set of three matching numbers to get victory points. Or roll a claw to attack the monster in Tokyo (or ALL other monsters if you're already in Tokyo). If you damage a monster in Tokyo they have the option to leave, and the attacker must then enter Tokyo. You get points for entering Tokyo, and points for staying in Tokyo a whole round. Win by reaching a number of victory points or by killing all the other monsters. Great fun in the right crowd, but strictly filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All Yahtzee-family games have been dry and boring. Not so with King of Tokyo, where the card upgrades provide an excellent shot in the arm. It also combats the "all faces of the die are good in their own way" syndrome by layering VPs and health on the game as trade-offs. The two objectives conflict through the decision on whether to man up in Tokyo, resulting in great dynamism in deciding what to go for with the dice.

This is the best '3-attempt' dice game by far, and it has brought the fun back to the retread genre.

It doesn't scale very well, however. All Yahtzee descendants play best with 2 or 3 intrinsically due to downtime, but with KoT, the lowered viability of being King in Tokyo with more players further deteriorates the game at higher player counts. It's reached the stage where nobody dares to go into Tokyo. Think about it: with 6 players, that's at least 5 turns of people whacking you, and at least 10 other-player turns before you get a chance to heal, if you want the 2 VP. I want to try the "Gain 1 energy at the start of each player turn while you're in Tokyo" variant if we play with 5 or 6.

[hr]
Nah, I think the player scaling is fine, just different. Live and adapt. It just raises the stakes for going into Tokyo, which all players then account for. Raised design from 4 to 5.

5+3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
bought summer, 2012

A solid filler game for gamers of all ages.  Truly a game that could fit in any collection.  The only "issue," as I see it, is the game mechanic reward of sitting in Tokyo.  Is there not enough incentive to stay in Tokyo?  Easily tweaked with house-rules, depending on how you feel about the issue.  Great fun, plays quick, would not turn a game down.

Update (November 2012):  having now played this with a couple different groups, I have to say that it really shines with older kids (8-13).  That's the group I want to play it with.  For adults (incl. non-gamers) it's still good filler, but I don't find it nearly as entertaining.  Downgrading to a 7 (from 8), since it's still a fun design - just not the knock-out I thought it might be.

RATING: 7
King of Tokyo -- 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow. Logic fails a bit in deducing why this game is as good as it is. 
1. It's attacking, but this attacking while simple has a balance to it and never turns into random bashing: you're either attacking monsters in Tokyo, or you're in Tokyo and risk getting beaten - but you can attack everybody outside. 
2. Another balance is between 2 goals - gathering VPs and attacking everyone else. I mostly ignore all the points and just make stupid sounds and try to kill everyone. 
3. THEME. With so little overhead (esentially the game is a bit of risk taking with a bit of yahtzee and special powers thrown in for chaos and amusing effects) the theme takes over and makes everyone behave stupidly. And all the time it balances on the border between party games and family type fillers. 

Masterpiece - both in terms of design and in  graphic direction.

RATING: 8
Filler de dados muy divertido, en el que los jugadores son monstruos tipo Godzilla y tendrán que aguantar el máximo tiempo posible en Tokio para ganar puntos... pero los demás jugadores intentarán eliminar al jugador que esté en Tokio y arrebatarle el sitio.
El juego es tipo Yatzee, pero mucho más divertido, pues a parte de los mamporros, hay multitud de cartas que le dán habilidades especiales a los monstruos.
En un principio, me pareció un juego muy caro para lo que trae, pero es lo merece, pues es uno de los juegos más divertidos y sencillos a los que he jugado en mucho tiempo. Muy recomendado para jugar 6 jugadores.

RATING: 3
KOT was the first game we bought when we started getting back into the hobby a few years ago (2013). It came highly recommended as a gateway game. As our tastes developed, however, the game lost much of its appeal. The only time it made it to the table was when I was volunteering during game night at a local library (younger kids enjoyed it); needless to say, we never played it any more, and we've come to the conclusion that we don't care much for games that focus exclusively on attacking the other player(s) (and especially at 2p, where every decision becomes entirely rote).

I don't regret owning it, per se. It's simply time to move on.

RATING: 7
Crazy dice game where each player takes on a stereotypical kaiju seeking either 20VP or to annihilate all others. There's little strategy to the game, although from my experience a defensive strategy at the start is preferable. The tactics, however, run deeper than it initially seems as attacking Tokyo can be a double-edged sword. Even after 5 games, I've miraculously never been able to end up in the final showdown. Plays best with 4, and my one 5 player game took an hour to complete. But everyone had fun, so they didn't notice the time anyway.

RATING: 7
Easy and fast
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
#65 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

Another classic gateway game. I should try introducing this one to my family at some point. The roll three times to try and get the best result is easy to pick up thanks to classic Yahtzee. Players try to be the first to collect a certain amount of points, which can be gained through die rolls and through occupying Tokyo. Staying in Tokyo is scary though as it makes you vulnerable to attacks from other players. If your health reaches zero, you're eliminated. I recommend playing with the Power Up expansion as it gives each monster their own unique deck of card abilities you can trigger throughout the game. We have the Halloween expansion as well, but I haven't played with it yet.

Acquired: Erik
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very simple game to teach non-gamers. This game features awesome chunky dice and just enough decisions to make it interesting for everyone at the table. I really enjoy the ability to re-roll twice before letting the dice take their effects.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fun, well-made Yahtzee variant with a monsters theme.

Players are monsters trying to be 'King of Tokyo' by scoring 20VPs or knocking all other monsters out. 6 dice are rolled with two re-rolls allowed. Players score VPs for rolling at least 3 of a kind of 1, 2 or 3 VPs. Other possible rolls include gaining life, energy cubes (used to buy effects cards) or attack.

In a neat twist, there's a Tokyo board where a monster (or two if you're playing it 5 or 6 players) can occupy. You can't heal in Tokyo but gain 1VP for entry and another 2VP each time you start on Tokyo.

The graphic design is very good and the game plays fast enough and scales well. Well done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Whenever I play we alter the rules just slightly; instead of taking one energy, take two when you roll the energy dice. We found that without this rule it got a little boring. By changing just this one thing the whole game dynamic is changed by people  buying cards frequently.

RATING: 5
Fell for the hype and got this at premium price.

I'm sure some uber geeks will be wetting themselves over this, but so far I've found it a bit pfft!!

I like a good dice roller, but the power up cards are not great... either not worth it or too powerful.

In the end we just tried rolling for numbers and avoided going to Tokyo so not to take a pummeling.

UPDATE: After a 4 player game. Everyone quite liked the idea, but again had issues with the cards, as hardly any were used before the game came to a sudden end. Thus still a bit of an anti-climax... 

2nd UPDATE: Just played a 6P with my mates 3 boys (Ages 8, 9 and 10), and they really enjoyed it. Thus this is where I feel the game belongs... more older child/teen group. Also game lasted nearly an hour (again mainly due to passive play), but at least a load of cards got used and did add to the enjoyment.

Despite this, for me, rating staying the same

RATING: 9
I can't find any great flaws with this game. It's short, funny, and can bring out the real monster in people (makes monster noises). It can be taught to almost anyone and can be fun for people new to board games as well as more advanced players. 

All of the monsters have the same stats, which I like, but the expansion does add unique abilities making each monster stand out.

Get this game.

RATING: 7
+ King of Tokyo: Power Up!

Fun, fast filler. When we have someone new to board games we invariably end up playing this, and then everyone wants to play this again.

I play with the draft variant from the BGG forums:

* All players draw five upgrade cards, then we draft those five cards. Take one, pass the rest, etc, usual draft. The cheapest card starts in play, and you can buy the other cards that you drafted (and no others) with energy as usual
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[2012-04-14]
Micsoda kivitelezés! Óriási szörnyek, hatalmas kockák, gyönyörű kártyák. Rögtön megvett a játék. Sima kockapóker megbolondítva vehető kártyákkal és tokyói tombolással. Szörnyeink egymást ütik, közben győzelmi pontokat szereznek. Tokyóban lenni előny, ha túl tudsz élni egy kőrt, de nagyon veszélyes. Ilyen körítés kell egy egyszerű mechanizmushoz és máris kellemes játék lesz belőle. Főleg gyerekeknek ajánlott, de felnőttekkel is mókás. Nagyon erős hatos.

[2013-02-02]
Emelek is a ponton, kiegyensúlyozott is. A kártyákkal is jól lehet kombózni és több út vezet a győzelemhez.

RATING: 9
I have to say that I was expecting this to be a pretty random dice-fest and while there is certainly a great deal of randomness to it, it is also a heck of a lot of fun. The artwork and short playing time definitely work to it's advantage. You are faced with surprisingly difficult decisions about what dice to try and reroll each turn and whether or not to push your luck and stay in Tokyo. I really enjoy this and hope to play it a bunch between longer games on most game nights in the near future.

RATING: 8
A true winner of a push-your-luck style game.  The art is fantastic, the mechanics are simple, and the cards thrown in really make it what it is.  Genius system that provides a party-type atmosphere and lots of trash talk.  That said, it can be riotously long for what it is, and it is quite devoid of strategy.  It is fun to play at times, at others I would pass it up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I got this for my friend as a Christmas/birthday gift and we played it at the end of our game night.  Learning the rules and playing a game with 3 took all of 30 minutes tops (and that's with all 3 learning the rules and playing for the first time).  Cutting out the need to read and learn the rules and you can easily get a game played in 20 minutes or less.

Yes, this does mean the game is simple but that doesn't make it mindless.  The rules are short, simple, and easy to learn but there's a good amount of game play and tactical thinking involved.  One of the players even said "this game is pretty simple...yet convoluted in a way" which describes it perfectly.  It's basically played like Yahtzee, you roll 6 dice (that you can re-roll any number of twice) to collect sets of symbols or numbers that attack the other players, heal yourself, collect energy to buy special ability cards, or get victory points.  The real meat of the game is in the tug-of-war and risk/reward battle for Tokyo and the special ability cards.

It's a pretty good game to play to fill 20-30 minutes and there are some decent decisions to be made in which special ability cards to purchase and when to leave Tokyo but there's not much more to it than that besides a themed version of Yahtzee.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the big buzzers at our game store, I find it only decently entertaining, some silly fun but it has a few icks that stop it from being the blast of fun everyone claims it is.
The monsters are great, the dice part is very Yahtzee like but that is ok. This game is luck based, the strategic decision of which dice to keep is mostly made by the game for you after all (when you need life points, you have to go for hearts etc.) 
What I disliked is that when you roll an attack on the third roll, you attack whoever is in Tokyo no matter if that is a good choice for you. Death in games is always a bit annoying since you only watch the rest of the game and who likes that. In co-ops the death might contribute to the group, here it only ends the game for you, a bit sad.
A good game to end the night on, I would play it if asked but not seek it out.

RATING: 3.5

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
You roll dice, pick what symbols you want to keep depending on the situation, and then re-roll the rest to hopefully get what you want. There is some strategy involved but also quite a bit of luck. It's like Yahtzee but less abstract and with a little more excitement. The rules are super simple and easy to explain to anyone. Ridiculously easy to open the box and be playing within 5 minutes, even with inexperienced players. Great fun for everyone including families and non-gamers. 10/10 for simplicity and replayability. 8/10 for simplicity (if you like things a little more complex) and luck factor. Always fun, though. Buy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Really fun game that my group and myself enjoy very much. We play it almost every time we meet for game night at least once or twice. 

I changed the rule of rolling for points that you need to have 4 of the same number to get the victory points. This was suggested here at BGG as a variation. If you roll let´s say four "3" you get 3 victory points. If you roll five "3", you get 3+1=4 victory points.

This houserule works well for us, since it encourages people to roll for damage/healing/energy more than just for points. Which is a type of KoT play that we all enjoy the most. More fighting, more buying powercards and everyone wants to get to Tokyo to get victory points or deal damage to the other monsters.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This kaiju fighting game allows you to play as a giant cyborg cat fighting an enormous penguin with freeze ray guns.  Is there more information I can give to sell this?  Yes, actually - it's well designed along with its kickass, over-the-top theme.  Richard Garfield of Magic: The Gathering and Android: Netrunner fame does a brilliant job here of keeping players constantly shifting between a lust for power and a healthy fear of being ganged up on by their bloodthirsty opponents.  Don't stay in Tokyo too long, kids!

RATING: 9
Very good dice rolling game.  It should appeal to both gamers and nongamers.  Manages the difficult task of marrying the theme with the mechanics very very well.  I cottoned onto this game early and I'm glad to see that it has raised in the rankings.  It is really very good.  It is a sort of superb family game, that is both readily accessible, appeals to all ages and yet is very good.

The only people who it would not appeal to are people who think board games should not be fun.

RATING: 6
A wonderfully over-produced, crazily chaotic, dice-rolling game with unnecessarily yet gratifyingly huge, splashy components.  It's fun.  It's not amazing, and you could probably give me any game with awesome dice and I'd likely enjoy just rolling dem bones, but it moves along at a good clip and provides decent entertainment value for what it is.  What it really needs, though, is a differentiation of the monster characters that is reportedly provided with the expansion.  The theme and artwork don't hold a lot of appeal for me, personally, but it works for a light bash-up like King of Tokyo.  Game design: 3.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 2.5/5  Total: 6/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cute Yahtzee-ish filler where each player controls a monster ravaging Tokyo: dice either gain you points, collect energy (to purchase and activate cards with game-breaking engine abilities) or do damage. If you do damage and you're in Tokyo, you hurt everyone; otherwise, you hurt whoever [i]is[/i] in Tokyo, and if they choose to retreat you take over.

Great art contributes to a filler that's great for what it is, but the lack of balance and strong luck level are only forgivable at filler length; play-time is uneven and the game can wear out its welcome if players take too long to die. In my experience, if you ever start to pray for death during a game, it's not a good sign.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's amazing how much fun it is considering a typical game lasts only 15-20 min. It may seem silly reading the rules, but the power cards add the right amount of planning without making it fiddly. Really looking forward to the expansion (Hey IELLO, cardboard monsters are cool and all, but we want DOLLS!).

Expansions: Promo cards
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Of the games I own, there is no game that is more popular. It is easy to learn, and almost anyone I play with loves the game. While I do enjoy this game, a lot of people who learn to play this game ONLY want to play this game. If they get tired of playing it they are usually not open to learning new board games. As a result, while the game does a great job capturing the attention of non-gamers, I don't recommend this game to be their first. I find that the friends I introduce other gateway-to-board-games type games (e.g. Takenoko, Love Letter) first will not be as clingy with King of Tokyo. I find this to be interesting. Perhaps this is telling of some of the friends I have and how addicting this game can get. If I'm hosting a game night and they are demanding KoT every time, I will simply tell them to buy their own copy and host their own game night. If anyone invites me to their place and plays KoT I will more than happily play and enjoy. But if I want to avoid losing my sanity playing KoT every night of my life, I will keep it out of my rotation when I host. 

Artwork- 9
Ease to Teach- 10
Fun- 9
Mechanics- 5
Replay Value- 7
Strategy- 5
Theme- 10

55/70= 78.6%

RATING: 8
After a few plays in larger group, a few in two players I may say what I think: This is stupid, random game. All is based on luck. Nonetheless, quite playable, but only to the limits of being tired with limited control over the game. You may take a few strategies here: Roll for victory points (a bit too strong ability), roll for energy and buy more special cards (good thing but too many cards with crappy skills dissolve the deck to a point of being almost useless) or roll for damage – but most of the wounds could be healed within a turn so what’s the point? If cards would be more important a maybe a pip cheaper, playing for cards and building some strategies on them may be more useful. If victory points would be a bit harder to obtain, more would play for cards etc. The game feels balanced but not necessarily in a perfect direction.

Two players game sucks, game is unplayable. +.5 to the ranking for excellent graphic design and good box with almost perfect inlay. +.5 to the ranking because I can still play it some more, but I think after 5-6 more plays I will trade it away.

RATING: 7
Fun little dice game. The only problem I have with it, is that the special ability cards seem to cost a lot and most people will see only 1 in the entire game. Wish going for them was more of a viable option, or that there was more available. I'm sure it is an easy house rule, but playing as-is it seems a bit weird. Also, some of the cards (Wings) are so powerful that if anyone manages to get them they can easily run away with the game. Besides that though, it is definitely a fun quick dice game that is a good way to start or end a gaming session.

RATING: 8.9
Santa cucaracha! Vaya juego, y mira que lo coges y miras la caja, y la remiras, y dudas si es un juego para niños o no, no te convence. El dependiente de la tienda te dice qeu es alucinate y sigues sin verlo claro, no... mejor no...

y luego vas y juegas, como obligado, como por no hacer el feo a ese colega que no para de hablar de el. En ese momento te conviertes tu en ese colega pesao alucinado de este juego.

El Kingof, es el juego de largo que más amigos se han comprado. eh! y no llega ni a 30€!

Holly cockroach! what a game! You first take a look at it, and then you relook at it. You doubt. Is it a kids game? The shopkeeper insist "it´s a blast!". But not, you don´see it that way.

Then, you go and play it. Not because you like the game but for not being a bad guest at your friend´s. He insist even more than the shopkeeper. At this precise moment you became your friend, now you´re the one that can´t stop talkin´ about "King of"

By far, "King of" is the game that most of my friends have purchased. hey! and it´s even a cheap game!

RATING: 7
Good silly fun. Its light and fast playing, and I like the wide variety of power cards. The combat and point gathering is well done, though scoring is very dependent on lucky rolls.
Downsides: Player elimination, though at least you shouldn't be out too long here. Components aren't great; some of our dials are peeling apart slightly, and the dice, not being etched, aren't going to last.

House rule: In a 5+ player game, a player going into Tokyo Harbor does NOT damage the player already in Tokyo.

RATING: 6.5
A quick and fun light game (that's made better by the expansions)... if it is played as a QUICK and fun light game. I've experienced a handful of games where players took a relatively long time deciding on their dice rolls and that sort of play style makes the game incredibly boring. A good game for non-gamers, young gamers, and families alike, but your mileage may vary outside of that.    

p.s. Never play this game with 2 people. Ever. =)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun light game that can fall flat if everybody just focus on getting points. The game is much better if your try to kill each other, and much quicker. 

The huge amounts of cards mean every game will be different. 

Not a lot of decisions to be made, but it's more a push your luck game. Do you stay in Tokyo a bit longer or do you flee? Do you go for energy and cards, or health? Or maybe you want to take control of Tokyo? 

Some card combos can be really over-powered but the game is short enough that it doesn't bother me.

The two expansions (power-up! and Halloween) are great additions to the game so don't hesitate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
#Players: 2-6
Time: 30 mins
Mechanic: Dice

Become the last monster standing or the most destructive monster in a rampage to take over Tokyo. Roll the dice to determine your attack, destruction, or energy for the turn. Mutate your monster to fight better or simply destroy the opposition.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
King of Tokyo is perhaps my favorite game of all time.  It is a dice rolling, press your luck game that still has some elements of strategy and decision making to make the game more interesting.  It lasts for a perfect length, perhaps 30mins-90mins so it is not so short it feels unrewarding and not so long that you want it to end.

There is really nothing I would change about the game, while it is a bit on the simpler side, the heavy die rolling and light gameplay makes for a lot of laughs and good times. I have never found someone who disliked the game and never has someone gotten mad or competitive, the game just breeds fun and perhaps for that reason it raises what would be an 8 or 9 game to an easy 10.

I would also recommend checking out the expansion, while the game doesn't need it, it can make the game a little more complex and interesting. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
RAWR!  SMASH!  
I was apprehensive at first.  Great looking bits, excellent theme... but it can't be as bad as Monsters Menace America right?  Pleasant surprise, what looked like a random dice fest akin to Yahtzee turned out to be a delightfully playable and amusing little risk taking game.  Theres a little more than just random luck here as it is more highly choice driven than pure die rolls.  Its fast, dirty and proving to be a terrific light filler game.  Highly expandable in the future, I'd like to see a little less player elimination from it down the road, but its fast and amusing enough that sitting out isn't so bad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great theme. A certain segment of the population likes this. Dh has a great time with the boys. Personally, any game that could throw you out of the game in the first few turns doesn't strike me as that fun. Very random and can also drag on and on trying to get someone to win.

RATING: 7
This is a huge success in my family.  My 10 and 11 year old daughters love it and we usually play 2-3 games in a sitting.

Average about 20-30 minutes.

The only reason I don't give this game a 10 is that the cards do not seem to find their way into the game very much so the energy cubes kind of play as a consolation prize to a poor turn at the dice.

Anyone who focuses purely on the Yatzee mechanic of the game seems to win every time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A dice game with a goofy theme that I didn't think I'd like -- but I do, quite a bit! Don't look for heavy strategy, but there is strategy. You have to know when to push your luck, and when to back off; when to attack, and when to get the heck out of Tokyo. The cards add special powers, but also extra strategy. The game is best played quickly, loudly, and with a group ready to get into the cartoony theme. Although there is player-elimination, the short play-time keeps things moving.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Another good gateway. Lightweight dice game, mechanics reminiscent of Yahtzee but with monsters smashing each other instead of "Yay, sixes".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is silly fun, with an enjoyable theme and lots of big dice to roll. It's a bit of a throwback in that it's fairly luck dependent and has player elimination. The high luck factor doesn't bother me because the game is short and goofy. The player elimination bothers me, though. It was interesting to play a game with player elimination after several years of playing games without it. I think it was a mechanism better off left in the past. Still, a pretty fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Not the most strategic game, but it's definitely a lot of fun.  It plays fast and works well with 3 to 6 players.  Everyone I've played it with has wanted to play again.  The power cards are pretty unbalanced, but I don't have a problem with that for this sort of game.  I don't have a desire to buy the game, but it's perfect for playing occasionally at your FLGS.

Update: I'm getting bored with this, especially with more than 4 because of the downtime.  Still good in the right situations, but I will probably never suggest playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I liked this one quite a bit. Even though it's just monster Yahtzee, it retains quite a bit of atmosphere. I like that there's a constant choice between grabbing points and slowing others down with a healthy dose of damage. The decision of whether to stick it out in Tokyo for a full round to pick up points also can be tough. My only quibble with the game is the vanilla monsters, which are identical other than the stand-up silhouette. The energy cards eventually give some monsters different abilities, but starting each one off with some small power to make them unique from the get-go would have added nicely to the flavor. But overall, this is good take-that fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Despite all the bluster, King of Tokyo doesn't offer any meaningful decisions.  The art is comical and the cards are a great idea.  Unfortunately, the oversized dice (wich can hardly be bothered to roll) rarely pose even a passing decision. The result is an attractive but simple game that plays itself.

Victoria's Rating: 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I picked this up at the same time as Quarriors (as a point of reference).  They have some similarities, but mostly they are both super fillers.

Right now, I have to say I love King of Tokyo.  With the cards and the push your luck element, it just feels right.  It doesn't try to do too much, and what it does, it does so well.  

UPDATE:

This is one of the best games of 2011, and one of the best fillers I have ever played.  It is super quick, a breeze to teach, and has tremendous hooks.  The cards are what tend to make the game click, as they offer all manner of whacked-out powers, ways to bend almost break the game.  For under $30, it is an absolute steal.  The dice are printed, card stock is so-so, and the stand-ups are kind of forgettable.  But you play this game because it is fun, not because you are proud of the way it looks.  It is shallow, true, but man is it fun.

RATING: 4
I mean... it's a kids game. That's really the defining feature. It has a card deck, kaiju is a really fun concept, it has a lot of adult fans... there were reasons I thought it would be more... it's a kids game. It's actively too simple to be enjoyable as an adult. Think Chutes and Ladders or Candy Land... It may be a little deeper, but not enough. Don't bother if you don't have kids... even if you do... see if they can handle something that'll stimulate you more... Imhotep or Evolution or something.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A dice-driven combat game for 2-5 players. Game is simple to learn and plays extremely fast. Theme consists of various monsters duking it out for control of Tokyo. Most games seem to last only 15-30 minutes. Definitely falls into the filler game category, as there isn't a terrible amount of strategic depth to the game. I don't typically enjoy games which are quite this reliant on luck (dice-driven), so I'm not always in the mood to play. I find the game can be fun when used as a warm-up game, a break from games of other types, or when used as a gateway game to introduce others into the hobby of board gaming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Can be a lot of fun, but has some issues. Depending on the cards that people get and the amount of healing that each player does, this game can drag for far too long.

People also tend to understate the player elimination in this game. Unlike something like Love Letter where a round is so quick that player elimination isn't a problem, in KoT you can get eliminated early and have to wait 30-45 minutes for a game to finish. That's never fun.

Sold.

RATING: 5

I use a variant I created called [thread=821635][/thread]. It doubles the number of energy cubes you get from an energy roll, essentially getting more cards into play much quicker. This makes the game much more interesting and different every time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I find this game very addictive (about 15 plays so far).

I love dice, I love the theme, I love the light confrontation.  Why isn't this a 9?

It isn't a 9 because of the player elimination.  You can play for 10 minutes then sit out for 20 minutes watching others play. The consequences of risky play are not just losing a game (no problem), but sitting around watching others play for too long (problem).  

A dice rolling game should not discourage high risk play so much.

I have also come to the realization that if this had a theme that was even a bit less fun or art and components that were even a bit less engaging this game would not get nearly the play for me that it does.  This stuff matters a lot more with light games.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 2
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 2
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 3
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3


Overall - 2

RATING: 9
This has quickly become my favorite filler game, by a lot. King of Tokyo is simple, fast and very engaging. It has a bit of depth but not so much that analytical players will slow things down trying to do fuzzy math. The campy theme makes the game accessible to a broad demographic and welcome at most gatherings (even in groups that typically only enjoy "party" games). My daughter also loves this game (current age 6), making it a family favorite.

RATING: 5
Ameri"trash" at its best!

Well this is a fun and refreshing game! Great components, great and super silly story/narrative, great replayability, excellent flow of play and several decisions along the way. In addition, it plays extremelly fast! I never thought I'd have so much fun ravanging Tokyo with a pink cyber-bunny!

Of course the game has lots of luck and chaos in it, but never to the point that it becomes annoying.

All in all, king of Tokyo is an excellent AT filler with a ridiculusly extravagant fantasy theme. Unfortunatelly, this is a category that I really dislike.

RATING: 6
A fan if I need to play something simple with my non-gaming friends. It has often gotten picked over games such as Cards Against Humanity on game nights. For this I am glad. It's got wonderful art, and it was easy to pick up. Expansions are great additions and worth the pick up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
In the late '00s, there was a wave of criticism of the then current crop of Eurogames as being JASE (just another soulless euro).  There was definitely some truth to this, as many euro designs were heading down the path of jumbling together a bunch of cube pushing mechanisms that worked well but lacked theme or immersion or the ephemeral "fun."

Well, the pendulum has now swung completely in the opposite direction with King of Tokyo.  Monsters!  Yay!  It has theme!  But ... it is basically Yahtzee with 95% or more of the decisions removed.  So what has been created here is not the themeless game, but the gameless theme.  Once you get over the fact that it has monsters battling in Tokyo (which surprisingly few seem to be able to look past) you find ... nothing.  There is no real game here.  I'm completely baffled that it gets so much love.  No real decisions at all, the always intriguing prospect of getting eliminated so you can watch two others roll dice at each other for 15 minutes, and did I mention no decisions?  If you're really in the mood for something this pointless and mindless, why not just turn off your brain entirely and watch some reality tv?  Just to keep your games played log numbers up?

But ... it has monster!  Yay!  So I'll bump it up from a 1 rating to a 2.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
Fun dice chucker, though a bit too easy to get eliminated and some of the upgrades are unbalanced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very simple yet exciting and fun game. Extremely easy to teach and play. There are some tactics, I guess you could say, but mainly it's just a game about tension and fun. This one is an absolute masterpiece in the eyes of young boys, but it definitely works with almost everyone. Note though, that it's not really fun with only two players, even with the pretty decent variants out there. Some of the cards are abit unclear in their wording as to how exactly they function, but that is very limited. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love this game, really easy to explain and then you're straight into it.  The cards are cool, the dice are cool and it plays really quick, shame there are no miniatures for the monsters but the cardboard cut outs have good artwork.  I do really love the art style for everything in this game, really attracted me to it.  It's just really fun yet really simple to pick up.  

I'm really impressed by how much fun it is, it a really good fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
King of Tokyo é um jogo rápido e divertido, uma excelente opção para iniciar pessoas no mundo dos boards e cardgames. Não há grande dependência de idioma (pouco texto nas cartas utilizadas). O jogador traça sua estratégia através da rolagem de dados e escolha dos resultados obtidos. Uma característica ruim do KoT é a eliminação de jogadores, fazendo com que a pessoa que foi eliminada tenha que aguardar o início de outra partida para poder jogar novamente.

RATING: 7
A really fun game! Roll the dice, do some damage, or try for points. Could this be the time to heal or to bash? Keep the two 1 or the one 3 and go for it? King of Tokyo isn't the a heavy-decision game. It's dice fun with big cardboard monster clomping each other to be the most famous (or the last standing) monster.

Not everyone that played, liked it. KoT has its quirks (luck being a thing not everyone if fond of), and won't be a winner all-around. Still, it works in several situations and with people that like to chuck dice.

****

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/939015/king-of-tokyo-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-por]here[/url].

Variability and randomness super present, but doesn't feel like crap. All-around just fun dice-chucking game.

RATING: 7.5
Power up expansion is a must - Love the Evolutions

With 3-5 people it is wonderful and one of those games everyone should own - More ppl is more fun

Perfect filler and just plain fun - every time my friends and I meet, someone wants to pull it out and play a game

Played with Halloween Expansion and was great - wish the monsters not in that expansion got the pass around evolutions, though - seems it almost makes the Halloween monsters too powerful - will see after more plays (even with them, a 'normal' monster still won)

We play A LOT - group loves it but it is beginning to get a bit ho hum for me - rating down a bit though still fun

---------------------

After more plays I feel the Halloween expansion is a bit flat - the costumes are kinda wonky, etc....adds a bit too much to the game and tries to be more then what it is (kind of like the 7-Wonders Leaders Expansion)  Will most likely leave this out on future plays

RATING: 7
great fun, with a wide range of age group appeal.  It's a good game with some beer n chips, and you get to chuck around dice!

Dice are kinda too big for me personally ( but my daughter loves the chunkiness, and I guess they are bright and visibile for everyone at a party table)

Artwork is bright and appealing, although hit n miss.  Some of the characters are great, the board fire and explosions are a bit janky :S  All the card artwork is probably the best.

This game has some fun randomness and there are enough tactics to try to keep you interested throughout a game.

Good game to own for a wide range of occasions - from grown up game nights where no-one wants to play anything super heavy, and for kids and family fun!

RATING: 6
King of Tokyo features an over the top flavor, smash 'em up game play, and light strategy.  The dice are oversize, and the standee monsters actually fit the game better than any well molded resin figures could.  This is the perfect game for some drunk gaming.  Here is a classic example of a game design shooting low and hitting the target well, making it a nice one to own to round out your collection.

RATING: 7.5
Good:
-A ton of interaction
-Family game
-Strategy helps a lot but good rolls trump strategy
-Interesting decisions throughout
-Power cards make the game more interesting

Bad:
-Power cards confuse non-gamers
-Some power cards are open to interpretation
-Some power cards seem too powerful (Wings & Jets)

Overall:
I'd recommend this game for any gaming group but think it's a stretch to call this a gateway game.  It will go well with just about anyone open to board games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun filler with sci-fi monsters, special dice and power cards. With attractive artwork and an appealing theme. However, I do need to be in the mood for a game with such randomness (lots and lots of dice rolling). And when played with more than 4 players, it is possible that it outstays its welcome in terms of playing time. Also, there is always a good chance that some players will be eliminated halfway through the game, so make sure that it is played with people who do not mind that too much. All in all, I think that there is too much hype surrounding this game. It is fun with a fantastic theme, but I would rather play Diamant/Incan Gold if I am in the mood for a pretty random risk taking game with a large group. Mainly because it has less downtime. Still, King Of Tokyo is very fun with the right group (like for example my teenage son :-)).
UPDATE: The more I play this game, the more I like it! I see now how you can guesstimate your chance of survival by assessing the intentions and the playstyle of the next players in line, making sure to leave (or enter!) Tokyo in time. Simple game, good fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A dice game at heart, players roll for victory points to win the game or eliminate enough opponents to become king of the hill. I did not find any earth-shattering novelty for this game and honestly, just a simple design that works. The game plays relatively quick and will likely work well with younger players. Since this is a dice game, loads of luck everywhere throughout the game. There really is not a whole lot of decision making.

This game also plays poorly with two.

022213: Plays a lot better with five. Much better. After several more plays with 5 players, this game's ranking rises a point. I look forward to playing with different groups since it is very light, fast and actually, the game play is quite tight. Sure, there is player elimination, but the variety from the card power makes it fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
The first player to reach 20 victory points is the winner, or you can kill everyone else. Everyone has 10 life points at the start.
The gameplay is very simple, you just roll dice in a "Yatzi" mechanism and try to do damage to your opponents and avoid damage yourself. You can also roll victory points or flash symbols with which you can buy cards with instant effects or assets to "improve" your rolls. Or you can roll hearts to heal you.
The first player to reach 20 victory points is the winner, or you can kill everyone else.
The first player to roll an attack symbol goes to tokyo (you always get victory points when you're in tokyo and additional points if you're still in there when it is your turn again.)
The guy in tokyo now attacks every other player whereas every other player attacks the guy in tokyo. And the big problem of tokyo is that you cannot heal yourself there. Always when you take damage in tokyo, you can decide whether to stay or leave. If you leave, the player damaging you that round goes to tokyo and you are attacking him then etc.
The "gambling" aspect when you're in Tokyo becomes more intriguing when you are playing with more than 4 players.
It plays very quickly so there's a good thing to this but overall it's not my favourite game since it becomes quite boring after a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun theme and fun game. The expansion is not good, but the KoT base game is great.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Fun monster themed dice game.  Somewhat similar to Yahtzee, but the cards and the king of the hill aspect add a lot more interaction.  The theme is fun and the components are nice (though I would have preferred engraved dice rather than stickers).  Secret Santa gift from 2011.

Edit: got the engraved dice.  Also, we have started playing with a variant where in a two player game you don't gain a vp for entering Tokyo and you only get 1 for starting your turn there.  These two simple changes make the two player game much much better!

RATING: 9
Fun game, especially for kids, where everyone is a monster, and you play "King of the Hill" by seeing who can stay in Tokyo the longest. If you are in Tokyo you make the most points, but you take the most damage, as everyone else is attacking you. Clever game with a great theme, and very fun. 

Note: the new King of New York has recently been released and the reviews say that it's better than King of Tokyo unless you also buy the two expansion card sets for King of Tokyo. If you're going to get all the expansions get this one; King of New York is a much better deal for just the stand-alone game, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really like King of Tokyo. I would say that my rating might be a bit inflated and would likely go down if I started playing it more.

KoT is a very basic game that uses a mechanic that most people are already familiar with. This the the Yahtzee choose your dice and roll up to 3 times. Except KoT adds in Monsters that are trying to control the city of Tokyo and crush other monsters. There are a lot of good things about KoT like you don't specifically attack any other monster (thus p*ssing them off) while in tokyo and instead attack them all. There are a couple different ways to victory for people who like to play different ways. The strength in this game is how light and fun it is. I think both of the expansions bog this game down, make it last too long and I would not recommend either one.

KoT is great fun. If you think about it as a light game that can start off the night, you can't go wrong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I’ve only played this once, so I can’t really give too much insight about the game itself. But I can definitely see why this game gets as much hype as it does. Really easy to learn and fun to play.

RATING: 5
Not that much here, but somewhat forgivable as a short game.  Better as a game for ~4 players, which is disappointing as the theme makes it seem like it wants 6+.  Much of the strategy here is about trying to identify the groupthink and exploit it.  Decisions are almost entirely tactical.  Use of the Yahtzee mechanic of saving dice between rolls is well-utilized, if not particularly innovative.  All in all, this is a forgettable game with a great theme.  If this wasn't a cool and underutilized theme, nobody would be looking twice at this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After a couple games I was a bit disappointed. It seemed like going to Tokyo made no sense at all since everyone would just beat you. But that was because everyone was rolling for attacks dice, we thought everything else was useless because 20 points seemed so far... But if everyone is aggressive then it's better to just roll for points and avoid attacking at all! But as more people start to roll for points then you're better of in Tokyo because nobody attacks you anyway!

I like how you need to adapt your strategy to the state of the game. There is much more depth than one might think.

RATING: 5
Rated after four games. The game has a simple idea and mechanics. I kind of liked it, but it didn't really hit me. Quite light and random, a Yahtzee variant. The game is easy to learn, so it is good for new gamers.

Works quite well with four players, but even then there's lots of downtime. With more players even more. Includes player elimination and lots of luck, not much of choices to make.

Updated after fifth play, dropped the rating to 4. We had four players and I just felt bored.

5th play felt better than what I expected, there were 5 players now. There was lots of hitting, so it was not that boring. And it only lasted 20 minutes, when the winner killed others during the same turn. Updated the rating from 4 to 5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was expecting this game to be a light dice-fest with a funny theme, and I wasn't disappointed; it's basically another board game based on the Yahtzee rules.  I was actually surprised to find that the game has a pretty decent system, to boot.  I like the balance between hitting the gruesomes who aren't in Tokyo, and the gruesome in Tokyo hitting the other gruesomes.  I'm not wild about the player elimination aspect of the game, but it played pretty quickly, and I found myself rooting for mayhem after I was wiped out early in the game.  I'd definitely play it again.

6 plays: 5 players
1 play: 6 players

RATING: 6
It never feels particularly exciting. 

The cards seem like a lumpy afterthought- either irrelevant or so OP that the game is a race for a single purchase, won by luck. 

Lots of bash the leader, but then if everybody _doesn't_ bash the leader, they run away quite quickly.

Has also not been a huge hit with less-nerdy friends and family, which seems like the one job this game had.

I don't hate playing it, but it only really comes out when everyone is far too tired to play a proper game. And even then, I'd rather be playing Skulls or Crossing or something like that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
King of Tokyo is just about the perfect game to cap off a game night. It's fast, easy to teach and has just enough player interaction to allow for some smack talk without leaving too many hard feelings when it's over. The scoring mechanism is a little odd, scoring points for matching numbers seems out of place in a game about giant rampaging monsters. The precedent set by the cards makes me think those numbers represent your monster smashing through valuable real estate, but the rules and components do nothing to verify that idea. I'm sure simplicity and ease of use were the motivating factors behind using those numbers, so I don't really consider them to be a flaw...It's just something that stands out as very non-thematic when I teach it.

RATING: 5
A well represented monster theme kids of all ages will enjoy.  Game play is dice simple, but not without having to make some crucial calls on those dice.  Ultimately, I prefer to only play this with kids.  If I want to play a simple game with my buddies, I'd prefer something else.

PLAYING WITH KIDS RATING: [bgcolor=#33CC99][s][color=#33CC99]|[/color][/s][b]9[/b][s][color=#33CC99]|[/color][/s][/bgcolor]
My youngest (5) is lost in this game except that he has a monster and he can choose to be king.  My daughter (8) likes the decision making and has quickly caught on.  They both like spiffing up and modding their monsters.  It's a dice game, but manages a good balance between what you get and what you want.  And of course there is the existential question of to be King of Tokyo, or not to be King of Tokyo.  It's fun to be king, but can you take the heat?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'd had my eye on this game since the first pictures on BGG because of the fantastically cute art.  Having now played it, it looks even better in person.  Among my very favorite game art ever.

The game itself is a lot silly fun.  Lots of cool special abilities that allow you to customize your monster and provide a ton of variability.

The King-of-the-Hill mechanic works great--being King gets you victory points, but also puts a big red X on you and takes away your ability to heal.  The possibility of accidentally winding up King is unique and leads to some pretty funny situations.

The central Yahtzee-style rolling mechanic works just fine, like it does elsewhere.  It feels a bit more random here than in some other games (like Roll Through the Ages or Pickomino) since you are often hoping for just one specific side to come up, and when it doesn't you often can't do anything with a bunch of your dice.  That's ok though, because it's hard to take the game too seriously.  Sometimes you get the crap beat out of you and sometimes you beat the crap out of everyone else, but either way you're hooting and hollering and having a good time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My girlfriend and her family love to play basic games like Jenga, Taboo, and Dominos. Having played with them, I wanted to bring something different to the table. Based of reviews, I knew I wanted this game the moment I saw it, but convincing my girlfriend and her family was my main goal. When they first saw the box, they all laughed and joked around saying that this looked like a little kids game. They soon found out that they could have tons of fun playing this "kids" game. My girlfriend's father(who is supposedly good at games and was telling everyone he was going to win prior to playing) lost in the first 5 minutes which was hilarious. At the end of the day, everyone loved it and we played it multiple times for over 6 hours. This is a wonderful game to start building my board game collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As I was growing up, Yahtzee was probably the most common family game we played. Mom would play. Dad would play. Even my little brother, while he was too young to read, could play Yahtzee and have a good time. As a result of all that tossing of dice in a plastic cup, the core mechanism of the game imprinted on my brain. There's some sort of primal joy that I get from the "roll, keep, roll" action of the game.

Also deeply imprinted on my brain throughout my more impressionable years is a youth of Sunday afternoons watching television matinees of Godzilla films. Guys in rubber suits battling other guys in rubber suits and cities being reduced to rubble.

King of Tokyo successfully mashes up those two core memories for me. You're throwing dice in a Yahtzee-fashion but instead of just adding up points, your dice are your monster, fighting or powering-up or trying to lick his wounds. And the added king-of-the-hill element makes for a great push-your-luck experience.

You monster can sprout poison quills, or spit acid, or have stretchy limbs and it all makes for silly-good fun. And just as my little brother played Yahtzee with us, I was able to introduce this game to my own kids who immediately latched onto it. And that was a pretty proud moment for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I looked forward to getting this game after seeing it on TableTop. I knew my son would love it because of the theme and the dice-rolling mechanic. But something about it just didn't push all our buttons. It's fun, but it's not THAT fun. This is possibly because we've played 2-player mostly, and only once 4-player. The 2-player games devolved into someone camping in Tokyo, scoring 2 points each turn, and hoping the other guy wouldn't roll too many claws. If they didn't, you'd just tough it out and win. The power-up cards are a good addition, but they didn't seem as good as they could be.

Overall, like I said - it's fun, and it's a solid purchase. But it's not one we're going to play the majority of the time.

RATING: 6
This game is super fun and fast. If there was any qualm I have, it's that just as I start to get my cards in tow, the game ends. I would like to see the cards used more. The game as a 2-player game, although very slightly amusing, greatly lacks the spark and frenzy that come with more players. Certainly a 3+ player game without question.

This is definitely a game I feel would be advantageous to own because it is accessible to so many ages, larger groups and it can be fit into nearly any time-frame at all.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is what Yahtzee should be if Yahtzee were a good game and had any theme.  Roll 6 dice and have up to 2 rerolls. Can try to attack other players to take control of Tokyo (which gives points every turn), gain energy (money) to buy cards with special abilities, heal your wounds, or gain points.

Game plays incredibly fast and there is actually some strategy for what dice you choose to reroll each turn. I usually hate games that revolve around luck of rolling dice, but this was not bad at all. I could see this getting very boring after a while, though, since at the end of the day, you're still just rolling dice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
The best gateway game I have tried, due to it being fast paced and pretty simple and with a fun theme.  Not much thinking though so more for those who (sometimes) like a game that is light on the brain cells.
Despite being into heavier games now, I still have a blast with this one when it comes out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can't believe how much fun I had with this simple game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a lightweight dice game with maximum player interaction.  The object is simple:  be the first to score 20 victory points, or be the last player standing.  Last monster standing, actually.  Each player assumes the role of a monster invading Tokyo.  The game is easy enough to teach to even non-gamers in a few minutes, and yet there are various strategies that must be employed in order to win.  The game is fast and fun.  The artwork on the cards is very well done and adds to the enjoyment.  The theme is totally integrated into the gameplay.  It's a light filler for gaming groups, but also appropriate to bring out with non-gaming groups.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
C.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was unexpectedly impressed with the "damage many others" mechanic: Those monsters inside Tokyo damage those on the outside, and vice versa.  And if you want to flame out and take 2-3 other inhumanoids with you - knowing that you won't last another round - you can.  That's a thing of beauty.

This would be an instant purchase at $15-20.  But it's a "nevermind" at whatever exorbitant price they're charging.

RATING: 7
A fun yahtzee type game. Rules can be taught in couple minutes and the theme generally goes over great with everyone.

My big gripes with this one are the player elimination (at higher player counts this can really hurt) and the fact that if you've got any luck with the dice, you can just roll for VP and generally pull off a win.

All the same, with new players who don't know this fact yet, the game is great! Just not one I'd bring to a table of highly experienced (and competitive) gamers.

RATING: 7.5
At its heart, this really is just a simple dice game. There is some strategy, but not much. It does, however, pair the theme nicely with the mechanics, which are themselves fairly original. It also gets bonus points for production value, though I find it a bit of a shame that they went so overboard with it simply because it was designed by Richard Garfield.

Anyway, it's fun, which is what counts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Like the artwork.

RATING: 10
I really enjoy push-your-luck dice games and you couldn't have a better theme on top of such a mechanism, King of Tokyo is a match made in heaven!

The game looks fantastic. The humor of the cards and characters is well done and very evocative and funny. This is a great game, especially if you have a sense of humor and don't mind player elimination.

After 10 plays with everything for 3-6 players, I must increase my rating to "10", this is an excellent game and one I'm likely never to tire of, especially with promised expansion due out before long. This has already become a favorite opener, closer and filler in my gaming group, and we even love an entire evening playing nothing but this game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]GodZILLA-FILLER![/b]


[i]Kong[/i] of the Hill Yahtzee style dice-fest.

[b]When the red moon sets, and the sun rises in the West, two monsters will appear to save the people.[/b] 

1. Huge great chunky dice. Surprisingly meaty in my clunky great paws.
2. Short and sweet rulebook. You only [i]really[/i] need a one-sheet. Trouble is, in this dazzling interweb age, there are so many morons playing games, and asking dumb questions about those games, that game publishers have to try and provide 100-page idiot-proof rules (Mission: Impossible). The rulebook here is clear and colourful. Back in the day, this would have been a photocopied black and white printed wafer-thin sheet, accompanied by a ridiculous questionnaire that needed posting to Atlanta or some-place, and a wargames catalogue of delights.
3. Fantastic giga-monster theme. Everybody loves huge killy monsters. And splashing in muddy puddles.
4. Fast playing. Yeah, it's a filler. McD's cheeseburger-like filler. Sometimes I like me one of those, and I could eat two on the trot.
5. Excellent evocative art on the action cards - are all well named and fit the Toho company B-movie stylee, ensuring dramatic reading during gameplay: [i]He's grown another head! She's had a son! Crikes - look at all the grabby tentacles you now have! It's a absorbing all the energy. He's eating a skyscraper! Christ, it's growing even bigger! Shit - he's breathing radioactive fire at me![/i] type of thing.
6. Box and contents feel classy, not cheapo.
7. Simple and straightforward mechanisms.
8. Gateway game, certainly. Might even see if my GF will try it - I know my daughter will be a potential target for KoT when she's a teeny bit older.
9. There's room for light strategic play in here. Do I play passively or aggressively or build up my super powers? Obviously you switch it any way you like, dice depending.
10. Interesting decisions. Each turn you'll agonise over whether to concentrate on healing, fighting, energy conservation, or go on a victory point drive. Plus there's the choice of special powers to buy or save up for. Another thing (decision) is whether to stay as King of Tokyo, fighting back with your mega-paws the pretenders to your urban throne (while you hoover up valuable victory points), or yield like a surrender monkey, letting a helmeted 300' high spider-legged alien into Tokyo city.
11. Fun - in a laugh-out-loud manner occasionally. Especially if idiots like me make silly monster screeches during play, or your friends make declarations like "Now I have a massive new brain!"
12. Can cope with up to six players - ensuring, with 5-6 friends, that you will have two 'hills' to fight over: Tokyo city and Tokyo bay.
13. Fast to learn. Takes minutes, and everyone knows how to throw dice - so it feels intuitive and smooth.


[b]O' Godzilla! Destroy the people of Japan, who once tried to conquer the Azumi Tribe! You will be the instrument of our revenge! O' Godzilla![/b]

1. Yeah - you could be slaughtered before getting to do much, in a 4+ player game, but the game's short, and trashy, enough that an [i]elegant[/i] solution to that 'wasn't thought up'/'or needed' - delete as your confirmation bias allows.
2. Luck of the dice can be cruel. You get at least 2 re-rolls, but it's still luck. Managed luck, to a degree, however. BUT, you're not just rolling bones here, folks, you also have to manage your energy (represented by cubes) and your special monster powers (represented by cards). So there's that.
3. Shame it's not an actual Godzilla-themed game, but that's not a biggie for me - there's enough daft monsters to keep most people happy, with all the major monster 'stereotypes' covered; you know, big lizard, mecha lizard, giant monkey, huge fighty robot of destruction, etc.
4. Because it's a King of the Hill game, you are beating up on the leader each turn; but, as the leader, you beat back heavier on those lesser monsters who wanna muscle in on your Tokyo throne.
5. Not convinced on the greatness of the 2-player game. If you need an exciting and fun pastime before cracking out Dune for your group, I'd heartily recommend KoT.
6. Similar to Yahtzee and some other games. Knizia's [i]Scarab Lords[/i] has a 'wait a turn before grabbing any points' system too. I liked it there, and I like it here, but I will not eat green eggs and ham, Sam I am!

 
TRIVIA: Did you know that Godzilla even has his own star on the Hollywood walk of fame? Well, he does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good, fast dice game.  It's all luck, but the "attack your opponents" mechanic gives incentive to go for something other than just rolling points (a downside to dice games like Zombie Dice, for instance).  
One thing this game really requires is the mutations expansion (a way to further augment your monsters powers - differentiating yours from everyone else's) .  It's a shame it isn't a default component, cause, really, once you've played with it, you won't ever play a game without.

RATING: 8
If someone told me that a game totaly based on yahtzee could be so fun I would never have believed him. And that's what really King of Tokyo is plus some special cards. And YES it is really fun! I don't know what it is, some games aren't supposed to be fun but they simply are. Love it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Basically it's a modern(?) version of Yahtzee. That being said this is the most entertaining Yahtzee me and my group has ever played. I may be dumbing things down when I said modern version of Yahtzee but the element of rerolling dices based on the situation and your ability to push your luck is similar to Yahtzee. But this is not Yahtzee. As much as there is deep in Yahtzee, so is King of Tokyo in itself. The mechanics of buying power ups and being able to invade Tokyo for power ups definitely makes the game a game of it's own. There is a lot of replay value for this game. Though there are some caveats as player elimination is possible and also a viable strategy to win. Aside from that this game is a must have. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Oozes fun and is very easy to teach and enjoy. The cards are great fun and give each player (that is, monster) his/her own personality. It plays well with a wide range of players. 

Now to nitpick a little: the insert isn't particularly functional. Once I added the promo cards and expansions, which I recommend everyone do, I tossed said insert. The quality of the components (the dice in particular) should have been higher. Be aware I own a first edition. I believe the components were better in subsequent printings.
